In conclusion, while I support the preservation of library materials in general, offensive materials should be removed to ensure a positive experience for all users.

I don't think books, magazines, movies, and music should be removed from libraries. However, I do believe that access to these materials should be monitored based on age. Younger children should not be exposed to adult or teenage - oriented content.  One way to implement this monitoring is through the child's library card. Teenagers also need to be monitored. Even though they are almost adults, some parents may not agree with the materials their teens are accessing. In such cases, there could be stickers on their library cards to indicate the restrictions.  In conclusion, despite the many opinions on what children should read, watch, or listen to, it's important to have measures in place to monitor their access to different materials. This way, we can ensure that children are exposed to appropriate content.

Imagine taking your child to the library. You've worked hard to teach your child respect and good manners. All those values could be undermined if they read a bad magazine or listen to an explicit song.  I support library censorship. Many people wonder where their children learn curse words or inappropriate sexual behavior and don't consider the media as the culprit. Explicit and offensive materials should be removed. I've seen offensive content fall into the hands of kids. For example, a teen - pregnancy book might present options like keeping the baby and facing the consequences or aborting the baby and moving on. In today's society, we seem to be allowing children to do as they please, giving them the impression that we don't care about their actions. However, this is not the case. From personal experience, I know that exposure to such content can rapidly change a person. Nowadays, the media portrays money, alcohol, fame, and drugs as positive things, which are then presented to children through movies, books, and magazines. This is clearly wrong. For all these reasons, we should implement censorship and restrictions in libraries. We are allowing children to grow up too quickly and introducing them to inappropriate things too early. In a sense, we are brainwashing them into leading a destructive life through adult - oriented materials. By taking appropriate measures, we can better protect the healthy development of children.

We often hear the claim that the media is ruining our youth. Teachers, parents, and grandparents all tell us how different their world was. I firmly believe that there should be no censorship. Censorship allows people to control what we learn, destroy information that goes against their beliefs, and violate our God - given right to freedom of speech. In conclusion, while there may be offensive content in the media, books, and music, it is a part of life. We should not impose censorship, as it would undermine our learning, beliefs, and freedom of speech. Allowing censorship could lead us down a dangerous path towards a dictatorship - like situation.

Censorship in libraries is not a necessary solution. Just because some materials may be offensive to certain individuals, it doesn't mean that everything should be censored. Those who find something offensive should simply choose not to engage with it. It should be an individual's choice whether to read a particular item or not. If a person is offended by a book, they can put it down. The book 'To @CAPS1 a @CAPS2' has offended many people, but I found it interesting and educational. The library is a valuable place for learning, discovery, and the acquisition of knowledge, open to anyone willing to explore its vast collections. Offensive religious comments in libraries are unacceptable. Everyone in the @LOCATION1 has the right to choose their own religion and practice it freely. The goal is to protect children from harmful content while still maintaining the diversity of knowledge in libraries. As @CAPS1, we have the privileges of freedom of speech and freedom of expression. Even though some works may be perceived as offensive or inappropriate, I believe they should remain accessible to the public. People may or may not agree with the ideas expressed in these works, but the right to hold an opinion is fundamental. These offensive or harsh pieces of literature can serve as learning tools. Katherine Paterson once said that we can all think of a book we don't want children to take off the shelf. I have read offensive literature myself, but despite its disturbing nature, I'm glad I was exposed to it. Libraries are well - known as places where individuals can access materials on virtually any topic of interest, whether it's a book, movie, or magazine. They are a valuable resource available to everyone. However, it's puzzling why some libraries choose to remove certain valuable materials from their shelves.  In recent years, library censorship has been the focus of numerous news reports. In most cases, library patrons have been outraged that specific materials were deemed unsuitable for the library. I wholeheartedly agree with them. People have the right to choose what they read, watch, and listen to. Opinions vary; what one person loves, another may hate. In conclusion, library censorship is restrictive and unjust. It creates obstacles for those seeking knowledge and takes away people's freedom of choice. Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' I couldn't agree more. I don't think certain materials like books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from libraries. People may need specific information, and these sources offer countless lessons.  For instance, if you need information on religion, you might find a relevant book or movie in the library. Similarly, if you want to learn about sex, a magazine or movie could provide new knowledge.  Different sources teach different lessons. Some people learn through examples presented in movies, music, or magazines. We may not realize it, but we rely on them daily, just like we use search engines.  In conclusion, we need these sources because people may require specific information, different materials teach different lessons, and all sources are valuable assets.

I believe that the right to remove books from library shelves is a bad idea. If this practice starts, libraries across the country will end up with empty shelves. Once the process of removing books begins, very few will remain.  We use books every day. Students rely on them for learning and entertainment in some classes. Books help us learn new words and important historical facts. Even adults enjoy reading in their free time.  It's wrong to remove a book just because some people think it's inappropriate. If so, libraries should have a special section for such books, restricting access to young children. However, a problem arises: which books should go into this section? One solution would be to establish a nationwide library service to set up the system and have people vote on which books to remove or place in the special section across all libraries. This approach can be applied to all library materials.  Another solution is for libraries to adopt a new labeling system in addition to the Dewey Decimal System. This new system could include critic reviews and summaries of the books. This would give readers more information about what they're about to read.  Books, music, and magazines in libraries exist for a reason. Someone wrote or composed them so that people like us can enjoy good stories, read informative magazines, and listen to great music.

Libraries should never remove any material simply because it might be considered offensive. What one person finds offensive may not be offensive to another. If the material violated the law, it probably wouldn't have been published in the first place.  People often get offended when they encounter something that goes against their personal views, ethics, or religion. However, they need to understand that others have different thoughts and values. Each person's opinion is equally important to them.  In today's world, many media sources are censored. It's crucial to have a place where people can freely access materials and express their opinions. As a student, I often struggle to find meaningful literature in the school library due to censorship. I understand that schools need to be cautious about what they expose students to. But it's great to have a public library where I can find more religious, derogatory, or less - accepted materials.  In conclusion, if people are offended by something on a library shelf, they can choose not to read, watch, or listen to it. But we shouldn't censor everything and deprive those who enjoy these materials of easy access.

I firmly believe that books should not be removed from shelves due to being considered offensive. What one person finds offensive may not bother another. While individuals have the right to voice their opinion that a book is offensive, they do not have the right to prevent others from reading it. I understand that parents want to protect their children. Instead of simply banning a book, parents should communicate with their children, explaining why they object to a particular book. They could also allow their children to read it and then discuss their concerns.  I hold the same view regarding the censorship of music and movies. When I was twelve, I started listening to the music I liked, rather than what my mother played. My mother was worried about the lyrical content of the songs I listened to. She refused to buy me the music and prohibited me from listening to it. However, I would go to my friends' houses to listen to explicit music and watch rated movies. She couldn't really stop me because explicit language was everywhere.  I think parents should explain their concerns to teenagers instead of trying to restrict their access to certain music, and then let the teenagers make their own decisions. Censorship should be the responsibility of parents. Sometimes, when parents try to control their children too much, they actually push them away. That's why it's crucial for parents and children to have open and comfortable communication.

Many individuals, including children, parents, and grandparents, visit libraries. I've realized that people go to these community - loved places to find peace and quiet. Some don't even go for the books; they may engage with music, read magazines, enjoy a cup of coffee, or use the internet. Some argue that certain books, music, and movies in libraries are inappropriate or offensive, but does this mean libraries should discard them?  There's no valid reason to ban these offensive materials. Firstly, libraries will lose customers. A large number of people enjoy listening to rap or other similar genres. It's difficult to find such music without swear words or sexual innuendos. Even I occasionally listen to this type of music for its catchy beats. Moreover, when listening to music in a library, people use headphones, so it doesn't disrupt others.  Secondly, customers who dislike the content of these materials don't have to choose them. If a book contains a sex scene or discusses drugs, one can simply avoid it. There are plenty of other books to choose from, including children's books. Those interested in these topics still have the right to select relevant materials. I've visited my public library many times, and I've never seen a book, music, or movie that was unappealing. If someone wants an offensive book, they need to search thoroughly, not just glance around.  Finally, freedom is a fundamental aspect. Isn't that what this country is all about? We have the freedom of speech, religion, and the right to choose the movies we watch. There are labels on movie backs indicating their ratings and content. We have the freedom to borrow or purchase these rated movies. As I've said, no one is forced to watch inappropriate movies, so we can simply choose what we like.  In conclusion, there's absolutely no reason to remove offensive books, music, or movies from libraries. These materials come in various types and styles and don't disturb anyone. Removing them would lead to a loss of customers, people can avoid inappropriate materials, and we have the freedom to choose what we consume. So, it's best to keep these so - called 'offensive' materials.

There are many who believe that certain books, music, movies, and magazines are offensive and should be removed from library shelves. Consider this: if you had to do a project on a subject that some find offensive and there was no information available, wouldn't you be frustrated? Similarly, if you like offensive music, you should be able to listen to it on the radio without worrying about it being removed.  Some people are assigned projects for work or school. If the project's subject is offensive to some, they'll need access to books and other information at the library to complete their work. If all offensive books are removed, people won't be able to finish their tasks.  Some individuals are interested in offensive subjects. For example, if someone is interested in a particular topic like @PERSON1, they'd want to do research. If books and magazines on this subject disappear from library shelves, they won't be able to learn more.  Many think that much of today's radio music is offensive. If all such music is removed, there won't be much left to listen to, and many people will be angry. Additionally, songwriters will lose their source of income and jobs.  I believe that those who find these things offensive should avoid them and stop complaining. People who don't take offense will be glad that books, magazines, music, etc., aren't being removed. I hope that the removal of these materials from libraries and other places is carefully considered.

In my view, if there are offensive books, music, movies, or magazines, we have the right to remove them from library shelves. I have a baby girl, and I don't want her to be exposed to offensive or vulgar content, whether through listening, watching, or reading.  I'm aware that this is a free country, and everyone has the right to their own opinions. Libraries are funded by taxpayers' money. If there are movies, books, music, and magazines that are offensive or vulgar, they should be removed. Children who are exposed to vulgar content may think it's acceptable or cool to say or do such things.  They may see inappropriate pictures, nudity, drugs, and violence. For instance, books may contain pictures of drugs like weed, cocaine, or pills. They may also see images of men hitting women or kids killing kids, which sets a bad example.  We live in a world where people are influenced by what they read, watch, and listen to. It's essential for parents to be aware of what their children are exposed to. The library is a place for learning, and only appropriate materials should be accessible. In conclusion, offensive and vulgar materials should be removed from library shelves to protect the well - being of children.

When entering a library, people have different opinions about what should be on the shelves, especially considering that libraries are accessible to children of all ages. Some believe that only age - appropriate materials should be available, while others disagree.  In my opinion, libraries should have books for all age groups, but there should also be a dedicated children's section. If parents are concerned about the books their children might encounter, they can direct them to the children's section. There's no reason not to have a wide variety of books available.  Regarding magazines, movies, and music, my opinion is somewhat consistent. All types of music should be on the shelves because one can't listen to it just by looking at the cover. However, my stance on magazines and movies is a bit more nuanced. I think all types should be allowed, except for pornography.  The reason for my view is that children shouldn't overly influence what's placed on library shelves. Parents need to be responsible and monitor what their children are looking at. But in a public place like a library, there's a line to be drawn, and that line is clearly at the exclusion of pornography. In conclusion, libraries should offer a diverse range of materials while ensuring that inappropriate content like pornography is not available.

Not all libraries are ideal. Some individuals visit libraries to use the computers and access websites discovered by children. Meanwhile, others need the computers for job applications, and library owners often require patrons to obtain a card. In some respects, this situation is unjustifiable. All kids can learn at the library and complete their work if necessary; there are so many things they can do that they could even stay there all week. From young children to adults, people can still learn in the @NUM1 century. You can learn about your ancestry, car crashes, or current global events. Whether it's Japanese or Chinese culture, you can gain a wealth of knowledge from the library and its books. It's up to families to use the library to learn more about themselves.

With over six billion people in the world, there are six billion distinct personalities and opinions. Removing all offensive media is virtually impossible since almost everyone is offended by something. Some media is more offensive than others, but it might be a subject the author is passionate about, and they could be offended if their opinion is dismissed. With the global accessibility of the internet, media that was once only available in libraries is now online and can't be permanently removed from public view. It's illogical to think that removing materials from libraries will prevent people from being offended. There's a clear difference between raising awareness and being offensive. Some books and magazines aim to explain a culture and increase awareness, but authors worldwide can easily cross the line into offensiveness. Thus, authors should consider the people they're writing about, avoid stereotypes as they can be hurtful. There's already a large amount of offensive literature, and trying to find and restrict it all is irrational. If someone is offended by a written work, they should avoid reading it. However, this doesn't give authors the right to specifically target and offend a group. This is a two - sided issue. It can't be solely controlled by censoring libraries; it also depends on authors and readers. Authors and media producers should consider others and focus on raising awareness rather than offending. Readers should understand why an author might target them and avoid conflict by avoiding the material. Targeting and offending a group in literature is wrong, and simply removing materials from library shelves won't stop this practice. Libraries are becoming less relevant due to new technology, and it's unlikely they'll regain their former prominence. So, censoring libraries may not significantly help offended groups. Everyone has the right to express an opinion, but they should also consider others' feelings. With the abundance of accessible media, writers and producers need to think beyond themselves before publishing.

What one person finds offensive can be very different from another's view. There's a vast amount of offensive material in the world, but removing it all wouldn't change much. Everyone has their own opinions and interpretations of what's offensive, so if we tried to remove all offensive materials, there'd be little left. For every piece of content, there's usually someone with a negative view. They might misunderstand it or simply think it's wrong. When asked what's offensive, people have diverse answers. For example, my grandpa loves all kinds of music and his life is centered around it. My grandma, on the other hand, dislikes some of his music because she says it goes against her beliefs. She pays close attention to the lyrics, while my grandpa focuses on the rhythm and beat. They often disagree about what music to listen to because of this difference in perception. If you ask people what they find offensive, you'll get countless different answers. If we removed content based on the sensitivities of a few, it would almost mean removing everything. So, I firmly believe that offensive materials shouldn't be pulled off the shelves.

Personally, I don't think books, music, movies, or magazines should be removed from the shelves just because they're considered offensive. However, I do think we need to protect young, developing children from reading books that might offend them or introduce concepts that could hinder their educational development. Kids who haven't been properly educated on controversial topics like drugs or alcohol might make bad decisions based on what they read. To address this issue, I propose a book - rating system. Similar to movie and video - game ratings, this system would indicate the appropriate age level for a book and explain the factors used for the rating. As a newspaper company, you're well - aware of our rights as citizens, including freedom of speech and freedom of the press. I don't think removing 'inappropriate' books from the shelves is a reasonable solution. I know from personal experience that when my rights are taken away, I get very angry. Authors, editors, photographers, and publishers work hard to put books on the shelves. Removing them would be a suppression of their rights as citizens. If I were an author and my book was removed, I'd be extremely upset. This could even lead to an author's strike until their books are available to readers again. However, as I mentioned, a book - rating system is a good idea. It allows authors to express themselves fully while informing readers about controversial content. I strongly recommend that you consider this proposal as it could prevent future conflicts between authors and the public.

Why censor content? Are there movies, music, magazines, books, and other media in libraries that some people find offensive? Many believe so, while others aren't concerned. Should this content be removed from public library shelves or allowed to stay? Katherine Paterson stated that if one person has the right to remove a book they dislike, then everyone has that right, and eventually, there'll be no books left. Personally, I think some literature and magazines should be removed from libraries. Many books are filled with foul language, violence, and sexual content. For instance, I once went to a local library with my little sister. She was looking for a Disney magazine, but there were provocative magazines with half - naked women on the covers right next to the kids' magazines. This is an inappropriate image, and no parent wants their child exposed to such content at a young age. The music in libraries is also not clean. A lot of today's music promotes sex, violence, and drugs. My father always says that music in the past was suitable for all ages. Hip - hop and rap are the main culprits for inappropriate content, but rappers and producers are just creating what people want and what sells. Movies rented from libraries are also offensive. They contain similar inappropriate material as books, magazines, and music, all presenting an image that seems to appeal to a large part of society. Can't we find better content to attract the audience? In conclusion, I believe this offensive material should be removed from public library shelves. However, removing it might not be effective as people will find other sources. As Katherine said, if we remove everything, there won't be any books left.

I firmly believe that censorship should be implemented to a certain degree in libraries. Currently, numerous children can access inappropriate materials in libraries, yet some of these materials might also have utility. For instance, I once borrowed a movie from the public library. When I watched it with my mother at home, we found it extremely inappropriate, offensive, and it made the situation quite awkward and embarrassing. We were shocked that people of any age could access a movie as inappropriate as "@CAPS1".  Although there are materials that don't belong in libraries, some materials that some people find offensive are actually in the library for educational purposes. Subjects like gay rights, abortion, and teenage sexual activity may be offensive to some, but there could be individuals who want to learn more about these topics for school projects or personal life issues. Someone might have a family member who identifies as homosexual, a daughter who has become sexually active, or a woman considering an abortion. What is offensive to one person may not be offensive to another.  In my opinion, censorship should be applied to some offensive materials. If the materials are educational, they can be beneficial to certain people. There will never be a perfect solution to this problem in the world. As the world evolves, so do human morals, and there is no content that is offensive to everyone in the world.

Have you ever been offended by a movie, book, song, or magazine? And did you have the option to choose whether to watch or read it? The question that interests many is whether offensive items should be removed from the shelves. In my view, they shouldn't.  I'm certain that if you ask anyone if they've ever been offended by a movie, book, or magazine, they can all provide an example. I doubt they would watch the offensive movie again, and if they did, it probably wasn't that bad. If something offends you, simply don't read or watch it. If you don't want your kids to watch something, just don't let them. You have the right to make that decision; no one is forcing you to engage with such content.  I admit that I've watched a few movies and read some books that perhaps weren't the best choices, but I made those choices voluntarily. No one compelled me.  Some of you might ask, "What about at school?" If a teacher assigns a book and your child is uncomfortable with it, discuss it with the teacher. Teachers are usually understanding and may provide an alternative book. They might also explain the reasons for having the class read the book and why children need exposure to such literature.  There will always be offensive books and movies. If we remove all the books in a library that have offended someone at some point, there won't be much left on the shelves. Everyone has different views on books and movies. What is offensive to you might be a great show to someone else. Therefore, I don't think offensive books, magazines, music, or movies should be removed from the shelves.

Libraries house a wide range of books, from comedies to those depicting violence. Some people enjoy reading about war and violence, while others find such content offensive. Since people have the freedom to choose what to read, there's no need for libraries to remove books that some may find offensive.  Most of the time, books in libraries are labeled according to their content. People typically go to the sections they like and pick books from there. There's no reason for them to go to sections they dislike because they won't read books from those areas and may only cause disruptions to those who enjoy such books. Whether to read a book is a personal choice, so there's no need to worry about what others are reading as long as they're satisfied. If a parent doesn't want their child to read a certain type of book, that's their decision. However, other parents may want their children to explore different materials to develop their views on various subjects.  Everyone has different views and ideas. If everyone were the same, the world would be boring and there would be nothing to talk about. Reading different books and listening to different music enriches conversations because not everyone is familiar with the same subjects. Reading new types of books can even open people's eyes to the world's diversity. Children are often more open - minded than adults. If there aren't diverse books for children to try, they'll never know what they like or dislike. A book that one child likes may not be appealing to another child or an adult, which is normal as people are different.  If everyone removed the books or music they found offensive, there would be very little left on the shelves. Styles are often opposite, like comedies and sad books. People who like comedies may not like sad books and vice - versa. If they removed the books they disliked, there would be nothing left for either group to read. Even with best - selling books, some people wonder how they became so popular, but that's just the way it is. Some people like these books, and if one person's dislike led to the removal of the book, many others might never have the chance to read it and potentially have their lives changed. Books can have a significant impact on people's lives.  In conclusion, libraries shouldn't remove books just because someone found them offensive. People have the choice to read or not, and different views and ideas make the world more interesting.

Real life contains explicit and violent elements, so there's no point in pretending otherwise. Libraries have the right to decide whether to remove books, movies, or music that they consider too graphic, violent, or aggressive. It's futile to try to censor the lives of kids and teenagers because explicit content is everywhere, not just in the media and literature. The attempt to shield this generation's children and teenagers from such content has already failed.  Currently, a large portion of movies, music, and books focus on violent, aggressive, inappropriate, or explicit themes. Removing these items from library shelves is pointless. There will always be violence, crime, and offensive language in the real world. It's understandable that some parents don't want their children exposed to such content, but in the real world, parents can't always be there to protect them.  Libraries are public places, and a certain percentage of the audience would be upset, frustrated, or angry if the books, music, or movies they liked were removed due to censorship. It might seem that exposure to violent or explicit content could have a negative impact on the listener, but children and teens are already exposed to such language on the streets, at school, and in parks. So, trying to censor their reading and viewing materials is a waste of time.  In my experience, I've grown up around people who have been exposed to violent music, graphic movies, and other explicit materials without being negatively affected. I saw my first rated @CAPS1 movie when I was nine. Parents can set an age limit to some extent, but at a certain point, censorship becomes a waste of time. With schools teaching students about the benefits of abstinence and sexual diseases, students are more likely to make the right choices regardless of what they see in movies, read, or listen to. Any child with internet access can be exposed to all kinds of inappropriate content.  In conclusion, real life is explicit, and trying to block it is an endless battle. Some content may cross the line, but others are just reflections of the real world. Movies have ratings and music has explicit content labels, so people should be able to choose what's appropriate for themselves. We shouldn't try to hide the real world from children and teenagers.

There are certain books in libraries that are inappropriate. Books about racism, violence, or pornography should not be accessible to young children.  School libraries are great resources for students to work on projects and essays or for leisure reading. If my child were in elementary or middle school, I wouldn't want them to check out books on inappropriate topics. However, for high - school teenagers, it's different. They are old enough to understand the real world. For example, if they are doing a project on the wrongs of pornography, the library is a safer place to find relevant books than the internet, which could lead them to many bad websites. As a student at my local high school, I appreciate being able to find everything I need in the school library for my projects.  Libraries also offer a lot of music, movies, and magazines. Educational music should be kept in libraries. For non - educational music like rap, pop, or country, people can get it from @CAPS1 instead of the library. Magazines can be educational; for instance, a fashion magazine can be very helpful for a project on fashion. However, magazines may also contain inappropriate content, especially since the media often focuses on sex. When I look at magazines, I skip the inappropriate parts and read about clothes, food, and people. Exposing young children to such content is not advisable, but teenagers can understand it. Movies should only be in the library if they are educational. There are plenty of @CAPS4 available, so there's no need for scary movies in the library.  In conclusion, the content in libraries should be adjusted according to the age of the users. For young children, it should be limited to educational and cartoon - related materials. For teenagers, a more relaxed approach can be taken while still maintaining an educational focus. If something offends you, talk to the librarian, and they may remove it from the shelf.

Books can be beneficial as they educate, entertain, and sometimes even serve as good pillows. However, they are not always positive. When a book is inappropriate for its readers, it should not be on library shelves. The same goes for music. If someone finds a book offensive, the library should definitely remove it. Some books may be offensive from a religious perspective. A person might hold strong religious beliefs, and a book could mock or degrade those beliefs. Some might argue that the offended person simply shouldn't read the book, but personally, I'd prefer the book be removed so I wouldn't be reminded of its offensive content every time I passed by it.  Books can also be inappropriate for young children. They may contain language that parents dislike. Some suggest creating a separate section for such books where kids can't access them, but we can't assume all parents have the same standards. What one parent considers acceptable, another might find offensive. Moreover, a book might have images that are unsuitable for children. We can't just create a section and think the problem is solved. Libraries could even consider censoring some of their books.  Some religions view certain types of music as the devil's music. I know from experience that my mother thinks scream - o music is the devil's music. She believes it's wrong for singers to perform in that way and that it wouldn't be approved. Other parents may share the same view.  Magazines can also have words or images that someone might misinterpret. While I don't think libraries should remove them, they should monitor who reads them. They could put a label on the magazine's cover indicating that it may not be suitable for everyone.  In conclusion, although books are generally good, they can be very bad. Libraries should consider censoring their books. If a book is offensive enough and receives numerous complaints, it should be completely removed from the shelves.

Just because I agree with something, does it mean you have to as well? If your cousin believes in something, does that force you to hold the same belief? In my opinion, the answer is no, and I hope you feel the same. When you come across something offensive, does it mean everyone around you will be offended too? The world is full of things that children like but parents don't, and vice versa. However, this doesn't make those things worthless or inappropriate.  Objects with so - called offensive material are ubiquitous. They are in stores, schools, indoors, and outdoors. There's no reason for them to be a problem. They won't disappear, and we shouldn't worry about them becoming a criminal offense. So, why fight against them? I say we don't.  Do you think seeing an offensive item makes an area less appealing or well - intended? What if something you like offends someone else? Does that make it wrong for you to like it? Most things in the world are liked or disliked based on personal opinions. Nothing exists without opinions; even life itself can be a matter of opinion.  I firmly believe that if something in a library is offensive to one person, it doesn't mean it's offensive to everyone. Nothing should be removed from a shelf just because someone disagrees with it. If we substitute other objects or ideas, would we remove a person from the human race just because someone is offended by them? I hope not, but some might see it as a solution. I strongly oppose this view.  Anything published is a form of self - expression and a way of life for the creator. They have the right to express themselves. We may not agree with their lifestyle, choice of clothes, but we can't judge their inner self. No characteristic defines all the others, so why should an item be removed based on one person's opinion?  What's good for you might be bad for someone else. If something you like disappears, it won't really vanish from the world. Removing a CD from a shelf won't make it non - existent. It's like cutting off your hand because your fingers look different from mine. There's no justification for removing things from stores or the world just because some people don't understand or agree with them. Anything can be deemed inappropriate, but what if your idea of appropriateness differs from others? Maybe there's no clear - cut definition of inappropriate, especially in today's world.  If we start eliminating everything we don't like, we'll end up with nothing. Removing a CD from a shelf won't make it disappear from the world, but it's an unjust act. We can't let one group's lack of understanding lead to the removal of things. We should accept the world as it is, with all its differences. Everyone has the right to express themselves, and we should respect that.

Libraries should not remove offensive materials from their shelves based on content. Writing is an art form, and censoring an author's work can obscure their message. People encounter offensive content daily on the streets and in public places, so censoring library materials won't protect anyone. Additionally, removing books from libraries can interfere with students' research and school projects.  Writing as an art form can use offensive language to convey a message. For example, in Harper Lee's *To Kill a Mockingbird*, offensive terms are used to depict the racial tension in the South at that time. If we censor such works, we miss the true context. Similarly, if a reader studying the Holocaust can't view pictures of death camps due to their graphic nature, they won't fully understand the horror of the event.  People are exposed to offensive content in their daily lives. On the streets, they may hear profanities from strangers or friends. Parents may accidentally or intentionally use profanity in front of their children. At school, children are also exposed to offensive language and behavior from their peers. Censoring library books won't protect them from this exposure.  Censorship in libraries can also hinder school and work - related projects. If a student can't access a book on a major war or event because of its graphic nature, it will be difficult for them to complete their assignment effectively. A teacher may also face problems if she can't borrow a book with mild profanity, which could prevent her from teaching the intended theme and lesson.  In conclusion, libraries should not censor books based on content. Censorship can obscure the message of a work, is ineffective as people are already exposed to offensive content in their daily lives, and can interfere with educational and research activities. If all libraries censor their materials, it will cause complications for students, workers, and readers.

Libraries are often thought of as boring places. You walk up and down the aisles, looking at books, wishing they were more interesting. After spending what seems like hours searching one shelf, you might spot an interesting - titled book. But inside, it could be full of inappropriate pictures and profanity. Who's to blame if you open and read it?  Profanity, nudity, and crude humor are widespread in the media, including books. Some parents try to protect their children by simply telling them they can't watch, listen to, or read certain things, without explaining why. If parents were more specific about why certain things are off - limits, children might be less likely to be interested in them.  Parents should not only teach their children why they shouldn't be exposed to inappropriate content but also be present when their children have the opportunity to encounter such things. If a child is too young to handle certain content, they're too young to be browsing a library without proper parental guidance.  In my opinion, censorship should be the responsibility of parents, not libraries, movie producers, television programs, or record companies. Parents know their children best and can make the most appropriate decisions regarding what their children are exposed to. By taking an active role in their children's media consumption, parents can better protect their children's well - being and development.
