Throughout history, humans have been documenting experiences, events, and ideas through various forms of art. These records often include profanity, sexuality, death, and other situations that the public may consider “offensive.” If we were to try to remove all such content, we would be destroying a significant part of history, and there are simply too many works to eliminate. Almost every form of art contains some negative elements, and removing them would leave us with very few, if any, books.  Secondly, people have different opinions on what is “offensive.” For instance, during a band trip, we played a movie that one parent found inappropriate, so we had to turn it off. However, other parents were upset because they saw nothing wrong with it. The same applies to books and music; it all depends on personal views.  Thirdly, people will encounter the things we try to hide in the real world. If we remove offensive materials from the library, people will still hear about them through the news, radio, or in daily life. For example, some want to remove the book “The [Title] of [Organization]” because it uses the word “nigger.” But replacing it with “slave” takes away the authenticity and power of the book.  In conclusion, I firmly believe that libraries should not remove “offensive” books, music, or movies. Doing so would erase part of our history and knowledge. With everyone having different views on what is offensive, it's impossible to determine which items to remove. Moreover, removing these items from libraries will not solve the problem, as people will still be exposed to such content in society.

Katherine Paterson once astutely stated that if everyone had the right to remove a book they abhor from library shelves, there would be no books left. Her view on library censorship is quite valid. Most books contain ideas and topics that may offend someone, yet I believe books with offensive content should not be censored.  What one person finds offensive may not be offensive to another. For example, a person who is pro - life may find a book about a teenage girl getting an abortion offensive. However, the author may be simply trying to convey the girl's feelings and experiences. If every person removed a book they were offended by, libraries would have to close as no books would remain. Religious books would also face censorship due to different religious beliefs. A religious text from one faith may be offensive to someone of another faith, and this could lead to endless disputes.  Censoring books would cause a rapid decline in literature. When authors write, they pour their hearts into their work. If a book is considered offensive and censored, the author is deeply offended. An author may invest their life's work in a single book, and having it removed from the shelves because a group of people dislike it is unjust. I prefer to read books with interesting and controversial topics rather than those that lack substance. If library censorship were to occur, many authors would likely give up writing, as it's extremely difficult to create a book that pleases everyone. Also, people are less likely to be attracted to books without engaging topics, leading to a decline in interest in literature.  Furthermore, censoring books would harm the quality of learning. Books are essential learning tools, and removing them would be detrimental to education. Some teenagers, including myself, may find some school - assigned reading materials offensive or controversial. However, these books have meaning, which is why teachers select them. A few offensive words will not prevent readers from understanding the book's message.  In conclusion, although a book may be offensive, it won't ruin someone's life. Removing a book or censoring music due to a few offensive words denies the creativity and passion of the author or artist. Given that what is offensive to one person may not be to another, and considering the negative impacts on literature and learning, library censorship should not be allowed.

Recently, I became aware of the growing issue of library censorship, which is extremely unfortunate. People have the right to unimpeded access to knowledge, and censoring libraries directly violates this right. Libraries are intended to be places of learning and should remain so. History is filled with both glorious and inglorious moments. We may not always be proud of our actions or what has occurred, but these events exist regardless of whether we choose to acknowledge them. Thinking that ignoring the less - savory aspects of history will make them disappear is not only unrealistic but also completely ignorant of facts. I understand that there are things children should not be exposed to, and I'm not suggesting otherwise. However, trying to shield them from what we consider "unclean" is neither right nor a good general idea. We can't protect our children forever; eventually, they will learn things we'd rather they didn't, which is inevitable. Life doesn't hide its darker side from us, and hiding it from our children will only handicap them. Children do need protection for a time, but it is the responsibility of individual parents to safeguard their own children, not at the expense of everyone else. Why should the views of some restrict the access of others? Those who presume to know what people should or should not see are out of touch. Those overly prudish individuals who believe people need to be protected from history, nature, or their own desires have no more right, and perhaps even less, to interfere with individual decision - making. People have the right to make their own choices, but they have no right to impose their opinions on others. This essay may not change the situation, but it has expressed what needed to be said and thus fulfilled its purpose. With this task completed, I can conclude with a clear conscience.

I firmly believe that offensive content, whether heard or read, should remain accessible for several reasons. Everyone should have an understanding of the world's history, which may involve aspects of racism or offensive elements. If you come across offensive content while reading a book or listening to music, simply stop. You aren't being forced to engage with it; it's your choice. Libraries should retain such materials because people should experience what it's like to be offended. I don't enjoy the feeling of being offended, but it's a part of life. There will surely be people who disagree with me, but this is just my opinion. There are libraries around the world that restrict certain people based on their views regarding the library's material selection. I once witnessed a woman at a library discussing how she reported someone who wrote offensive remarks about her religion on the internet to the police. It's not so much about what happened to the person, but the fact that she involved the police. She could have handled the situation herself by approaching the person. As soon as she started reading the offensive content, she should have stopped or left the website. It was her decision to keep reading. I don't see why she needed to involve the police over someone's opinion. Libraries should keep these materials as some people may want to understand the concept of offensiveness. Libraries shouldn't hide this topic from anyone. People can be offensive due to their upbringing or nature. Others have to deal with such people, even if they don't like it or may take action against them in their lifetime. In conclusion, libraries should keep certain materials, even if they are offensive. They shouldn't change their approach for those who dislike the materials. There are many people who want to learn more about these topics, and they shouldn't be hindered by those who don't. It's simply a part of life.

The question of whether certain materials like books, magazines, movies, etc., should be removed from library shelves if they are offensive to some is complex. However, I firmly believe that if someone dislikes or finds a particular item offensive, they should not have the right to have it removed. One reason is that what is offensive to one person may not be offensive to another. For instance, @PERSON1 might be interested in reading a book about abortion, while @CAPS1 is against and offended by this topic. If the book is removed, it restricts the access of others, like @PERSON1, who wish to learn about it. Another reason is that if one type of material is offensive to some, another will likely be offensive to others. If we start removing all offensive materials, there will be very few resources left for students to read. Even though certain materials may offend some individuals, I think they should not be removed from the library. People who dislike a particular item should not have the power to take it away. This is because other people may want to read it, and removing such materials would severely limit the available resources for learning. In conclusion, libraries should keep a diverse range of materials on their shelves, including those that may be offensive to some. Everyone has the right to access information, and we should not let the sensitivities of a few restrict the learning opportunities of many.

Dear @ORGANIZATION1, I disagree with the decision to remove materials from the library. It is not the library's fault if someone is offended by books, movies, music, or magazines. If a person doesn't like an item, it's their own choice to pick it up in the first place. Children under the age of thirteen should not have access to inappropriate movies, as they are too young to view such content. Movies can be very entertaining for children. Funny movies amuse them daily, and some children even quote movie lines to make others laugh. As a teen, I often watch funny movies to brighten my day. There are some movies that are so hilarious that I can quote every line. Music is extremely important to teenagers today. It brings me great joy. I love various types of music and find it very enjoyable. I'm not a fan of rock music, so I wouldn't borrow it from the library. Teens use music for many activities such as dancing, singing, working out, and simply enjoying themselves. Books are also important. Although I don't read often, I do like to read books that interest me. For example, I wouldn't read a scary book as it would give me nightmares. I'm more interested in fiction books. My two favorite books are A @CAPS1 To @CAPS2 and The @CAPS3 @CAPS4, both written by @PERSON1. I love all of his books, but these two stand out. Please reconsider your decision to remove so - called "bad" music, books, and movies. It's the responsibility of the borrowers, not the library. If someone doesn't like an item, they shouldn't have taken it home. Let's keep the library diverse and allow people to be happy with their choices.

There are numerous books that are inappropriate for children and teenagers, yet they can still borrow them from the library. By taking these books home and reading them, they may discover things that are not suitable for their age. Children also check out rated @NUM1 and rated @CAPS1 movies, as well as unedited @CAPS2's, and may learn inappropriate words and behaviors. Libraries are supposed to ensure that borrowers are of a certain age, like @NUM2 years old, before allowing them to borrow rated @CAPS1 movies. Similarly, there should be age restrictions for purchasing @CAPS2's and games intended for older teenagers. There should be age limits for borrowing or buying any material with vulgar language. Today's kids are not as mature as in the past, and the situation has changed significantly. In my opinion, teenagers should have age - related restrictions for renting or buying inappropriate items. However, I've also read books that weren't entirely suitable for my age. It really depends on an individual's maturity and their ability to accept vulgar content. Parents should be the ones to decide if their children are ready for such materials. In conclusion, the decision of whether a teenager can access certain materials should depend on their maturity level and readiness. Libraries and stores should set age limits for books and other items. Although not everyone will agree, there should be boundaries and age - based privileges that teenagers should respect.

Many individuals base their actions on personal views. What may seem justified to them, due to their beliefs, can cause an uproar among others. A prime example is media censorship, which occurs daily and everywhere. Some people take it upon themselves to, in their opinion, “improve a piece for public viewing.” In reality, they are ruining the media experience for others and even infringing on the rights guaranteed to us by the Constitution: Freedom of the Press.  First, consider library books. Every time I visit the library and pick up books, there is often one with “bad parts” marked out. Someone found these words offensive and decided no one should see or read them. This is irritating. I may not always like those words either, but having them marked out is distracting and ruins the author's voice and writing style, thus impairing my understanding of the book. Moreover, some marked - out words may not be offensive to others. Simply put, if you find a book offensive, don't read it. Others may enjoy it, regardless of whether they share your views.  People also freely remove entire pieces of media from shelves because they find them offensive. If everyone removed what they disliked or found offensive, there would be nothing left for anyone to enjoy. As American citizens, we have the right to make our own choices, and our choices should not be limited by the views of certain individuals. That means if I want to read or view something, it should be available to me so I can learn and expand my views, even if it makes someone else uncomfortable.  Whenever a controversial form of media is released, people often harass the producers and claim the piece should never have been made. This is wrong. Producers and authors can publish whatever they like. It's called Freedom of the Press, a right guaranteed to us as American citizens under the Constitution. Clearly, if such pieces are being produced, people are reading them. If everyone found it offensive, no one would buy or read it, and it would stop being produced. But since some people do read it, it continues to be produced. Again, if you don't like it, don't read it.  People should not take it upon themselves to censor what others can do, see, or read. If someone wants to read a story with “bad words,” so be it. Others should not ruin the experience by marking out the words. Not only is it rude and ruins the reading experience, but it also destroys someone else's property. If someone wants to view something against a certain religion, they have the right, and no one can take that right away. In my opinion, censorship in libraries, whether by the government or other civilians, should not be allowed. We citizens have the right to make our own choices, and in public libraries, the public should be allowed to read or watch whatever they want. Choice is one of the principles of the Constitution and should be protected, not limited.

Many libraries house books, movies, music, and magazines that some may consider offensive. However, these libraries have valid reasons for including such materials, whether for educational or recreational purposes. Therefore, libraries with “offensive” books should be allowed to keep them because these books are not offensive to everyone and can be beneficial to readers.  Books that offend some people may not be offensive to others. For example, Sarah, who is from the South, visits a library and finds a book about the Civil War. She reads that the South had people who mistreated their slaves and gets quite offended. Meanwhile, Tom, an African - American historian, picks up the same book. He thinks it is a great book that provides valuable insights. This example shows that the people of the United States are diverse, and with this diversity come opposing views among citizens. A library aims to appeal to all races, and in the process, it may accidentally offend some. Citizens need to be more understanding that their race is not the only one in the country. If a book offends someone, they simply shouldn't read it.  Moreover, these books that many may find offensive can also be beneficial to readers. Consider the Civil War reference again. Sarah was reading her Southern history textbook. She got offended because it described the South's actions regarding slavery and its loss in the war. On the other hand, John, who is in the same class as Sarah, was reading the same history textbook and became more and more excited. He was happy that kids across the country were learning about what happened to his ancestors and that the Union defeated the South. If this book were removed from the library, how would students across the nation learn about the Civil War?  Libraries cannot discard books just because they offend someone. As Katherine Paterson said, if everyone removed the books they disliked, there would be no books left on the shelves. Libraries should keep the books they have and acquire more. The nation needs as many books as possible because they are helpful to those who choose to read them. We must remember that not all books will appeal to us, and we should not be offended by those that don't.

In my opinion, library censorship is over - rated. We often hear that books, music, magazines, and movies are offensive or degrading, but does that mean they should be removed from public library shelves or bookstores? I say no. Future generations may be short on knowledge or become naive due to library censorship. Katherine Paterson once said, “All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.” If books are removed because they are considered offensive, there will be so many gone that children will not have as broad a view as many people have today.  Everyone has different opinions about what is offensive. Just because one person finds a book offensive doesn't mean others will. I've heard of teachers not allowing students to see pictures of the Confederate flag because they think it's offensive. But not everyone agrees. The Confederate flag is an important part of history, and categorizing it as offensive is wrong. It's not the only unpleasant part of history. If we start removing significant parts of history, they will be forgotten.  I believe libraries should not tell us what we can and cannot read. We have the right to choose what we read. If we think a book is bad, we won't read it. But that doesn't mean a book should be removed because one person finds it offensive. Someone else might want to read it. I think people are mature enough to choose what they read, and parents can make choices for their children.  With so many different opinions, it's difficult to decide what to do about censorship. I believe that if something is offensive, there could be a special section for explicit media and reading. That way, people won't be offended. Just because one person doesn't like something doesn't mean others won't.

Dear [Recipient's Title],  My name is [Your Name], and I believe everyone has the right to their own opinion. Some adults may not want their kids exposed to certain movies, books, or music. However, there are far more harmful things in the world that children encounter, such as hearing bad language, seeing fights, and witnessing people getting shot. There is more bad in life than what children listen to, watch, or read.  I think the world can be more harmful than anything else at times. Adults may want their kids to grow up differently, so they should tell them not to watch or listen to bad things on TV. But if kids want to learn about less - than - ideal things, we should let them.  It's not right for people, movies, or other things to change just because some people don't like them. Why should others have to change for those who don't approve? There are some materials that are inappropriate for minors, but they can only be purchased by those 18 and above. So, people should be okay with things that don't involve minors. Censoring things ruins a lot, as they were made a certain way for a reason and should be kept that way.  I'm sure many people may not agree with my view, but it's something to consider. People wouldn't create the things they do if they were supposed to be censored. Censorship takes away the meaning of many things. So, my answer is no to removing non - censored things. We should keep them so people can understand life in both easy and hard ways.  Sincerely, [Your Name]

As a citizen of this city and an avid library - goer, I believe that library censorship is necessary. Some of the materials in libraries today are very graphic and often quite offensive. Do we really want our children to see half - nude people or the murder of innocent people because of their skin color?  In today's libraries, there are many books and movies that depict racism. For example, the movie “[Movie Name].” In this movie, white children are yelled at for playing with African - American children. This is a clear example of why censorship is necessary. Imagine if your child watched this movie and then said something rude to an African - American friend. It would be very offensive. Although the movie is about historical events, in my opinion, it still needs to be removed from the shelves.  In today's society, nudity is becoming a major issue in movies and books. You might think it's okay to let your child watch a movie rated [Rating], but there could be nudity in it. Depending on your child's age and whether you allow them on the computer, they might think it's okay to look up nude pictures on the internet.  This is also an issue in books. The other day, I sat down to read a book about a musical I wanted to see, and it had nude pictures in it. Once I discovered this, I asked my mother to return the book. These are the kinds of things that need to be removed from library shelves.  The language used in music is also a big problem. Many rap artists think it's okay to use offensive and explicit language in their music. They don't seem to consider that young children will be listening to it. This genre of music should be removed from the shelves. You might think it's okay for your young child to listen to it now, but wait until those words end up in their vocabulary.  I think library censorship is a serious matter that needs to be carefully considered. It may seem strange at first, especially when you can't find your favorite rap tape or [Rating] movie. But in the long run, you'll thank the library for removing these materials, especially when you have children of your own. You won't want them listening to, reading, or watching the same things you did as a child.

Today, I am writing this paper to discuss the censorship of books, movies, music, and other media. In my view, there should be a restricted selection of content accessible to children. When one enters a store or a video - rental shop, children are exposed to a wide range of materials. Seeing such content may lead them to believe that inappropriate behavior is acceptable. I firmly believe that inappropriate items should not be visible to children. They should be removed from public display and stored elsewhere. Regarding music on the radio, although it is censored, people can still figure out the original lyrics. Certain words that offend some individuals are still prevalent in radio broadcasts, on television, and in books. If people were more mindful of what they produce, the situation would be different. Currently, children are being exposed to inappropriate content, such as through violent video games like “@CAPS5 of @CAPS6”. Seeing shooting and other violent acts in these games makes children think that such behavior is normal. This could potentially contribute to the high levels of violence we see today. I am writing this paper to advocate for an article in the newspaper to propose stricter rules. By implementing such rules, we can reduce the exposure of inappropriate content to the public, especially children, and hopefully decrease the prevalence of violence.

Imagine being disrespected and called derogatory names, like hearing “@CAPS1 did you say to me @CAPS2”. Would you think materials with such content should be available in libraries? I believe anything hurtful, harmful, or offensive should be accessible to the public. It offers a valuable opportunity to learn. Books, magazines, and music related to slavery are essential resources. They might cause pain, depression, or irritation to some, but they also provide valuable historical knowledge. People of all races can gain an understanding of the pain and struggles faced by those who came before us. Despite the discomfort, this kind of learning is beneficial and should be available in libraries. Knowledge about suicide should also be accessible. Some of our friends and family have either attempted or committed suicide. Without knowledge about it, prevention becomes difficult. Books on this subject can offer help to those with suicidal thoughts. Reading about past struggles and facts can provide tips on how to avoid suicide. I believe that enlightenment on this topic is the only way to prevent it. In conclusion, I am of the opinion that all types of literature should be made available to the public. All forms of literature present a great opportunity to learn. By reading about past situations and struggles, we can avoid or overcome the challenges we face in our lives.

Should certain books be allowed in libraries? If we limit the selection, people will have to read the same books repeatedly. There is a wide variety of books, including history, poetry, drama, romance, and horror. However, some books are not suitable for all places. Regarding music, some types are acceptable, while others I do not approve of. Rap, for example, consists of people rhyming about their lives. Rock - and - roll was initially disliked by many when it emerged in the late @NUM1. But as time passed, more people started listening to it. Many parents didn't want their children listening to it back then, calling it “devil music”. Today, a lot of people still enjoy it because they grew up with this kind of music. There are numerous movies available, with different ratings like @NUM2 and @CAPS1. Many parents don't let their children watch certain movies because they are scary, ugly, or gross. There are also shorter shows suitable for kids. Magazines are a relatively new form of media. Older people often read magazines because they have more free time. However, some people are really into magazines and want to buy every issue that catches their eye. There are various types of magazines, such as those about fitness, food, cleaning, and toys. In my view, these forms of media can be addictive. Some people get so caught up in them that they end up spending a lot of money. By the time they realize it, they may be broke.

If we were to remove everything that someone in the world finds offensive, there would be nothing left. Different cultures have different sensitivities, and it is unjust to take away something just because a select group of people are offended by it. Being offended is not always a negative thing, and removing something based on someone else's opinion is wrong. Firstly, the perception of what is offensive is largely influenced by culture. In most @CAPS1 cultures, declining food is considered offensive. In @CAPS2, any form of harm to cows or eating them is a disgrace. When someone finds something offensive, it may be due to their different cultural background. It is impossible to satisfy everyone. Secondly, one of the great aspects of @LOCATION1 is the freedom to hold one's own beliefs. If an item is removed from a library shelf because someone finds it offensive, it is an infringement on freedom of speech. I have my own beliefs that may offend some people, but that doesn't mean I should remain silent. Likewise, I don't want others' beliefs forced on me. Removing offensive items from public spaces means removing the right to free expression, which is not only wrong but also illegal. Some people may be offended by a book with a cross on it or a @CAPS3 cover with a pentagram. However, this doesn't mean these items should be removed. Getting offended can sometimes be a good thing as it makes people stand up for their beliefs. For example, the terrorist group @ORGANIZATION1 may be offended by the @CAPS4 flag, but we wouldn't stop flying it. In my opinion, removing offensive items from public view is wrong for multiple reasons. So many people find different things offensive, and removing all of them would eliminate everything. It would also violate freedom of speech. Moreover, offensive things can remind us of our own identities. We should have the maturity to look away instead of demanding their removal.

One day at school, all our teachers informed the class that most of the books in the library would be removed from the shelves. Our class is against this decision. The teachers said that some parents had complained about what their children were reading. I think most of the books in the library are beneficial for kids. They like to read these books and learn about things they aspire to have or do in the future. It is a positive sign that children are interested in learning about their future careers. When I have kids, I want them to have dreams about their future. If they want to spend time in school reading magazines to figure out their interests, that's fine with me. If the school removes the books from the shelves, the students may lose motivation in school. They may not know what they want to be in the future. I'm sure that if this happened to my kids, I would buy them all the magazines they need to pursue their dreams. Taking away the books will likely upset parents because it will shatter the kids' dreams. When the kids want to read, and the school removes all the good books, they won't know what they want to do later in life. A good solution would be to let the students vote on whether to remove the books. I bet most students would want to keep the books on the shelves because they enjoy reading and looking at pictures. This shows that they have aspirations for the future. There are two possible outcomes. One is that the school removes the books, and the students lose motivation and may not know what they want to become. The other is that the school keeps the books, and the students will be more eager to read and have a better idea of their future. If I had the choice, I would keep the books on the shelves to make the kids happy.

Rewrite of the first item Everyone holds a personal opinion on library censorship. In my view, libraries should not be subject to censorship regarding their shelf selections. People vary greatly in their preferences for reading, listening, viewing, and watching materials. In today's era, opinions on censorship are diverse. I oppose censorship because individuals have different tastes, thoughts, lifestyles, and learning desires.  Each person is unique. If libraries were to censor their offerings, not everyone would have access to the content they wish to consume. This would make some people feel marginalized. For instance, if a library only stocked romance materials, what would action - movie enthusiasts do? A library is a place for all its visitors, not just a specific group.  People grow up in different environments. Children don't choose their parents, and some parents censor their children's reading and viewing, while others do not. Kids with less - restrictive parents may have a wider range of interests. Not everyone likes the same things.  At school, students typically learn the basic required knowledge. Outside of school, there is a vast amount of additional information to discover. Libraries are a resource where people can explore topics that interest them. The topics people study in their free time can vary widely, from drugs and sex to other subjects. If libraries censor what people can access, not everyone will be able to learn the extra information they want.  I firmly believe that libraries should not censor the materials they make available to the public. People are different, and that is a good thing. Censorship would deprive individuals of equal opportunities. Parents have the option to censor what their children read, but since not all parents choose to do so, children develop different interests. By censoring library materials, libraries prevent everyone from having an equal chance to learn. Let people be themselves! Do not censor the books, music, movies, and magazines in libraries.

I firmly believe that removing books from library shelves, even if they are considered offensive, is unjust. I have three main reasons to support this stance: access to knowledge, the sectioning of libraries, and the principle of freedom. Before delving into these reasons, it's important to note that many who advocate for censorship often do so out of fear.  When a book is removed from a shelf due to its perceived offensiveness, it becomes inaccessible to those who wish to read it. This is clearly unfair. In life, there are numerous things that can offend people, but we must learn to accept diverse views. Everyone has the right to form their own opinions, which is only possible through exposure to different ideas. Reading enriches our vocabulary at any age. Just because one person dislikes a book doesn't mean others won't find value in it. We should allow others the opportunity to develop their own perspectives.  Libraries are ubiquitous. If parents are concerned about their children accessing inappropriate books, they can take them to libraries with well - defined sections. All libraries are divided into various sections. By keeping young children in the 'children' section, parents can avoid potential concerns. As children grow older, they can explore the library independently and discover their preferred types of books.  We live in a country that has always championed freedom. Some people cannot afford to buy books or access the internet, so they rely on public libraries. If they cannot find books that interest them, they may stop reading. They might even be searching for a specific book that has been removed from the shelves. Additionally, there is a religious aspect to consider. There are many versions of certain texts and a multitude of religions. Should we remove all books that don't align with a particular religious view?  I understand why some people advocate for censorship, but often, they are trying to avoid facing uncomfortable realities. We cannot pretend that the world is perfect. Allowing people to read whatever they choose is a positive step towards a more informed and inclusive society. We should respect the freedom of all individuals to access and engage with different ideas.

Censorship in public libraries is an affront to these institutions. Libraries, as repositories of knowledge, should not be restricted by society in terms of the information they provide. One of the primary purposes of a library, a haven for researchers, is to offer information that people need to access safely. Books are neutral vessels of knowledge and do not make judgments.  Censoring library books hinders human progress. The principles of freedom of thought and freedom of the press, which are widespread globally, oppose the idea of such censorship. If one book can be criticized or opposed, then by the same logic, all books are potentially subject to the same treatment. Valuing one opinion less than another undermines the very culture from which libraries emerged. Libraries are communal spaces that welcome all views and writings. The goal of bringing books together is to give them equal standing as literary or scholarly works.  From personal experience, library censorship has cost me valuable time and deprived me of parts of my life. Growing up in a small town with rigid views on gender and sexuality, I struggled to find dissenting opinions in the school library. As a child seeking answers about my sexuality, I found only heteronormative love stories. It was only after leaving school that I discovered that books on alternative perspectives were in the library but were restricted. The most offensive part was not just the lack of representation but the separate treatment of these books.  The root of the problem is that some people believe that ignoring minority opinions or values will make them disappear. This is the essence of censorship: pushing an issue or a lifestyle choice to the point of extinction. However, books do not force their values on us. We must actively choose to read them and engage with their knowledge. Unlike advertisements that may surprise us, we have to pick up a book to access its content.  If my library had provided the guidance I needed, my personal growth would have been much smoother. I would have learned to accept myself and others more easily.  In recent years, as the effects of certain global events have reached the younger generation, our country has tried to honor the victims of violence and oppression. However, it has struggled to create effective memorials because there is a lack of material to draw from. The consequences of violence and book - burning have left a void. Architects have created 'anti - monuments' to represent this loss, such as a wall with gaps in the shape of book spines. This symbolizes the knowledge that has been lost. We must ask ourselves what valuable perspectives, prose, and beauty have been taken from us without our ever having the chance to experience them.  Library censorship is equivalent to burning books. Once a book is removed from the shelf, it is likely to be forgotten. To safeguard the future and educate our descendants, we must preserve all books, regardless of whether they are considered offensive, disgusting, brave, or new. Let readers determine the value of a book. Give books a chance to have an impact. Leave libraries as they are, as monuments to the preservation and advancement of knowledge and wisdom.

Have you ever thought about how libraries select their books? I certainly have. There is some material out there that is not suitable for young children. I firmly believe that libraries should practice censorship. There are three main reasons for this: protecting children from books about violence, safeguarding the social lives of everyone, and addressing the issue of inappropriate music.  Let's start with the impact on children. Look around and you'll likely see children in libraries. They might be reading books that are too explicit for their age. For example, a six - year - old child with no restrictions could check out a book about violence and sex from the library. What can parents do when their child brings such a book home? In many cases, they do nothing. It's time for librarians to take a stand and censor these harmful books. If libraries don't censor, any child could be exposed to inappropriate content.  Children aren't the only ones affected by uncensored library books. Think about the conversations at school and work. Most of them revolve around sex and violence. These conversations often stem from the uncensored books available at the library. People of all ages, from toddlers to the elderly, can borrow books. When I was a child, my parents encouraged me to go to the library to learn. But if the library had no censorship, what would I have been reading? Our social lives are significantly influenced by what we learn and how we learn it.  Another issue is the music available at libraries. Every time I turn on the radio, I often hear songs that are inappropriate. I sometimes listen to radio station @NUM1, and most of the music is about violence. Libraries also have some of the CDs of these artists. The combination of uncensored books, music, and movies in libraries can create a negative social environment. Censoring music is a good step, as it would reduce the obsession with violence in our society.  We shouldn't have to tolerate the presence of uncensored books in libraries. Librarians and concerned individuals should fight for censorship. A library is a place for peaceful learning, not a source of violence. By implementing censorship, we can create a safer environment for everyone. No one should be exposed to the harmful effects of uncensored books and music.

When a woman screamed '@CAPS1' after being stabbed in the back by her abusive husband, it highlighted the kind of violence that children are exposed to around the world. The inappropriate content children encounter on television, the internet, and through their classmates is already concerning. This is why books and magazines in libraries worldwide need to be censored.  In our local library in @LOCATION1, @LOCATION2, the magazines are extremely graphic. Kids are more likely to read these magazines than educational or interesting books. They draw disrespectful images in them, rip them in half, and engage in other destructive behaviors. This lack of respect for library materials may stem from the idea that they can do whatever they want. Many of the books kids read contain content that doesn't teach them anything valuable, such as stories about a zombie apocalypse. Having such books in a school library doesn't offer any educational value. Instead, it may encourage kids to take the books home and expose their siblings to inappropriate language. These are all valid reasons to censor or remove some of the leisure - reading books in libraries or to censor offensive language.  Another important point is the financial loss that schools face due to damaged books and stolen property. Kids draw inappropriate pictures in magazines and books, causing schools to spend a significant amount of money on repairs and replacements. If schools restricted the removal of these books from the library, they could save money and use it for more educational purposes.  If libraries around the world censor books and magazines, we can expect to see better - behaved children. By not allowing kids to take books out of the library, we can prevent them from damaging, stealing, or defacing the materials. This shows authority and teaches kids to respect library resources. The money saved by libraries and schools can be used for more educational initiatives. I hope you will consider the points I've made and take action to implement censorship in libraries.

I firmly believe that libraries should implement a degree of censorship. There exist books that may be offensive and cause issues. However, even if a book is insulting, it shouldn't be hidden from others. Libraries house some books with rather objectionable content. As libraries are public spaces, many people visit to borrow books. What's to prevent a child from accessing such books or movies available in libraries? Do we really want a child to check out materials containing violence, foul language, and sexual innuendo? One solution could be to censor these books and keep them from the public, but this would create another problem. The concept of censorship may seem reasonable at first glance, but it's not the right approach. Hiding materials from the public simply because they contain some undesirable elements is excessive. If an adult wishes to read a book with a bit of violence, they'd have to look elsewhere as the book might have been removed due to swear - words deemed inappropriate. Censorship would make it more difficult for adults to find the books they want to read. So, what should be done when there's an offensive book on the shelf? Should it be left there or removed? A better solution is to impose age restrictions on books. If an underage person wants to borrow an offensive book, they should obtain permission from their parent. This way, the book can remain on the shelf and be accessible to those who are allowed to read it.

People have diverse perspectives when it comes to judging things. That's why I believe libraries should retain books that some might find offensive. What one person deems offensive may not be so for another. If people claim certain books are offensive, they can choose not to read them, but a single person's opinion shouldn't lead to a book's removal from the library. What is offensive to one individual could pique the interest of another. The person who doesn't find a book offensive should have the right to read it. Removing a book because one person objects to it is a violation of others' rights. Some people might find a book useful as they want to learn more about the topic. If the book is removed due to one person's objection, they'll lose the opportunity to gain knowledge. Personally, I enjoy thrilling movies and books with some violence. If a library removes such books or movies because a parent saw their child engaging with them, it's unjust. The parent would be depriving me of my preferred reading and viewing materials, which is completely unfair. A viable solution is to allocate specific areas in the library for different age groups. This way, people can access materials appropriate for their age. In conclusion, due to the wide range of opinions, we should respect everyone's right to access the books they want. Age - appropriate areas in libraries can effectively balance the needs of different age groups and ensure fairness.

Over the years, libraries have served as a valuable resource for research, movie rentals, and discovering new reading materials. They open the door to a vast world of learning and reading. All libraries should have the freedom to stock the content they choose. No book, music, movie, or magazine should be excluded from the shelves based on its content. There are numerous books on topics such as sex and drugs that many people may find offensive or simply ignore. Each person's interests in reading, watching, or listening are unique. When someone wants to purchase a book on safe sex, the library shouldn't deny them access. Instead, it should be placed in a separate section. What some consider explicit content may not be so for others. When I was in middle school, I was curious about sex and drugs. I knew I could find relevant information in the local library. If a child wants to learn more, they'll look for information. If I had been denied access to books on these topics, I might never have been aware of their consequences. In a library, not everyone is reading light - hearted books. Many people read books about real - life situations that they can relate to. These books may be considered explicit by some. The purpose of a library is to provide access to materials of all kinds, regardless of others' concerns. Libraries can organize their collections by topic and genre. Explicit materials or those for adults can be placed in a back room or on a separate side of the library, out of reach of children. In conclusion, books, magazines, music, and movies should not be removed if they are found offensive. Every item has the right to be on the shelf, and people should have the freedom to access them according to their needs.

Censorship is a highly debated topic. If one person dislikes the content of a text, they may claim the right to prevent others from accessing it in a public library, online source, or other public location. But what about the opinions of others? Shouldn't they also have a say? Suppose 'person one' disagrees with the language in a text, while 'person two' likes it. In this situation, which person's rights should be prioritized? Freedom of speech and expression are highly valued in our society, though sometimes overlooked. In this case, both 'person one' and 'person two' have the right to express their thoughts about the text. Should 'person one' have the right to demand the removal of the text from a public location? If everyone had the power to remove materials they disagreed with from the public domain, there would be nothing left. In a large and diverse society, there will always be someone who disagrees with the content of every lyric, magazine, book, and text available. Some may argue that it's unfair to the group that disagrees with a material. However, it's equally unfair to the group that supports it. The group that disagrees still has the right to voice their opinions, just like those who agree. Take iTunes as an example. If a song contains offensive language or content, it is marked with a red 'explicit' tag. This alerts those who may be offended by foul language. Additionally, there is often a 'clean' version of the song, which has the offensive content removed or replaced. This way, both parties can be satisfied. Movies are another example. They are rated based on their content, with a higher rating indicating more explicit material. The rating is accompanied by an explanation of why the movie received that rating. This allows viewers to make informed decisions. In conclusion, a material should not be removed from the public just because some people disagree with its content. Both parties should be able to express their opinions, and solutions like tagging and rating can help achieve a balance.

Have you ever borrowed a book that you found offensive or thought should be censored? I once checked out a book with a lot of racism and sex - related content. Some books, movies, magazines, and other materials in libraries may not be suitable for all viewers, and we should consider restricting access to them. Libraries contain books with significant amounts of racism. In some cases, the racism in these books can be so severe that it may influence young readers and lead them down a wrong path in the future. A young racist might persuade their friends to adopt the same views. No parent wants their child to be racist, although there are racist families, which I find hard to understand as I believe we are all equal. Some library books also contain detailed sex - related discussions. This is inappropriate for young viewers as it may give them ideas that are not suitable for their age. Young children should not be exposed to such content until they are older. Many parents, including me, would not want their children to read books like this. Music is popular among people of all tastes, whether it's rap, country, or the blues. Some people think rap music is offensive and should be removed from the shelves. Rap music often reflects the artists' past and lives, and it may contain some racism and inappropriate language, which is not suitable for young listeners. Although there are materials with offensive content on library shelves, I think they should be placed in a separate room so that only adults can access them. At the same time, I believe books with racism can be kept as they show how much society has changed over time. By implementing these measures, we can protect young viewers while still preserving the value of these materials.

New restricted sections in the library. Have you ever come across a movie or book that you didn't want your kids or family to engage with? I have, and sometimes it's impossible to stop them from accessing such content. I don't believe offensive books should be removed, but I think they should be moved to a different part of the library. This restricted area of the library should only be accessible to adults or with an adult's permission.  Kids often mimic their peers, not realizing that much of what they see in movies is fake. By having this separate section in the library, parents can keep racist, drug - gang - filled, and murder - themed books away from children. This is beneficial for all races. For instance, an African - American family can prevent their child from accessing books about slavery or gangs. Some books can be highly emotional and trigger strong feelings. Someone going through a tough time might be more likely to think about suicide after reading a related book.  I'm convinced that separating bad - influencing books from good - influencing ones will be very helpful. People under the age of 18 are not allowed in this restricted area without a parent or a parent's signature. So, come to the library council on [DATE1] and vote for the new restricted section of the library! Thank you for your time.

When I was a little girl, I went to the library one day. I was eager to find a book to read. I made my way to what I called the “big kids side” and tried to check out a book. The library lady gently told me I was too young and showed me the books appropriate for my age level, taking the book I wanted back. That experience made me realize how libraries do a great job of keeping books at appropriate age levels.  Censorship in libraries is like cutting off the world's air supply. It takes away from a reader's imagination and stops them from expressing their minds. In my view, censorship in libraries is unnecessary. Libraries worldwide are already good at categorizing books according to age. If certain materials are removed, readers will wonder why, demand that their books be left alone, and may even fight for more books like those, which could then lead to the need for censorship.  Books are meant to make people wonder, learn, and get excited. Cutting out different materials stops people from enjoying the world of ideas. The more books are taken away, the more people turn to television. Eventually, there would be fewer authors and more actors and actresses, and people's minds would no longer be engaged in wonder, learning, or excitement.  So, in conclusion, censorship is not needed in libraries. It would undermine a librarian's job and take away from readers' imaginations.

The issue of censorship in media and literature involves a certain level of responsibility, and determining who should bear this responsibility is a complex task. Children are highly susceptible to the influence of various media, and much of this material is readily accessible. Once individuals reach the age of making life - affecting decisions, they should have the freedom to choose what they read, watch, and consume. Shop owners, within the boundaries of the law, should be able to sell whatever products they deem fit to earn a living.  In a library setting, children usually do not visit alone. Parents have the authority to decide whether their children can borrow certain books, movies, or magazines. When a child presents an offensive or inappropriate item, it is the parent's decision to allow or restrict access. If a parent permits a child to access offensive media, the child may perceive such content as acceptable.  Adults who have reached the legal age and enjoy other freedoms should be allowed to purchase, read, and watch what they desire. To access offensive material, they should be required to present valid identification as proof of age.  A shop owner or businessperson should have the right to sell legal products without being unjustly restricted by non - legal authorities or non - guardians. Only law enforcement officers or legal guardians of minors should have the power to restrict an individual's access to non - illegal material.  In conclusion, only law enforcement or legal guardians of minors should be able to restrict the purchase or rental of certain media. There is no valid reason to prevent people from accessing non - illegal material. If someone is offended by certain literature, they should attempt to have it regulated through legal means.

Censorship is a highly debated topic in today's society. People around the world have vastly different views on it. In some countries, dictators restrict citizens' access to the internet, news, and even television. They do this because they don't want their citizens to know what's happening globally. This creates a “fish bowl” environment where outsiders can see the country's problems, but the people inside are oblivious.  Although we don't always encounter such extreme forms of censorship, it still plays a significant role in modern society. Everything from radio music to military files is subject to censorship. Think about how often you can listen to a radio song with all its original lyrics intact. Debates about censorship have raged on for years without much progress. Each side of the argument, whether for or against censorship, is mostly based on opinion. It's impossible to say for sure whether censorship is completely necessary or not. It's just too difficult to determine which opinion is more convincing.  In my opinion, nothing should be censored. When a writer of a TV show uses a vulgar word, it's often to evoke an emotional response. The same goes for songs; artists use certain words to convey their message more effectively. Parents argue that their children are exposed to too much violence on TV, causing behavior problems. However, instead of censoring everything, parents can simply prevent their children from watching inappropriate shows.  In [LOCATION1], we have the right to freedom, which we exercise daily in our clothing choices and speech. We should apply this freedom to the issue of censorship. Instead of complaining about violence in movies or sex on TV, we can choose not to watch such shows. Everyone has the option to say no. It's a simple solution; we just need to exercise our right to choose and say no to what we don't want to see or hear. This could potentially end the long - standing debates about censorship.

Dear [CAPS1] [PERSON1], the question of whether certain books should be removed because some people believe they are inappropriate for their children is a complex one. In my view, these books should not be removed but rather placed in different sections of the library according to age.  All children's books and magazines should be grouped in one section. Young adult and teen books and magazines should have their own section, as should adult books and magazines. Autobiographies and documentaries should also be in their own dedicated section. This categorization would make it easier for readers to find the books they want. For example, a teenage girl looking for a book about a high - school girl with a crush on a boy would most likely find it in the young adult section.  Parents who are concerned about their children's exposure to certain books should be able to voice their opinions. However, consider a situation where a teenager needs to find a famous person's autobiography for a school project, even though it includes details about the person's past drug use. That student should not fail just because a concerned parent deemed the book inappropriate and it was removed from the library.  In conclusion, the best approach is to categorize all books by age. This would simplify the process of finding books and ensure that all readers, regardless of age, have access to the materials they need.

In contemporary society, inappropriate materials appear to be ubiquitous. They can be found in magazines, books, and music lyrics, with countless opportunities for offensive references to sneak in, and they seem to pop up everywhere these days. However, should one's access to such materials be restricted based on others' morals or values? I firmly oppose this, and here's why.  Everyone has distinct morals, values, and a sense of right and wrong. Perhaps one's religion or culture leads them to avoid certain materials. But why should one's values and beliefs determine what another person can access from the library? I'm certain I'm not alone in saying that I'd be extremely annoyed if I couldn't obtain the books or materials I wanted or needed simply because someone else disagreed with the content discovered through research.  I do believe that certain materials should be segregated in libraries. For instance, books offensive to children should be kept away from the children's selection area. This is entirely reasonable. Nevertheless, when materials are removed because some people find them offensive or disagree with them, it goes too far. This nation was founded on the principle of freedom of belief. So, why should we force others to adopt our beliefs? Just because I find something offensive doesn't mean others will, and that's perfectly acceptable to me. It's their personal opinion, and my beliefs shouldn't prevent them from learning about what they're interested in.  One solution to this problem is to separate potentially offensive materials into a different section of the library and post a sign or notice indicating the content of that section.  In conclusion, I do not believe libraries should be censored. I know I might encounter offensive materials in my local library, but I wouldn't want my personal opinion to influence others' access to that material. People should consider others' perspectives occasionally and not be overly fixated on their own beliefs. The world is full of diverse opinions, and without them, we'd have nothing. Libraries are filled with valuable resources, so the focus should be on what can be gained from them rather than on what one doesn't want to see. If something is offensive, simply avoid it, but don't try to remove it from everyone else.

I think libraries should have censorship because young kids might come across inappropriate materials. Censorship would ensure that kids don't view such content. There are three main reasons for library censorship. First, inappropriate materials can teach kids bad things. Second, they can have a negative influence. Third, there's no real need for kids to be exposed to them.  Regarding the first point, inappropriate materials can teach kids bad things. If kids start looking at such content, they're more likely to get into trouble. There's absolutely no valid reason for them to be exposed to it.  Secondly, these materials can have a bad influence. Kids might show and tell their friends about it, leading them to engage in inappropriate behavior and potentially have a negative future.  Thirdly, there's no real need for kids to look at such materials. Unless, by some rare chance, a book with inappropriate content falls off a bookshelf and lies on the floor, there's no reason for kids to encounter it.  I believe that implementing censorship in libraries would protect kids from harm, allowing everyone to lead a proper life. In conclusion, library censorship is necessary to safeguard the well - being of young children.

I firmly believe that library censorship is unnecessary. The justifications for censorship are highly subjective and biased. Two readers can have completely different interpretations of the same book.  When a reader chooses a book, they are likely aware of the general plot from the back - cover summary before even starting to read. People are capable of making their own decisions about whether to read a book. The books considered inappropriate or offensive are usually found in teen novels or adult literature. In such cases, the readers should be mature enough to handle encountering such content and decide whether to continue reading or put the book back.  It's true that some material may be unsuitable for younger age groups. However, at that age, children should be accompanied by an adult when checking out books. The unacceptable material is almost always in novels intended for a mature audience. If a younger child is reading such a book, that in itself is the problem. Teens and adults reading such materials are surely old enough to handle a few foul words and innuendos in the plot.  The perception of inappropriate or offensive material varies between different audiences. A high - school teen has probably heard worse in the school halls, and an adult worried about their children's reading material has likely been exposed to enough in their lifetime to either overlook it or put the book away. It's not right to label material as offensive based on just one person's view.  Tough situations and our surroundings prepare us for the future. Should we ignore the unpleasant aspects of life? Should a child being beaten at home suffer in silence because the story is too graphic? Should the story of a homeless man who turned his life around not be told because his past troubles are disturbing?  I believe these are the stories that need to be told the most. They teach us how to prevent and overcome life's difficulties. There will always be things we don't want to see in life, but it's our actions after encountering such misfortunes that define us. Libraries should not be censored but should be open to the public who want to explore these stories. Books are written for a purpose, which may be to inform people that these things are happening and to show that they're not alone in their struggles. In conclusion, libraries should remain uncensored to allow people to access these valuable stories.

I think that certain books indeed don't belong on library shelves. Some people may feel the urge to remove books of their choosing, but if the library deems it appropriate to include such books, that's their decision. I believe that if one doesn't like a book, they should simply stay away from it.  If a book is intended only for adult readers, then by all means, it should be removed from general access. I know some parents who won't let their children read a book just because the main characters kiss, as mentioned in the book review. I find this rather ridiculous, but it's their parenting style. As long as they don't try to impose their parenting methods on libraries and other learning institutions because of the books, I'm fine with it.  Some people find books about slavery, the Holocaust, and similar topics offensive. I see these books as part of our history. These topics are taught in schools, and we're likely to learn about them as we grow up. What's the difference between learning about them as children and as adults?  People seem to want to shield the world from swear words. If a book has a few curse words, so what? If parents think it's bad, they should tell their kids to avoid it, but they shouldn't remove the book from the library. People have always had and will always have different views. If a parent strongly opposes certain books, they can take a position, gather signatures to have the books removed or moved to a different section of the library. They shouldn't force their opinions on others.  In conclusion, while there may be a need to manage certain books in libraries, we should respect different views and avoid imposing personal opinions on others. Libraries should strive to balance the diverse needs and views of their patrons.

I'm writing to discuss the issue of offensive materials in libraries. Many adults find certain books inappropriate for kids, and I believe libraries need to take action.  First, there are many books in libraries that are offensive to kids. These materials are often in the adult - reading sections, yet libraries allow kids to access them without proper identification. These books can teach kids bad things and mess with their young minds. Libraries should provide more age - appropriate materials, like educational books for school.  Second, parents should protest to get rid of offensive materials. They can either have offensive books removed from the shelves or make a list of such books and restrict access to adults with proper identification. This way, the valuable books won't be completely removed.  Third, libraries should carefully consider what kids are taking home to read. Adults should monitor their kids' reading choices. Kids need to understand which books are suitable for their age; otherwise, it can cause confusion in their developing minds.  In conclusion, libraries must come up with a solution to prevent children from reading offensive books. These books can have a negative impact on kids' mental health, and parents may even have to pay for therapy to help their children. Libraries should act to relieve parents' concerns about what their kids are reading. For me, I don't want my child to read offensive materials as it may lead them to imitate such behavior. So, I urge libraries to address this issue of offensive content.

In my view, censorship has no place in libraries. People are intelligent enough to decide what they want to read. There are several reasons why censorship should not be permitted in libraries or in public. First, censorship shows disobedience. Second, many individuals may over - use their authority, which will lead to a negative reputation for the library. Third, it will alter the entire atmosphere of a library.  Censorship in libraries is a form of disobedience. I believe that some people may use profanity and adopt a non - caring attitude. If people use inappropriate language at home, they should keep it there and not bring it into public. In my opinion, censorship should never be allowed in libraries or anywhere else.  When people over - use their authority in libraries, such as being loud and preventing others from reading, it drives people away. A library should be a quiet and welcoming place, which will make the reading experience more pleasant.  Ultimately, I firmly believe that censorship should never be allowed in libraries or other public places. A library is a place for reading, studying, and completing homework. People should be able to make their own decisions about reading materials related to censorship, as long as they can handle it.

I firmly believe that certain materials, like those inappropriate for young children, should be removed from the general library area. These materials should be placed in a separate room where access requires an ID. This is crucial because we don't want young children, like my own son, to stumble upon inappropriate content such as Playboy magazines.  Little kids shouldn't read books with excessive swearing. Such content can have a negative impact on them, getting them in trouble at school and at home.  It's true that adults may be interested in reading about sex and drugs, but we need to consider whether we want our children exposed to the same material. People who manage libraries should be more mindful of what they leave accessible, as kids are always eager to explore new things.  So, whether you're working at a library or just visiting, you should be careful about where you place materials. Otherwise, children will likely come across them. In conclusion, libraries need to take proactive steps to protect young readers from inappropriate content.

Inevitably, everyone encounters offensive content at some point. The government has attempted to shield youth from such material, believing that parents should be the ones to inform children. However, if children are introduced to these topics at an early age, there's no need to keep them a secret. Libraries and all forms of media should not be subject to censorship.  Kids often ask questions like "where do babies come from?" Adults, to avoid awkward conversations, may fabricate stories or withhold the full truth. Imagine a world where the government allows the media to be unrestricted. Initially, it might seem vulgar, but then the government could properly teach about sex and drugs in schools. More children would be educated, reducing their curiosity and the likelihood of engaging in such behaviors.  This doesn't mean that newscasters should curse on television. It simply suggests that the media should report the whole truth instead of hiding half of it. They have the right to freedom of speech, and we have the right to know.  At first, people might think this would create a terrible world. But with proper leadership, it would foster a more truthful environment. Children would learn about sex and drugs in a safe school setting, and drug use and rape rates could decline. Eventually, "offensive" topics would no longer be a source of embarrassment for kids. This change would make the world a better place.

The library is a haven of dreams and imagination. For many, it offers an escape from reality into a world where anything is possible. It houses a vast collection of books for all age groups. However, books suitable for one age group may not be appropriate for another, which leads to problems.  Young children are frequent visitors to the library. They often wander around and access various books and magazines. There are many adult - only magazines in libraries. For example, one evening, my mother, brother, and I visited the library. While my mother and I were searching for books, my younger brother browsed the magazine rack. He found a Sports Illustrated magazine with pictures that my mother was not happy for him to see. Library staff should place such revealing materials out of reach of young children.  There are also many books in the library about historical events. While some people find them interesting, others may find them offensive. Certain races have endured painful historical experiences, and they don't want to relive those traumas. The library should consider how different people feel about certain books. When I was in elementary school, I did a unit on slavery and the underground railroad. I went to the library to find research materials and came across a book with horrible acts against black people that I shouldn't have seen at that age.  Personally, I love reading as it helps me escape the real world. But I've encountered books that were inappropriate for me. For instance, I found a book in the young - adult section that described a young girl experiencing rapes and beatings. Although I might appreciate it now, I shouldn't have read it then.  The debate over which books should be in the library is endless. Many think inappropriate books should be removed. In my opinion, if these books are placed where younger audiences can't access them, this ongoing feud could be resolved.

I do not believe that offensive materials should be removed from library shelves. This is just my opinion, but I think it's a pointless task.  Children will encounter offensive material outside of school, such as racism, murders, and inappropriate language in music, movies, magazines, and books. When we come across offensive content outside of school, we usually avoid it and choose something more suitable.  Some movies and books about certain topics may be offensive to some people. But if we remove them from libraries, it will be difficult to find accurate references for essays. The internet may not provide completely correct information, while factual books in the library are reliable.  In conclusion, removing offensive materials from library shelves is a futile effort. Since children can avoid such content outside of school, they can do the same in school. Libraries should keep these materials available for those who need them.

In my view, offensive materials in libraries, including books, movies, music, and magazines, should not be removed from the shelves. What one person finds offensive may not be offensive to another; it's all a matter of personal opinion. If you come across something offensive, simply don't pick it up. Admittedly, some content can be highly offensive to certain individuals, and they may try to have it removed. However, this is a misguided approach. What might be offensive to you could be crucial for someone studying a particular topic. Removing such materials would disrupt their research. I'm not advocating for violent or offensive materials. I'm just suggesting that if you find something offensive, ignore it. What offends you may not bother others at all. There are numerous books and movies that many people find offensive. If we were to remove all of them, there would be very few subjects and titles left for people to read and watch. In conclusion, I firmly support keeping offensive materials on the shelves. They can be beneficial to many, even though they may offend others. If you're offended by something, just look for another subject or topic. Denying someone the right to read a book or watch a movie is wrong; everyone has their own opinions and rights.

There are certain books that should not be removed from libraries due to censorship. From my past experiences with censorship, I've learned that it can have a detrimental impact on literature. For example, in the book @CAPS1 @NUM1, the burning of books leads to the breakdown of society. Censorship often stems from people with a more ethnic background who don't want children to be exposed to inappropriate language. The most recent book I've heard of being censored is @CAPS2 @CAPS3. The main word being removed from this book is "nigar" because some people find it extremely offensive to their race. Committees are trying to remove the book from school shelves. I believe we should not have censorship. Just because parents don't want their kids to hear certain words in school or read them, it doesn't mean these materials should be removed. Eventually, kids will learn these words on their own, whether from their parents or on TV. Personally, I think committees should stop trying to censor everything because they can't control how adults talk around children and young adults. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is an over - reaching measure that can have negative consequences. We should respect the diversity of literature and allow individuals to make their own choices about what to read.

I wholeheartedly agree with the idea presented by well - known author Katherine Paterson. She says, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf—that work I abhor—then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf left for any of us.' If everyone has the power to remove books they find inappropriate, there will soon be nothing left to read. While it's good for parents to voice their opinions and stand up for what they believe in, books should not be banned. People have diverse views on what is right and wrong. Some may think a certain book is obscene, while others may be offended by a different one. If every parent could get a book banned, there would come a time when no book meets their approval. Many of these potentially controversial books offer great learning opportunities for students. They encourage students to think in new and different ways, allowing them to learn from alternative perspectives. Students can also reflect on their own morals and values through these books, which is a positive thing. When a teacher selects a book they deem appropriate, parents should respect that decision. They can suggest other readings or offer ideas, but getting the book completely removed is unjust. On the other hand, the situation with movies can be different. My parents would be appalled to see grotesque and inappropriate movies on display for everyone to see. The difference between books and movies is straightforward: books usually don't have inappropriate covers, while bad movies often do. This means that even those who don't want to watch the movie are forced to see disturbing images. When walking past a book one doesn't intend to read, there's no need to be appalled by its cover. In conclusion, although parents are concerned about what their children read, books should not be banned.
