Library owners should stock as many books as possible and not exclude a book simply because they don't agree with its content. By maintaining an uncensored library, we ensure that everyone has equal access to knowledge and the opportunity to explore different ideas.

I remain neutral on this matter. Whether new books, movies, music CDs, or magazines are added to or removed from the library's shelves is of no consequence to me. Additionally, it makes no difference if I have to pay for the items I borrow from the library or if I incur a late fee for overdue books. I am also indifferent to the noises in the library, the types of books it holds, how it is managed, the requirement to be quiet, the duration of my stay, the mode of transportation I use to get there, the library's policies, or if I am expelled and have to go to another library. Finally, it does not matter to me if I borrow ten books or movies from the library. Thoma.

I firmly believe that books should not be removed. People know what they are reading, and if they do not like a book, they can simply put it aside. There is no valid reason for anyone to remove a book because many people have diverse preferences in reading material. If books are removed, it will upset a large number of people who may have loved a particular book and wanted others to read it. Some books may have been in a family for generations, and family members wish to share the enjoyment of those books. Moreover, removing a book is not a good idea because new books need to be purchased, which incurs costs and wastes paper. Another drawback is that if a new book replaces an old one, readers may not like the new book, causing the bookstore to lose money. In conclusion, removing books is not a prudent decision as it will result in financial losses for the bookstore and deny readers access to good books.

Censorship in libraries is a significant issue in contemporary society. Many individuals become irate at libraries and markets due to the items on display for the general public. Suppose a consumer enters a library in search of a book and comes across one from the early @DATE1's. During that era, certain words were used that are now considered "harmful." However, most people fail to understand that these words had different meanings in that historical context. When someone encounters such "harmful" or inappropriate words in a book, they often form a wrong impression. A small group of people who dislike a particular piece of literature then oppose the majority who understand the literary work, its emotions, and dialect. I will now explain to this small group some important points to consider before removing a book from the shelf.  When people visit a store or library and encounter a piece of literature they do not fully agree with, they should simply put it back and move on. No one is forcing them to read the book, so there is no need to make a fuss. The main reason some people object to certain word usage is that they do not understand the book's dialect or the time period in which it was written. If they do not fully comprehend the literature, they should not create a scene or attempt to revoke the author's right to have the work published and available on the shelf.  Authors have the same rights as everyone else. When they write a poem, novel, or short story, they have the right to have it published and placed on the shelf. Similarly, if we disagree with some of the literature in our schools, stores, and homes, we can express our views through writing a novel, newspaper article, or creating a website. We can also use web polls and other methods to gather opinions. This is a more indirect way to address the issue of removing a piece of literature. By using polls and obtaining multiple opinions, we increase our chances of winning an argument to have a book removed from the shelves, while causing less chaos and drawing less attention to ourselves and others.  Another reason against allowing people to choose what is on library shelves is that researchers are constantly working on various theories and laws. If we remove an important book, such as one written in the @DATE2's about evolution, we may miss out on crucial information when we need it in the future. Scientists may require that piece of literature to test a theory, and its removal could deprive us of valuable knowledge. Therefore, the more information we remove from the shelves, the less we will have to solve our problems in the future.  In conclusion, I hope that after sharing my opinions on this topic, you will have a better understanding of library censorship. Ideally, all books and literary works should remain on the shelves for readers to enjoy.

Curse words, alcohol, drugs, and pornographic pictures are things that we do not want our children to engage with. These exist in the real world, but just because someone witnesses others doing these things does not mean they will follow suit. People should not be shielded from the realities of life. If children are shielded, they may not know how to respond when faced with the opportunity to do drugs or drink. They may even be unsure of what is right or wrong. Children of a certain age need to be aware of what awaits them in the real world as they grow up and start their own lives. While not everyone will encounter these situations, it is essential for them to have this knowledge.  Parents play a crucial role in teaching their children the difference between right and wrong. Adolescents are particularly vulnerable to the negative aspects of life. Exposure to such content in books, movies, and magazines can have an impact on their lives. It is the parents' responsibility to guide them on the right path.  One way parents can help is through restrictions on certain materials. Movies have age restrictions, which limit access to those within a specific age range. However, for other materials like books, music, and magazines, there is no easy way to deny access. Parents need to be vigilant and monitor their children's activities.  Censorship can be a double - edged sword. It can be beneficial for those who are more vulnerable to negative influences, as it shows them that certain behaviors are wrong. However, people should also have the right to access information. While it is an ongoing debate, in my opinion, censorship should not be implemented. Everyone has the right to access and view the things they desire.

Libraries and bookstores around the world stock books with a wide range of subject matter, from the odd or inappropriate to the serious or violent. These books are written to evoke various emotions in readers, such as excitement, humor, horror, and empathy. However, it is sometimes unclear whether a book is suitable for young or mature readers. Although some books may seem unappealing or offensive, it is unjust to censor them without the unanimous disapproval of everyone. There should be no censorship of novels and literary works because writers deserve the freedoms of speech and press, new ideas are worth exploring, and target audiences deserve books that interest them regardless of others' approval.  Firstly, writers have the right to the freedoms of speech and press. They can express their opinions and write about the topics they are passionate about. Even when they use highly provocative or inappropriate subject matter, they have the legal right to do so. Preventing them from writing their opinionated stories is similar to the book - burning and writer - execution practices in Nazi @LOCATION1. Despite the fact that some books are not suitable for all ages, they still have potential readers.  Secondly, books and stories are meant to break new ground and explore uncharted topics. The variety of literature is what makes it so popular. For thousands of years, written text has been a means to understand and connect with different cultures and people. Just because a story may not be appropriate for a child does not mean it should not be written or read. Instead, its use should be monitored to ensure that only those who can understand and accept its message have access.  Finally, censorship is unjust because it limits the ability to discuss and present stories that appeal to a wide range of people. What may be horrific to a parent could be a preferred form of literature for another group. Limiting literary subjects is similar to limiting people's freedom of opinion. It is unreasonable to restrict literature to a single category with a few message variations for a select group. Variety is what makes each person's opinion unique.  In conclusion, censorship of literature should not be enforced. Writing topics should be open to all, as every book has a purpose, regardless of whether it is offensive. Since writers have the right to express their ideas through literature, there should be no limit to these rights. Therefore, censorship should never be used to remove a piece of literature from the shelves.

Do you believe that every book you read, every movie you watch, and all the music you listen to is offensive? Who can determine what is offensive to everyone? Who can tell you whether something you think is offensive or not? How can you maintain your individuality if others make decisions for you regarding the books you read, the movies you watch, and the music you listen to? I will explain why I think certain materials such as books, movies, music, magazines, etc., should not be removed from library shelves just because someone finds them offensive.  Who can be the ultimate judge in deciding if something is offensive to everyone? Everyone has their own definition of offensive. Different people find different things offensive. How can you claim that something offensive to one person is also offensive to another? I believe that if one person finds something offensive, that is their opinion. However, the next person who encounters the so - called offensive material might love it. You should not make decisions for others about whether they want to read an offensive book, watch an offensive movie, or listen to offensive music. That is their choice, not yours.  If every person removed a book from the shelves that they considered offensive, there would soon be no books left. Some people think certain music, books, and movies are offensive, while others find them cool and interesting. So, what should be done? Over the years, I have learned that not everyone will agree with your opinions, and vice versa. But everyone is entitled to decide what they like and dislike, and to choose what books to read, movies to watch, and music to listen to. So, why should we let anyone prevent us from being ourselves?  You can never say that anything is offensive to everyone because no single person represents everyone. You cannot speak for others as everyone has their own voice. So, do you think every book, movie, and piece of music you engage with is offensive? You might not, but somewhere, someone is trying to remove certain items from libraries because they have a negative opinion. Is that fair? In conclusion, we should respect the diversity of opinions and keep these materials in libraries to allow individuals to make their own choices.

Imagine your child or a very close person who is around @NUM1 years old, just beginning to learn how to be an adult and take on responsibilities. This young person wants to try new things. They hear their friends talking about drinking alcohol and how much fun it is. They think it sounds amazing to drink without knowing whether it is bad or not because no one has ever told them. So, they start drinking and later die of alcohol poisoning.  Surely, you don't want this to happen to someone close to you. If people are too afraid to talk about the negative aspects of life, such as sex, drugs, etc., then there should be books and movies to show how bad these things are. There should not be censorship in libraries. Some might say, "They're too young; they can't handle these things yet." However, you should consider their maturity level. They can learn from other people's mistakes, and it would be an educational experience.  How can you assess someone's maturity level? There are multiple ways. If you talk to someone about sex and they start laughing and making jokes, they may not be very mature. But you can't assume that every @NUM2 - year - old is immature. Many people take these topics seriously, while others may not, but they will still be able to view them in their own way. Implementing censorship in libraries is not a good idea.  Many topics in books, movies, music, magazines, etc., may contain inappropriate content such as sex, drugs, drinking, and bad language. Should all these things be removed from libraries and their shelves? It's a difficult question to answer. What we can say is that it would allow people to learn from mistakes. For example, if there is a movie where a guy does drugs and later dies, people can infer that drugs are deadly. It's harder to show how offensive words are bad, but when people hear or read about such things, they can ask questions, and we can explain that saying or doing such things can be offensive.  Can you educate someone by letting them listen, read, or watch something offensive? It depends on the person, but you can educate them about the subject matter regardless of how offensive the topic is. We should teach people about these things. If we don't, history is likely to repeat itself. For instance, if we censor the Holocaust because it is horrifying, no one will know about it, and we may repeat such a tragedy. Censoring certain things in a library is not a good idea.  Certain people can handle talking about certain subjects. It's not always beneficial to censor offensive subjects. We need to educate people about these things so that they can learn and avoid repeating mistakes. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is not advisable as it hinders the learning process and the ability to understand the real world.

Offensive books should have a place in the library, but they should be placed in a separate area away from children. If everyone were to choose a book they didn't want in the library and have it removed, there would be no books left. Since everyone has different opinions on what is offensive, it's difficult to decide what can and cannot be in the library.  When I was a child, my grandma would take me to the library almost every @DATE1. I noticed that she tried to steer me away from certain books while being okay with others. My @CAPS1 did the same, but they had different views on what was appropriate for me to read. Grandma wanted me to get religious books, and @CAPS1 was fine with that and other books like '@CAPS2 the @CAPS3 @CAPS4 @CAPS5' and '@PERSON1'.  Even at home, opinions vary greatly. For example, when it comes to music, @CAPS1 likes country, @CAPS7 likes metal, my brother likes alternative music, my uncle likes rock, and I enjoy a combination of all these genres.  This shows that people have diverse opinions, with some being more strict than others. If we relied on people's opinions to keep libraries free of offensive materials, libraries would be empty. In conclusion, we should accept the diversity of opinions and find a way to accommodate different types of materials in libraries to meet the needs of all users.

Taking any of these books off the shelves would be like taking away a part of our childhood. That wouldn't be a nice thing to do. If some books were removed, what would we show our children when they ask about our favorite childhood books? We'd have to tell them that the library doesn't have those books anymore because they had to make room for other books.  Think about it. Our parents got to read all their favorite childhood books. How would you feel if you couldn't share that experience with your kids? I'd be really upset because my parents told me about those books, and I went to the library to get them and loved them.  So, please, if you can, leave the books alone. In conclusion, these books are an important part of our heritage and should be preserved in libraries for future generations to enjoy.

What is a library? A library is a place where one can access books, movies, music, magazines, etc., for research or entertainment purposes. The question is, should there be censorship in libraries?  In my opinion, there should be very limited censorship in a library. If every time there was a complaint about something offensive in the library and it was removed from the shelf, there would be nothing left in the library. Many people go to the library to relax, have some quiet time, and let their minds wander, imagine, and dream. They don't worry about being offended by a @CAPS1 @CAPS2 book.  However, censorship in a library can be beneficial if used carefully. For example, moving adult - oriented books to a section where children won't access them can prevent children from having nightmares about disturbing images. What I'm suggesting is to have censorship at a very low level. If a library had high - level censorship and everything was removed from the shelves, there would be no point in going to the library; it would just be an empty room.  If someone is offended by something in the library, appropriate measures should be taken based on the severity of the offense. For instance, if something offends someone unintentionally, it can be left where it is. But if something intentionally offends someone based on their race, ethnicity, etc., it should be removed from the shelf.  Having low - level censorship in libraries is a good idea. There would be a sufficient quantity of materials for research, and a wider range of topics to stimulate imagination. At the same time, people wouldn't have to worry about being severely offended. In conclusion, a balanced approach with low - level censorship is the best way to maintain the functionality and value of a library.

Censorship in libraries involves the act of removing items that some individuals dislike from the shelves, which implies disregarding the opinions of others. The decision to remove an item should depend on the nature of the product, such as books, magazines, music albums, or movies. In most stores, products are categorized not according to personal preferences but by genre or age - suitability. For instance, if a person ventures outside their typical section, the products in the new section may not align with their taste.  A local community library offers a wide range of reading materials, including baby books, kids' sections, teenage sections, and adult sections. As an individual, I used to frequent the kids' section, but now I'm more inclined towards the teenage section. However, just because I no longer have an interest in kids' books doesn't mean they should be removed, as the next generation will likely enjoy them.  Music presents a different situation. People have diverse musical preferences, like country or alternative. Libraries provide various music albums for patrons to sample before renting. If I don't like an album, I simply return it, and the librarian doesn't discard it based on my opinion, as it may appeal to others.  Regarding movies, while I believe anyone can watch different types of films, not all parents allow their 12 - year - olds to watch certain rated movies. In libraries, age restrictions are in place for some movies, but this doesn't mean these movies should be removed, as younger patrons may develop an interest as they get older.  In conclusion, an individual's opinion is important to them, but other opinions matter as well. Library products are for everyone to access, not to be judged. If everyone were to judge and remove items, there would be little left in the library.

I firmly believe that it is unjust to ban any type of materials from the library. Withholding information from children is simply wrong because they will discover such information sooner or later. It is far better for them to learn from books, magazines, movies, or CDs, as they can then turn to their parents with questions. This way, they can gain accurate knowledge and understand the difference between right and wrong, rather than getting misinformation from peers.  For example, if a child reads about sex or an affair in a magazine, it is beneficial for parents to be involved in the child's learning process. Parents can guide the child, helping them distinguish between truth and falsehood and preventing unnecessary confusion or worry.  Moreover, the information children can find in magazines or movies is readily available on the internet. The internet often contains more graphic content and false information, and a child's curiosity may lead them to inappropriate websites.  When I was a child, my parents tried to shelter me from certain topics. However, in second grade, high - schoolers on the bus introduced me to topics like sex, showed me pictures, and shared information that I would have preferred to learn in a more appropriate setting. I felt unable to discuss these things with my parents, fearing their lack of understanding.  It is understandable that there are some materials that children should not access. But it is unfair to deny them the opportunity to learn and ask questions. If a child gets hold of inappropriate materials, it may be due to a lack of proper supervision. Parents should engage with their children when they read, listen, or watch something that seems inappropriate. They should explain things clearly, ensuring that children can tell the difference between good and bad. Taking away materials without proper explanation is truly unjust.

Banning books from library shelves is not a good idea because people have diverse reading preferences. Books are valuable as they help improve reading skills and expose readers to new knowledge. When I was in middle school, I was fond of reading books by @PERSON1 and @PERSON2. However, when I asked the librarian if they had those books, the answer was no. The librarian thought that middle - schoolers shouldn't read books with cuss words and violence. But I believe it shouldn't matter what kids read because you can't force a child to read something they're not interested in. Everyone has different tastes, and there are various types of books, such as mystery, fiction, non - fiction, and historical books. Classroom textbooks are also books, but they are not the kind we read for pleasure every day.  I think parents should take their children to the public library. When I was in elementary and junior high, we had reading tests on the computer. In seventh and eighth grade, we had reading sessions in class, and there was even a reading challenge among schools, which was part of our English grade. Reading was never a problem for me as I loved it.  That being said, there are some books that libraries should remove from the shelves, especially those with nudity or excessive violence, and this is mainly for children under 13. Currently, there are more adult books than children's books.  In conclusion, parents should monitor what their children read but not prevent them from reading. If a child doesn't like reading, parents should encourage them to try. When children see their relatives reading, they are more likely to follow suit. Reading is beneficial for people of all ages, regardless of the type of book.

In this persuasive essay, I aim to discuss whether offensive materials should be removed from library shelves, and I firmly believe that we should not do so.  Firstly, what one person finds offensive may not be offensive to another. Removing materials based on individual opinions can harm those who want to access such materials. Some movies and books that are considered offensive may actually be beneficial for kids' future development.  Secondly, if we remove all offensive materials, the library would be left with only a few inoffensive movies and books like Bambi and Scooby - Doo. In fact, almost all materials in libraries can be considered offensive in some way by different people. I have yet to find an offensive movie or book in any library. If we remove all offensive materials, the library would be nearly empty, with only about @NUM1 movies and books in the entire building. In that case, having a library would hardly make sense.  People encounter cuss words in their daily lives, at school or at home. The words and actions in movies are often not as bad as those in real - life situations. We should view movies and books as just forms of entertainment. Scary movies and some books are fictional, and although there are inappropriate elements like sex in movies, age restrictions are in place.  In summary, removing materials from library shelves is not advisable as it can harm others and serves no real purpose. We should keep the library as a place where people can freely access a wide range of materials.

When I visit a library to search for a book, I hope not to come across inappropriate books, movies, or magazines. The thought of a child seeing such content concerns me deeply. I want a library where my child can visit without my having to worry about what they might encounter.  To address this issue, libraries can take several measures. One option is to censor the materials placed on the shelves. By locating the adult - book section near the checkout area, library employees can easily spot young children who might wander into that section. If this solution doesn't work, libraries can rate the sections, similar to movie ratings. Group books and movies according to different levels of suitability, such as @CAPS2, @CAPS2 - @DATE1, @CAPS4 - @CAPS5, and so on.  I had a personal experience when I took my baby brother to the library. He brought me an adult book with a nude woman on the cover and asked to check it out. I was shocked and embarrassed. I never expected such an incident to happen in a public library.  I believe that everyone should have the freedom to choose the books or movies they want. Therefore, I don't advocate for the removal of inappropriate materials but rather for better organization. By arranging the materials properly, we can ensure that children are less likely to be exposed to inappropriate content. In conclusion, libraries should take steps to manage their collections to create a safe and suitable environment for all patrons.

Should libraries censor the books on their shelves? I firmly believe they should. There are numerous offensive materials on the shelves. I wouldn't want my child or anyone else's child to read offensive books. Therefore, we should either eliminate all the inappropriate content or at least filter it. Any book, movie, or magazine containing a significant amount of profanity or inappropriate pictures should be removed or restricted to a certain age group. If libraries wish to keep these materials on the shelves, they should require readers to be in high school and have a permission slip to access them. Completely removing these materials would cause too much trouble. Instead, we should ensure that children are of a certain age and have permission. I wouldn't want my [@NUM1] - year - old child to read a book with bad language. Children pick up on such things quickly and may start imitating the language, which is not a good outcome. There are already many negative influences in society that can harm children. They don't need to read about criminal activities. I think the prevalence of such issues today is because people are exposed to these ideas at a young age and may want to emulate them later. They don't need books and movies that make the situation worse by making them think bad things are acceptable. If we don't filter what children are exposed to at a young age, they may become unruly and out of control, believing that actions shown in books or movies are okay for them to do, when in fact, they are not. I advocate for setting an age limit on access to such materials to improve society and help our children become better adults. We need to filter out the bad and provide better content for our younger generation. If we don't, we can't predict how they will turn out, and the world could deteriorate. So, let's start the filtering process to save the world and our children's future.

In my view, offensive literary works should be removable from libraries. If a piece of [@CAPS1] is extremely offensive, it should not be on display. From my own experience, controversy is the main reason books are removed from libraries. All my experiences, observations, and reading have led me to one conclusion: offensive literary pieces are taken away. When I encounter books that cause controversy, I usually don't like them. As someone who isn't particularly fond of reading, coming across offensive content makes me lose interest in reading altogether. All my experiences suggest avoiding books that cause distress or controversy. My observations also align with my experiences. I've noticed classmates and others who lose interest in reading because they feel offended by a novel. Although my observations [@MONTH1] may seem one - sided, I've seen more cases of reduced reading due to controversy than increased reading. All my observations support the removal of 'banned books'. The most prominent book I've read on this topic is [@CAPS2] [@NUM1]. In this novel, society has banned all books. While the story seems to support those who want to read controversial novels, we can draw a lesson from it. The people in the story lived happily without controversial books, although not all of them did, due to certain factors. Stories like "The Three Little Pigs and the Big Bad Wolf" show how poorly the concept of controversy is handled. For example, I was shocked when I first heard it and never wanted to hear it again because I thought it was not politically correct. Offensive literary pieces should be removed. If someone is not interested in reading a book because of its content, the book should be removed from public access to maintain peace. I wholeheartedly support the removal of controversial books from public places.

Nowadays, people often seem eager to find something offensive. The [@ORGANIZATION1] often feels pressured to please these individuals. The reality is that in a country with a large population, there will be a wide range of ideas, preferences, and dislikes. Libraries are repositories of knowledge, housing various books, magazines, and movies to cater to different tastes. Most people can quickly determine whether they like a book or not, so books rarely offend readers. Magazines are similar to books in that people know what they want. They usually flip through the pages until they find an article they're interested in and then move on. Music has accompanied humanity since ancient times. It has a soothing effect on the human body and is constantly evolving. Initially, music was just vocal, but over the centuries, it has become more complex. It would be ideal if there were a single type of music that everyone liked, but that's not the case. There are so many music genres that it's difficult to find someone who likes all of them. Some people resist change and stick to their favorite music types. If everyone changed with time, there would be only a few music genres. Since there are many, there will always be someone who objects to a particular song. Movies have advanced significantly in the last century. They used to have simple plots that everyone enjoyed. However, many people want movies to evolve with technology. Today's movies often feature special effects, love, sex, alcohol, parties, and fighting. Directors try to create engaging movies by including just enough of each element, but if they overdo it, someone is likely to find it offensive. Movies are meant to be entertaining, not a source of offense. Fortunately, the movie industry has established a rating system to warn audiences. Whether it's a book, magazine, music, or movie, there will always be someone who doesn't like it or is offended by it. This is an inevitable part of diversity, and we can't do much about it. It simply shows that everyone in the world is different. We should conclude that just because one person dislikes something doesn't mean others will.

In my opinion, books and similar materials should not be removed from library shelves just because they are considered offensive. If there is content in a book that is potentially offensive to children, it should be placed in an adult - only section. Most libraries I've visited have separate areas for different age groups. If a book contains racially unacceptable content, it should be in the adult section, away from children. When determining whether a book is offensive, all possible ways in which someone [@MONTH1] might interpret the story should be considered to gauge their reaction. There are many genres of books, music, magazines, etc., so there is always a suitable place for each item. Most concerns about books revolve around language. For example, in [@CAPS1], the book "[@CAPS2] of [@ORGANIZATION1]" has been questioned about its suitability for school reading because of the 'n - word'. Although it is a harsh word, it is relevant to the story's setting and background. When unsure about a book's acceptability, one should consider the story's context and whether the word is necessary. In many cases, the seemingly unacceptable elements are integral to the story. If one book is questioned for something wrong, should all books, music, movies, magazines, etc., be questioned? If something is not allowed in one item, it should not be allowed in others. The appropriateness of a book depends on the audience. I've read books with certain words that don't bother me, but others may be offended. Some parents don't want their children exposed to foul language or inappropriate content in music. It all comes down to the individual reader or listener. Katherine Paterson makes a valid point: if we start removing books from the shelves, eventually, there will be no books left. Just because a book contains a bad word or phrase doesn't mean it should be taken away from people's enjoyment.

If you grew up with caring parents, you've probably heard them say, "No, you can't play that game, listen to that music, or watch that movie." When you asked why, the answer was always, "You're not old enough." If you had the nerve to ask again, they might have said, "[@CAPS2] If I wanted you to know, I'd let you find out on your own!" and that didn't get you far. Now, think about those things you weren't allowed to do as a child and how you can do them now that you're older. What if those movies, [@CAPS3]'s, or games had been removed from the shelves before you could access them? What would you and your friends have done if you couldn't watch "[@CAPS4] [@CAPS5] [@CAPS6] [@CAPS7] [@CAPS8]" because someone found it offensive? Also, think about your future or current child. Would you want your [@NUM2] - year - old to be exposed to movies like "[@DATE1] The [@NUM1]" or "[@CAPS9] and [@CAPS10]" at that age? Most likely not. But what if these movies were removed because they were considered offensive? Then your child would never see them, and some might think that's the right thing. However, movies with sexual themes, drug use, or foul language are still being made. "[@DATE1] The [@NUM1]" has been remade and is even more graphic. There are countless other movies with such content, and they're becoming more popular. There are [@CAPS11] movies with sexual references, cigarettes, or bad words. You might be able to remove a few, but it's impossible to rid the shelves of all of them. Even if you could, what would be left to watch? If all offensive movies were removed, your kids would have limited options, maybe just [@CAPS12] the [@CAPS13] and [@CAPS14 - @CAPS15]. And what about you? You'd have nothing to watch either. All the things you like in a movie but don't want your child to see would be gone. My advice is not to discard everything that [@MONTH1] be offensive or that you don't want your child to see. Instead of taking extreme measures to shield your child, simply don't let them watch those movies or listen to that music. This is what our parents did, and it has worked so far, so there's no need to change it.

I firmly believe that library censorship, as it stands, is appropriate for several reasons. Firstly, almost all the materials in libraries are for people to learn from, whether through reading books or watching movies. Secondly, if all offensive or disliked materials were removed, there would be far less information available for people to learn from in libraries.  I concur with Katherine Paterson's quote. It implies that if we removed every book that someone found offensive, there would be no books left. Everyone has different sensitivities, and it's impossible to eliminate everything offensive from libraries. For instance, if someone wants to learn about a historical war, but another person is offended by it due to losing a loved - one, should the related writing be removed? Libraries are places for learning. They contain a wealth of information on various subjects, even if some of it may be offensive to certain individuals. If someone dislikes or finds something offensive, they should simply leave it on the shelf, as someone else might gain valuable knowledge from it.  In life, people need to be exposed to and informed about various things, even if they're not always pleasant. Libraries are where people are introduced to such information. If these materials are removed, people will have nowhere to turn for this knowledge.  In conclusion, while there are offensive materials in libraries, others can learn from them. It would be unfair to deprive everyone of this information. Libraries are for learning about different things and should always offer a wide range of information. Many people have learned life - changing things from libraries and will continue to do so as long as they have access to diverse sources of information.

The Harry Potter series by J.K. Rowling, consisting of seven books, is frequently censored in school libraries across the United States. The main reason is the positive portrayal of witchcraft, which is thought to harm innocent children. Many books, like Catcher in the Rye and Harry Potter, have been banned from school libraries because a group of people deems their content inappropriate without considering the broader meaning of these works. Public - accessible works should not be removed from library shelves just because they're considered offensive.  Under the First Amendment to the Constitution, every citizen has the freedom of speech, press, and religion. Censoring authors' speech denies their rights. Authors have the right to express what they think is necessary, and it shouldn't be up to a board of parents or directors to prohibit this right.  Banning books like Harry Potter or Catcher in the Rye disregards their greater meaning. Many conservative Christian groups have advocated for Harry Potter's ban in schools due to its portrayal of witchcraft (and thus satanism) and the fact that J.K. Rowling stated that Dumbledore (the headmaster in the series) is homosexual. However, the ultimate message of the series is that love triumphs over evil. Apparently, this isn't a message worth teaching American youth.  Even if every school in the country removed Harry Potter from the shelves, it shouldn't stop children from reading these books. Since Catcher in the Rye became part of many schools' curriculums in the 1950s, it has been at the top of the most - censored book list due to its vulgar language and a chapter about a prostitute. Yet, millions of teenagers have read this novel, which is a rite of passage for most young adults. Being one of the most - challenged books in the last fifty years only adds to its allure and popularity among the very people the censorship boards are trying to "protect".  If a parent doesn't want their child to read such a novel, it's up to the parent to censor their child's reading. Just because one parent doesn't want their child to read Harry Potter doesn't mean every child should be denied the opportunity. Censorship should be a private matter, not a public one.  In conclusion, books and other works should not be censored in libraries. Censorship violates an author's freedom of speech and disregards the greater meaning of the works. Although some groups advocate protecting children from offensive works, children will still find ways to access them.

Censorship in libraries isn't always necessary. It's the parents' responsibility to control what their kids access, not the library's job to dictate people's choices. However, there are certain situations where censorship may be needed.  Parents are in charge of raising their kids and teaching them right from wrong. They should be the ones to guide their children, not the library. Otherwise, parents are shirking their duties.  Libraries have the right to acquire books as long as they don't contain extremely harmful content. It's understandable if they remove materials for adults, but if there's just one offensive word, people should get over it.  Some people want to change classic books like Mark Twain's Huckleberry Finn because certain groups find them offensive. This is wrong. They're trying to rewrite history and sugar - coat the truth. Books are like the real world; people aren't always nice. The world is full of flaws.  There shouldn't be an issue with one or two bad words in great works of literature. In real life, people may curse, while in books, the offensive language is limited. We shouldn't change great books just because a minority finds them offensive. Libraries shouldn't decide what we can and can't read, and they shouldn't censor their books.  In conclusion, libraries should focus on providing a wide range of materials and let parents take the lead in guiding their children's reading choices. Censorship should be used sparingly, and the value of literature should be respected.

A young boy enters the local library. He looks around and finds a movie recommended by a friend. He checks it out and goes home to watch it. Later, when his parents return, they notice their son acting strangely. He starts making rude comments, being violent, and using profanity. Who's to blame? The friend who recommended the movie or the library for having it on the shelves and allowing the young boy to check it out?  Today, many libraries offer a variety of books, movies, music, and magazines. Some even provide computers for people of all ages, which can be used for business, personal email, or kids' games.  But are all libraries meeting their standards? Some people find many books, movies, music, magazines, and websites threatening. Libraries have movies with ratings like R, PG - 13, etc., and music with explicit lyrics. Some libraries fail to meet their requirements, which is why they have less business than others.  In my opinion, if a library has offensive materials like books, music, movies, magazines, and websites, they should be removed from the shelves. If librarians let young kids check out explicit music and R - rated movies, they might need to be fired. From my own experience, I've never had problems with libraries and their materials. I've never been to a library with explicit music, the computers have blocked bad websites, and the magazines are suitable for all ages.  In conclusion, libraries should respect both people and the materials they offer. They need to ensure that the books, movies, music, and magazines are appropriate. Censorship is necessary for every library, and I believe most libraries are meeting their requirements.

I firmly oppose the censorship of library - checked - out materials. While some library - goers may not seek offensive language or themes, others believe that un - censored content, when used appropriately, is better than censorship. For example, a book about a particular person might contain offensive elements, but for someone writing a report on that person, having as much information as possible is crucial.  However, I do make one concession: when it comes to music with offensive language, libraries should provide both clean and explicit versions of the albums.  Censorship has its pros and cons. Some people are offended by bad language and themes, while others see it as a form of artistic or authorial freedom. In my view, allowing both good and bad forms of content without censorship is better than complete censorship.  In conclusion, libraries should strike a balance. They should respect the diverse needs and preferences of their patrons while also providing access to a wide range of materials. By offering options like clean and explicit music versions and not over - censoring materials, libraries can better serve their communities.

In contemporary society, a significant number of children are exposed to harmful influences and engage in undesirable behaviors. There are certain materials that are inappropriate for children, which is why I firmly believe that libraries should implement censorship. Censorship in libraries serves multiple crucial purposes: guiding children towards positive paths, alleviating some of the burdens on parents, and addressing the issue of offensive content.  Censorship can effectively guide children in the right direction. When a child sees their role - model depicted on a movie case smoking, it is highly likely to pique their curiosity about smoking. I have witnessed this phenomenon firsthand. I once saw a kid I admired drinking, and I almost followed suit. Fortunately, the influence of my positive peers steered me away from this path. Children are greatly influenced by the actions of their role - models. By censoring such content, libraries can prevent children from being exposed to potentially harmful behaviors.  Parents are constantly worried about their children getting involved in legal troubles. Some movies available in libraries feature actors engaging in illegal activities. A child may perceive these actions as "cool" and attempt to imitate them. I have watched numerous movies that made me want to replicate the actions on screen. It may seem far - fetched, but there have been real - life cases where children have committed serious crimes after being influenced by movies. For example, a six - year - old boy shot his father in the head because he thought playing with guns was safe, as he had seen it in movies.  Censorship can also relieve some of the stress on parents. Parents are constantly concerned about their children's whereabouts, activities, and companions. If libraries censor inappropriate music and movies, parents can be more at ease, knowing that their children are less likely to be influenced by negative content. This gives parents confidence in their children's well - being.  Finally, offensive movies can cause harm to children, parents, or the target audience. Based on my personal experience, I know that offensive content in movies can create a hostile environment. In many movies, smart kids are often portrayed as being bullied, while athletes receive all the attention. As someone considered a "smart kid," I have felt the negative impact of such portrayals. My peers, after watching these movies, seem to think it is acceptable to pick on me, creating a sense of hatred. This situation could have been avoided with proper censorship.  In conclusion, it is evident that censorship in libraries is necessary. It helps guide children, eases parental concerns, and mitigates the negative effects of offensive content. Censorship is beneficial not only for children but also for parents. In my view, it is an essential measure for the well - being of the community.

People around the world hold diverse opinions. When someone dislikes something, they have the option to ignore it. Therefore, I firmly believe that when one finds something offensive in a library, they should not have the right to remove it.  One of the primary reasons for this stance is that not everyone shares the same perception of what is offensive. People have their own unique viewpoints on all things. If someone removes a book or other materials from the library because they consider it inappropriate, others who enjoy such content will be deprived of the opportunity to access it.  Another reason is that removing offensive materials can lead to dissatisfaction among some people. Many individuals enjoy the so - called "offensive" elements in books, movies, and other media. From my perspective, I appreciate having a bit of the unconventional in my life. Whether it's through reading a book, watching a movie, listening to music, or reading a magazine, I want to be able to visit a library and freely choose what I like without worrying about its availability.  In my opinion, offensive remarks and words often contribute to the humor in books and other forms of media. Just because something seems rude or inappropriate doesn't mean it lacks value. These elements can make a book or other content more interesting and engaging.  Although some offensive materials in libraries may appear inappropriate, if they are present, it indicates that they are not overly harmful. They should not be removed simply because one person believes they do not belong in a library. Everyone has their own opinions in life, and sometimes it is best to keep them to oneself. In conclusion, offensive materials should remain in libraries to respect the diverse interests and opinions of the public.

There are numerous books and movies that are considered inappropriate for younger audiences. Rating movies and designating specific age - groups for books help in categorizing these materials.  In public libraries, all books and movies are made available for everyone to borrow. There is an ongoing debate about whether these inappropriate materials should be accessible to all. If a child borrows a book or movie rated @CAPS1, parents may be upset with the library for allowing the child to access such content. On the other hand, there are also cases where parents want their children to borrow a @CAPS1 - rated movie, and the library may face harassment for denying the request.  The question of whether public libraries should allow certain age groups to borrow inappropriate materials logically leads to a negative answer. If a child is not permitted to watch a rated @CAPS1 movie at the theater, there is no reason for them to freely borrow such movies from the library. Public libraries should take measures to prevent underage children from borrowing inappropriate materials. A simple solution is to include the age of the library card holder on the card, which would resolve many misunderstandings.  By adjusting their censorship policies, public libraries can enhance their reputation and provide a safer environment for children to access materials. Taking control of the content available in libraries is a responsible step that benefits both the library and the community. In conclusion, public libraries should implement effective age - based censorship to ensure that children are not exposed to inappropriate materials.

It would be extremely beneficial for libraries to adopt a more flexible censorship policy, allowing a wider variety of books. In my view, this would be advantageous for students, parents, and teachers seeking information on different topics. Many students may need to write papers on unfamiliar subjects, and having access to a diverse range of books would greatly assist them.  A library is a place where people can go to gather information, enjoy a good read, or simply relax. When researching an unknown topic, it is highly desirable to find a comprehensive book on the subject. This is particularly helpful for students working on reports and for anyone seeking additional knowledge.  If someone does not want a certain type of book in the library, they should simply ignore it. I believe that books that are beneficial to others should not be removed just because they may be offensive to some. Even if a book covers topics such as drugs, sex, or violence, it can still educate those who are not well - informed about these inappropriate or offensive subjects.  In conclusion, it would be a mistake to censor libraries by removing books. This practice deprives many people of the opportunity to gain knowledge on various topics, whether for educational or professional purposes. A diverse collection of books in libraries is essential for the intellectual growth and development of the community.

No, books should not be banned from libraries. If we start banning books based on the fact that they might offend someone, then almost every book could be at risk. If a person thinks a book is bad, they simply shouldn't read it.  First of all, a book is just a form of media. There is no valid reason to ban it just because some people don't like it. If a child reads an adult - oriented book, it can actually be beneficial as they get to learn big words. Even if they come across a naked picture, it's not the end of the world. It's likely not the first time they'll encounter such content, and it won't be the last.  Secondly, some people try to ban books just to create drama. They know that banning a book will cause a stir, especially with the author. This kind of behavior is unjust and goes against the principle of free access to knowledge.  Finally, if we ban books because they are considered offensive, there won't be many books left in the library. Almost anything can be considered offensive by someone. In conclusion, no single book should be banned from the library. Libraries should provide a wide range of reading materials to meet the diverse interests of the public.

In libraries, some shelf - stored materials may offend certain individuals, and I've witnessed such materials myself. The question is whether libraries should remove them. Offensiveness is subjective; what one person finds offensive, another may not. Libraries can't satisfy everyone. In my view, libraries shouldn't remove these materials because what one person dislikes could be another's preference. However, there are solutions for those who want the materials removed. For example, 'offensive materials' can be placed on taller shelves or in a separate room so that children or those who object don't have to see them. This way, both parties' concerns are addressed. If this solution fails, libraries can replace extremely offensive materials with more suitable ones. Overall, I believe libraries shouldn't remove these materials. Instead, efforts should be made to satisfy both those who are offended and those who aren't, thus resolving the issue.

I firmly believe that if library materials are offensive, they should be removed. A library is a place where people go to gain better understanding of unknown things. If someone visits a library and finds something inappropriate, it should be taken off the shelf. I wouldn't want anyone to be dissatisfied with the library's books, movies, music, etc., especially when children are involved. A public library should be a place that meets people's expectations and is suitable for children to learn. It is a learning environment that should inspire education, growth, and development. The primary goal of a library is learning, so offensive materials should be removed. Children should be able to visit a library and be content with its offerings. In conclusion, offensive materials have no place in a library as it undermines the library's purpose of providing a positive learning experience.

Should library materials be censored? I don't think so. If a material is offensive to someone, they simply don't have to look at it. People should have the right to access whatever they want from the library. If someone doesn't like the available materials, that's their problem. Regarding the concern about kids getting inappropriate materials, libraries won't let kids check out inappropriate items. Also, parents should monitor what their kids get. I visit the library often and have never seen anything inappropriate, and I know no one who has reported finding offensive materials. Libraries generally understand what people want. It's not right to remove materials just because a few people dislike them, as there are likely others who like them. Only extremely offensive materials that everyone agrees are bad should be removed. Removing materials every time someone complains would leave the library nearly empty. In conclusion, materials shouldn't be removed just because some people find them offensive, as many others may not be offended, and taking them away would be unfair.

I think that books in libraries that children aren't allowed to read should be placed in areas where kids can't access them. There should be sections for specific age - groups. In some libraries, many books not suitable for children are accessible to them, and this should not be allowed. The same principle applies in stores. In some stores, the magazine section has inappropriate content for kids. At the grocery store I go to, there are inappropriate images and words. I once saw a little kid reading a magazine with bad words and pictures. So, magazines should be placed in an area restricted to certain ages. In the same store, the music section is often filled with children. While the music isn't always bad, kids can take the music home to listen to, and it's the parents' fault if they buy it for their kids. Music for different age - groups should be separated. The same goes for movies. There are movies rated for different audiences, and many movies rated for older audiences have content that children shouldn't see. They're often just sitting on store shelves. The reason for all these measures is to prevent children from getting hold of inappropriate materials. If kids listen to bad music or watch inappropriate movies, they may start using bad words and get in trouble. In conclusion, children should not have access to inappropriate books, magazines, music, and movies.

Should we have the right to remove offensive materials from shelves? I believe we shouldn't. If we had this right, there would be few materials left for future generations. Many materials may contain content related to discrimination or offensive words, or they may not be to our liking. But we should never have the right to remove them. There are books that either discriminate against certain races or inform us about past discrimination. If we could remove these materials, they would eventually disappear. Future children would either be unaware of these events or have inaccurate information. If someone finds a single offensive word in a book or movie, they shouldn't be able to remove it from others' access. Many good books and movies would vanish because of one person's dislike of a word. Some people may think certain materials are a waste of space and remove them, but there are others who enjoy them. Judging a book by its size or word - size is not valid. I think no one should have the right to remove books, movies, music, or magazines from the shelf. We should preserve these materials for future generations. In the past, people destroyed materials they disliked, and we now have no knowledge of them. There's no reason to remove materials based on one person's or a group's opinion. In conclusion, we should respect the diversity of materials in libraries and other media sources for the sake of future learning and understanding.

Removing offensive materials from library shelves is not the right approach. Despite how offensive some materials like books, music, movies, and magazines may seem, there are alternative solutions. Everyone has different views on what is offensive. For example, some people prefer comedies, while others like horror movies. People have their own preferences for what they read, listen to, or watch, so why take away things they enjoy? A better solution is to separate certain materials in the library. If something is considered offensive, it can be grouped with similar items. This way, materials don't need to be completely removed. Mothers often worry about their children accessing offensive materials in the library. Separating these materials can address this concern. In conclusion, there's no need to remove materials from libraries because people have diverse interests. Offensive materials should not be removed from libraries.

I'm currently quite ill with a throbbing headache as I write this paper, so I hope you'll be lenient. Every literary work is a product of someone's imagination, shaped in the direction the creator desires. If writing, an art form, were censored, it would be no more than worthless trash floating in the streets. It's similar to watching TV. If a horror movie with nudity is too scary and inappropriate for your kids, don't let them watch it. In a library, a mother can't always pre - read books for her child. So, one has to take responsibility and decide whether to read a book based on what their mother might think. The idea of library censorship is absurd. I wouldn't want to see certain explicit content in the children's section, but it's just a matter of proper book placement. Keep explicit books on one side and non - explicit on the other. Most library users are old enough to choose their own books, and if not, they're accompanied by their mothers. In conclusion, library censorship is unnecessary. We should rely on proper categorization and individual responsibility.

Libraries and stores across the country are filled with various types of books, music, movies, and magazines. Consumers often pick these items without fully realizing what they're buying, and parents may not be aware of what their children purchase. Some materials can be offensive and have a negative influence, but if parents are more cautious, there's no need to remove these items from the shelves. One key reason not to remove these items is that consumers have the right to choose what to buy or borrow. People should make their own decisions. If they don't like something, they can go to another shelf or store. Taking away items is like taking away people's right to choose. It's the adults' responsibility to prevent their children from accessing mature - content movies. Parents can restrict certain things until their children are old enough to decide for themselves. Just because some people are bothered by offensive items doesn't mean they should be removed. It's difficult to remove all such items from libraries and stores due to the media's reach. Younger children will likely always be exposed to such materials through TV commercials, music videos, and magazines. If people removed all the items they didn't approve of, library shelves would be empty. Taking away one book could mean taking away someone's favorite. We separate children's and adult sections for a reason. In my experience, kids usually prefer the children's section. In conclusion, offensive materials should remain on the shelves. It's the parents' responsibility to monitor their children, and people can't remove items just because they're offensive to some.

I think that if you're in a library, movie store, or anywhere else and you find books, movies, magazines, or CDs offensive, they should probably be removed from the shelves. I've had the experience of walking into a store and seeing something inappropriate for kids, which made me feel embarrassed. That's why I believe such items should be removed from the store or at least from the shelves. I often wonder how my grandparents would feel if they knew the kind of music most teens listen to today. There's so much bad language, talk of violence, and other inappropriate content that it's not suitable for anyone to hear. I know some people have different views on this, and some take it too seriously. But everyone is entitled to their opinion. In conclusion, offensive materials should be removed from public shelves to avoid discomfort and inappropriate exposure.

I'm conflicted about whether certain books should be removed from library shelves. On one hand, I believe some books should be removed. Public libraries are frequented by under - age children. Although they can't check out certain books, they can still read them in the library. Also, some books may be offensive to certain people. For example, a book that makes offensive jokes about a particular race could be hurtful to someone of that race. On the other hand, I don't think any book should be removed from a library. Libraries are meant to cater to a wide range of interests. It's unfair to remove books just because some people find them inappropriate. People should be able to freely browse books without having to search for ones that interest them but have been removed due to others' sensitivities. In conclusion, the decision to remove books from libraries is complex. We should try to see from different perspectives and not hastily remove books based on individual sensitivities.

When one visits various places, there will always be something that they dislike, as not everyone likes everything. A library is perhaps the worst place in this regard. Censorship in libraries is worsening day by day, encompassing books, movies, music, and magazines. Should such materials remain on the shelves? Everyone who reads this will have different thoughts about library censorship. There are many items on the shelves with bad language and inappropriate pictures. Young children can easily pull these books off the shelves and see things that their parents don't want them to see. Censorship exists not only in libraries. The materials in libraries need to be improved and made less objectionable. If there is a demand for such content, a special store should be established for it. In conclusion, a balance must be struck to ensure that libraries remain a suitable environment for all, especially young readers.

Censorship in school libraries is a significant issue. Sometimes, students may want to read a particular book but cannot access it in their school library. Many excellent educational books have been removed from library shelves because they contain either excessive violence or inappropriate language. If children or parents are offended by such books, they simply don't need to borrow them. There should be no censorship of books in schools. Many books that teachers consider educational have been taken off library shelves, books that teachers would like to assign to their classes. There should be no problem with students reading a book that has a few swear words or violent scenes. Some of the banned books could resonate with readers and have a profound impact on them. The practice of banning books in libraries needs to change. People should have the right to read what they want, even if it's from a school library. For instance, '@CAPS1 for @PERSON1' was banned in public schools for some reason. This is one of my top - five favorite books, yet I couldn't borrow it from the library because it was banned. Such restrictions should be lifted regardless of the reader's age. In conclusion, library censorship must be eliminated so that people can freely access the literature that may enrich their lives.

I firmly believe that certain offensive materials should either be removed from the general shelves or placed in restricted areas where young children or those with religious objections cannot easily access them. For example, there are books, music, movies, and magazines that contain offensive images or language, which are offensive not just to me but to many others as well. Offensive content includes inappropriate images, videos, and bad words that are not suitable for everyone to see or hear. One must be cautious when judging something as offensive because everyone has different opinions. We have the right to express our thoughts through speech, reading, and writing. I'm not advocating for the prohibition of certain books or music; rather, I think there is an appropriate time for everything. As young people, we are striving for a better future, and the older generation, with their experience, should provide us with the best guidance. In a free country, people should voice their opinions. It's important to stand up against offensive words or images and not let others force us to do something offensive to someone else. In conclusion, while respecting freedom of expression, we should also take measures to protect the well - being of all, especially the younger generation.

In today's world, there is an abundance of content around children. If we tried to remove all potentially harmful materials, we would end up taking away most of the entertainment available. Many adults note that the world has changed significantly since their youth. Instead of complaining, we should take action. Adults can limit the amount of content children bring home. Nowadays, in any store, one can find something that they wouldn't want their children to consume. People are doing their best to separate inappropriate materials from family - friendly ones, but it's often not enough. Children are getting addicted to certain content at a young age and sharing it with their friends. Many movies and music convey negative ideas that children don't need to learn. Content related to drugs, parties, and drinking should not be on radio stations or TV channels accessible to young children. Adults need to understand that this kind of content is harmful to children and should keep them away from it as much as possible. As the author said, if everyone removed something from the shelves, there would be nothing left. While we can't eliminate all such content, we can start by reducing the amount. The remaining content can be kept in places where children don't usually go. Our towns and cities can do a better job of protecting children from @CAPS1 rated movies, negative songs, and books about 'adult things'. Since children are the future of the world, exposing them to such negative content bodes ill for the future. By keeping children away from these materials, we can create a better world. In conclusion, it is our collective responsibility to safeguard children from harmful content.

There are numerous books, music, movies, and magazines that some people find offensive, and some advocate for their removal from the shelves. However, I do not believe they should be completely removed. Not everyone finds these materials offensive, and they should not be taken off the shelves just because a few people object. Firstly, people have diverse views on what is offensive. Just because one person is offended by a movie or book doesn't mean everyone wants it removed. If someone found my favorite book offensive, I wouldn't want it taken off the shelves. Secondly, if every offensive item were removed, there would be very little left. As author Katherine Paterson said, if everyone has the right to remove a book they abhor, then there will be no books left for anyone. People find different things offensive, and if we act on every objection, there will be nothing for anyone to enjoy. Finally, if someone finds a book offensive, they don't have to read it. Instead of removing it, they can simply avoid it. Taking offensive materials off the shelves could upset many people who don't find them offensive. In conclusion, while some may be offended by certain content, we should respect the rights of others to access it and find alternative ways to deal with offensive materials rather than complete removal.

Everyone has things that can offend them, whether they admit it or not. Books, music, movies, and other materials can all potentially offend different people. Even books used in school classrooms can cause offense. Reading is important, and readers will inevitably encounter something that offends them. In my view, we have the right to have these potentially offensive things. There are numerous books that offend people, music and movies already have censorship options, and if someone is offended, they can simply ignore it.  First, we have the right to these kinds of books. In life, there are things we don't like, but we deal with them. The same goes for books. Even though some people don't like certain books, those books are often well - liked and become famous. I once read a book that some wanted to ban, and it was one of the best I've ever read. If we removed every book that one person didn't like, there would be very few left.  Second, music and movies have censorship. We can choose whether to have it or not. Movies indicate appropriate age groups, and music can block offensive words. If people don't want to be exposed to offensive content, they don't have to listen or watch. We all have things we love and hate, and we can't eliminate all the hated things.  Last, if people don't want to be exposed to something, they don't have to. Music and movies are options. It's all a matter of opinion, and there's no right or wrong. I know people who don't have @CAPS1's or don't listen to the radio, and that's fine. They don't need to complain if they don't pay attention to it.  In conclusion, there are many books that offend people, music and movies have censorship, and those who are offended can avoid the content. These books, magazines, music, etc., are well - liked by many. Why get rid of them for the few who are offended? We all have things we like and dislike that we can't change. As Katherine Paterson once said, 'But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.'

I was wandering through the library, looking for the perfect books to check out. I came across a book that seemed incredibly interesting. Its cover showed a depressed girl with a look of hope on her face, and the back had a summary that made me eager to read it. The book, titled @CAPS1, was about a girl who overcame troubled times. All kinds of stories, novels, magazines, or books on tape find their way onto library shelves, and it's our job to discover them. Whether the literature is about love and heartbreak, sorrow and depression, or the success of a sports team, it should all be allowed on library shelves.  Everyone has opinions that conflict with others. Our world is full of different viewpoints, and literature and music should reflect these opposing sides. Literature is an escape for many. It allows readers to experience the world through the characters they read about. If we remove books that might be offensive to some, we're taking away this opportunity for others. In my opinion, removing potentially offensive material from libraries is like sheltering our world.  No matter how hard we try, children and teenagers will eventually be exposed to offensive material. Instead of hiding the real world from them, we should let them experience it in a safe way, like through reading or listening to music. If someone finds material offensive, it's the parents' responsibility to decide whether their child reads or listens to it. Removing the potentially offensive material won't help.  In conclusion, offensive material shouldn't be removed from libraries. Instead, it should be regulated by parents or elders. Regulating what's on library shelves isn't the most effective approach. If any material has the potential to be offensive, it's not the library's job to decide whether it's displayed to the public.

Library censorship should remain as it is. There are several reasons for this: parents should control what their children read, not all people agree on censorship, and libraries have a wide variety of books on different subjects.  Parents should be in charge of their children's reading. If parents tell their children not to read a certain book, the children will likely comply. If parents don't want their children in a particular section, they can simply tell them to stay away. Even if a child might stray from their parents, it's unlikely that the parents won't notice. So, parents should be responsible for what their children read.  Not all people agree on censorship. Some people think religion is important regardless of what a book shows, while others find parts of religious books (such as nudity or swear words) inappropriate. Some believe that books like @CAPS1 mythology books are inappropriate and need to be censored, while others see them as part of past culture and want them to remain in libraries. Most children find these books too big to read and won't even look at them. There are few people who agree on censorship, and many who disagree.  Libraries have books on different subjects, so people can choose to read something other than inappropriate books. It's unlikely that a child will pick the dirtiest book and say they want to read it. Children usually prefer books related to television shows or movies. So, people can easily ignore inappropriate books.  In conclusion, library books should keep the current censorship level. Parents should control their children's reading, there is no consensus on censorship, and libraries offer diverse reading options. Some people think the current censorship is fine, while others disagree. But children probably won't be interested in inappropriate books anyway.

I once saw an old lady looking at a book in the library. The book was about medical marijuana. She seemed offended, but I firmly believe that if a book is on the library shelf, it should stay there.  I'm trying to convince librarians, readers, and everyone else that if they're offended by a book, magazine, movie, or any item in a @CAPS1 library, they should keep quiet. A library has multiple functions. First, it's @CAPS1, open to everyone. Second, with a library card, people can borrow books, movies, music, etc. Third, if someone needs a place to go while on the road, they can use the library.  My point is that nothing should be removed from library shelves. Of course, there are times when we need to take action, but we can have an adolescent - only room or something similar. Removing an item from a library shelf is like taking away a part of its essence. Suppose there are @NUM1 @CAPS1 libraries in a town. One library has an item that the others don't. If someone protests and gets it removed from the shelf, it may be hard to find it elsewhere, unless you buy it online, which can be expensive when you could get it for free at the library.  I understand why some people want to remove certain materials. For example, if a @NUM2 - year - old kid walks up with a sex - related book, it can be a problem. Parents want to keep their kids in a safe environment, and they may complain about such books in a @CAPS1 library.  After such incidents, people often blame librarians for having inappropriate books, movies, and music. But it's not the librarians' fault. Different people like different books, which is why libraries offer a wide range of choices.  Then the idea of having separate rooms for different books comes up. It sounds good, but who will pay for it? Libraries rely on donations. They are profitable to some extent but also a non - profitable resource. Libraries have been around for a long time, starting small and growing big. They make money by selling donated books they don't need. Only then can they start creating separate rooms.  This solution may seem crazy, but it won't cause a riot. People, librarians, and readers will be happy. You can easily find the book you want in a specific room, check it out, and enjoy reading.
