A library serves as a place where people can borrow books, music, movies, and other materials that they may not have at home. Some individuals visit the library to use the computers for projects or to check out various media. It's not necessarily a bad thing if the library has materials that some people find offensive. If people don't want to be exposed to offensive content, they can simply avoid the relevant areas of the library.  In my opinion, the presence of offensive materials in the library doesn't greatly affect me. However, there should be an age - restriction for borrowing or reading such materials. Not everyone should have unrestricted access to them. If a person under the specified age tries to check out offensive materials, they should be denied.  If someone is offended by certain materials, they have the option to bypass that section of the library or simply ignore the content. The library could set aside a specific area for these types of materials so that neither adults nor children are forced to see them.  Moreover, if a child wants to access offensive materials, they may find other ways to do so. They don't have to rely solely on the library. If a child is determined to see something, they will find a means to achieve it.  If parents are unhappy about the presence of offensive materials in the library, they should teach their children not to look at such content. If they catch their children looking at offensive materials, they should discipline them and explain why it's inappropriate. Libraries shouldn't be required to remove their books, music, magazines, etc., just to satisfy parents.  If libraries were to remove these materials from their shelves, they would likely lose business. Therefore, libraries should not be pressured to remove materials just to please parents. Instead, parents should take responsibility for guiding their children. Offensive materials should remain in libraries, but with appropriate rules in place.

To start, a woman might read a book about wives and find it offensive. However, it was her decision to pick up and read the book. Should the book be removed from the shelf? Certainly not. Different individuals hold diverse perspectives on what they read, and not everyone will have the same reaction. The same principle applies to music, movies, magazines, and so on. For instance, someone might see a naked picture in a magazine and dislike it, but it was their choice to pick up the magazine. No one forced them to engage with the content.  @CAPS1, it doesn't make sense to remove a book or other media just because one person doesn't like it. There is still a large portion of the population who might love it, some who might simply like it, and others who are indifferent. We can't focus solely on that one individual; we must consider everyone else. If a person finds a particular item offensive, they should have made a more prudent choice in the first place, and it's their own responsibility.  In conclusion, offensive items should not be removed from the shelves. If someone doesn't like something, they can simply choose not to read or engage with it. Another person might enjoy it. Some people who find things offensive may be viewing the content from the wrong perspective. If we start removing items for being offensive, eventually, everything might be removed. Then, what will we have left to read or listen to?

People learn from books, whether they have happy, sad, or gruesome endings. All types of books can offer valuable lessons to readers. Many believe that history repeats itself, which is why history is taught in schools to prevent the recurrence of past bad events. Similarly, the books on library shelves serve a similar purpose. When reading a book, readers can experience the lives of the characters as if they were living alongside them. Through these experiences, readers can observe the right and wrong actions of the characters without having to directly live through those situations. By the end of the book, readers will gain new perspectives on life and try to avoid making the same mistakes as the characters.  Parents are often concerned about inappropriate language or scenes in books. To be honest, there is foul language and inappropriate behavior in the real world. It is better for children to gradually discover these aspects through reading and some life experiences rather than having it all suddenly presented to them. Censorship on the radio and television is understandable, but when someone wants to improve themselves through reading, they should have the freedom to choose whatever they want to read.  A library is a place of wonderful learning, but censorship restricts that learning. Through reading, people can experience life without facing the consequences of those experiences. All books have something to teach, and they should all have the opportunity to be read and learned from.

In @LOCATION1, many young @CAPS8 are raped, but this isn't shown in movies. We shouldn't let pornography be so accessible. Censoring movies can help kids understand the real nature of sex. I strongly believe in censorship. My parents still ensure that the movies we choose are appropriate. By separating inappropriate materials, parents can have the opportunity to teach their kids, and kids can grow up in a more suitable environment.

Katherine Paterson once wrote, "If I had the right to remove that book from the shelf, the work I abhor, then you also have exactly the same right, and so does everyone else." Having the right to do something is closely related to freedom of speech. It is about believing in the decisions or choices one has made. When reflecting on the issue of censorship in libraries, we all have the opportunity to state our opinions on what should not be included. There may be inappropriate books in libraries that we would not want younger siblings to read. However, we should ask ourselves: Should we deprive our children of the freedom and right to read, listen to, and access updated media and publications when we ourselves had such opportunities? Is it really necessary to censor libraries?  In my view, censoring a library is not necessary. A library is a repository of history. Libraries are organized systematically, with authors' names arranged alphabetically, non - fiction and fiction separated, CDs in one section, movies in another, magazines in a distinct area, and adult books and children's books placed in different sections. Across the world, it is possible that a child may choose an inappropriate book, but this is a common occurrence. Given the abundance of negative influences, peer pressure, violence, and sexual content in the media and the real world, a single book is unlikely to cause significant harm. It would be unfair to deny our children the chance to read and learn from books.  I firmly believe that we should not restrict our children's access to learning. As a child, I loved going to the library. It enhanced my vocabulary and spelling, and I learned many new words. The books I read as a child were not perfect, but I could relate to them. Therefore, we should not censor libraries. Libraries should be a place where children and adults can go for learning, fun, and comfort. Taking this away from our generation is simply unjust.

The presence of offensive books and movies in libraries should not be permitted. If one person finds a book or any item in a library offensive, it is highly likely that others will too. By eliminating such offensive items before they are seen by the public, potential problems can be averted. In today's society, offensive materials are more prevalent in libraries, and people are more easily offended by minor things.  One of the reasons for implementing censorship in libraries is the concern for children. If one has a child, would they want their child to encounter derogatory writings and movies in a library? I would be extremely distressed if my child were exposed to such content. These offensive materials can teach children the wrong values and give them the impression that such behavior is acceptable in the community because it is available in a library. For example, if a library has books or movies about drug use or sexual content, children may look up to these and are more likely to engage in such harmful activities, which can endanger themselves and others.  If the government provides tax funding for libraries, the presence of offensive items on the shelves reflects poorly on the government. When we look to the government for support and guidance, it is disheartening if they show no judgment regarding offensive materials in libraries. This may lead to a sense of panic across the country and cause more problems than necessary. Censoring libraries would be a more straightforward solution.  If libraries were free from negative and offensive literature, there would be more space for materials of greater value. Libraries could stock educational books and movies that actually teach people useful knowledge, rather than leading them to make bad decisions. If someone really wants a particular book, there are many other sources available, not just the library. Moreover, if a library has offensive items, the variety is likely to be limited. It would be wiser to look for the desired materials elsewhere, where a larger selection can be found.  When I visit the library, I go in search of educational books, not those that teach kids inappropriate things like drug - related activities or sexual positions. I strongly oppose the inclusion of such offensive materials in libraries, as it has a negative impact on our society. By implementing censorship in libraries, we can not only alleviate recurring problems in our communities but also potentially eliminate them completely.

There are a multitude of things that can be offensive to different people. If we start removing content from TV, books, and magazines, we would be constantly engaged in the process of censorship. Instead of removing offensive content, a more practical approach is to place graphic or inappropriate materials in the adult section. Censorship is not the answer. We should be more vigilant about our children's activities, which would reduce potential problems.  Adjusting the age limits on movies could be beneficial. If parents watch movies first, they can guide their children on what is appropriate and what is not. Libraries and media should also include more authentic historical content, making them more educational and engaging. This way, we can teach children more valuable knowledge.  Some music, especially rap music, should be subject to a certain degree of censorship. There is a significant amount of rap music that needs to be cleaned up to prevent young children from being exposed to inappropriate lyrics.  There may be better ways to control children's access to inappropriate content. Teachers can play a role in educating children about what is right and wrong. We also need to pay attention to new cartoons on TV, as some of them need to be improved. People have different preferences regarding content, and some may not care about offensive materials at all. Hopefully, in the future, we will find an effective way to manage this issue.

Many people believe that books are useless and should be removed from library shelves. However, I firmly believe that no book is useless, and no book should be removed from any library. All books have value, whether it is in terms of career development or learning new things.  Magazines may not be as helpful as books in many aspects, but they can provide entertainment. Music is not just for listening; it can also help people relax while reading a book. Movies can have a profound impact on individuals. While many people view movies as mere entertainment, they can also offer encouragement and insights into human behavior if one pays close attention.  No book, magazine, music, or movie should be removed from the shelves. These materials are not just for us to read, listen to, or watch; they are there to convey information about things that people may not know. People should re - evaluate how these forms of media can affect their lives. More books, magazines, music, and movies should be added to school libraries and public libraries. The more people engage with these materials, the better they will understand life.  I have noticed that some people go to the library just to relax by reading a book, but they often fail to understand the content. It is a pity that people do not delve deeper into what they are reading. This is why it is important to have more books on the shelves. As Katherine Paterson said, "If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, the work I abhor, then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us." If people truly understood the meaning of this quote, they would have a better appreciation of the value of books in life. We should be grateful for authors like Katherine Paterson, as they help us understand the significance of these wonderful books.

A library is a public space accessible to people of all ages. It offers a wide variety of books for different purposes. There is a cozy area for children to select books and sit down to read. For adults, there are coffee tables, sofas, and other amenities while they read. Libraries should never be required to restrict access to certain materials based on the ages of the visitors.  Censoring a library is not an effective way to keep young children away from offensive materials. When children are in a library, they should go to the appropriate sections for their age group and be supervised. In general, most children are not attracted to books without many pictures or colors. Since libraries are public places for all ages, even though there are bookstores that sell adult - only books, movies, and magazines, these items should not be removed from libraries. Equal rights should be upheld in libraries.  The world is full of offensive things. When children are outside the library, whether at home or in public places, they may encounter the same offensive content as they would in a library book. Removing certain books, movies, and magazines from libraries will not solve the problem. I believe that if parents teach their children the difference between right and wrong, there is no issue with children being in a library that has adult materials.  If I owned a library, I would not mind having a selection of books that are appropriate to a certain extent. I have visited many libraries and have seen some content that I thought was inappropriate, but often I was not in the right section or was not doing what I was supposed to do. This issue does not bother me, and I do not think certain books should be removed just because children are in the library. Libraries should remain a place that caters to the diverse needs of all age groups.

Censorship restricts our freedom, much like someone telling us what we can and cannot do. Recently, I and my friends wanted to watch a newly - released movie, but due to censorship, we were not old enough to see it without our parents. This kind of situation isn't ideal. Censorship violates our freedom to be different. It limits our access to music, movies, and books based on age. It's like a modern - day authority figure dictating our actions, clothing, and speech. History has shown that such an approach fails. Just like the victims of a certain ideology in the past, who were punished for being different, censorship classifies people and restricts their choices. The world is diverse because of different people. We should not let censorship make everyone the same.

People hold diverse views on literary works, including books, magazines, movies, and music. If libraries were to remove these from their shelves, they would lose business, alienate children, and undermine the purpose of having such materials. By removing older works that might offend younger generations, libraries risk losing customers who appreciate such content. These older works, which may contain elements that seem harmful but are actually meant to show how life was in the past, like the era of slavery, serve an important educational function. For children using the library, removing such literature would give them a false sense that things have always been as they currently see. As they grow older, they may struggle to believe in the changes that have occurred over time because they lack the early exposure. Such literary works are written to educate, not to harm. Libraries should keep these pieces on their shelves to teach the younger generation about the world's history and their ancestors' lives.

I firmly believe that there should be censorship in libraries. Children should not have unrestricted access to certain books if they are inappropriate for their age. This can prevent people from getting into trouble and reading the wrong content. There are already stores where age - restricted items are sold. In libraries, which are public spaces, if a material is suitable only for a certain age group, it should be subject to censorship. When children know there are off - limits materials, they may try to access them secretly. Censorship can prevent this. Censorship also ensures that everyone is treated equally and no one feels left out. There are bookstores and online platforms where age - restricted purchases can be made with a credit card. Similarly, libraries should implement censorship. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is necessary to protect the appropriate audience and maintain a proper environment.

The library is a place where people can freely read according to their interests, either for enjoyment or information - seeking. Sometimes, the materials available may offend others, but due to freedom of speech, there's little we can do. For example, there may be books or magazines about homosexuality. While some may oppose their presence, others may find them valuable. Another debated topic is books about sex or drugs. Parents may be concerned about their children reading such books, but these can also show the negative impacts of these behaviors. I personally like reading such books as they illustrate how these things can ruin lives. However, I oppose materials related to racism, such as books, magazines, music, and movies. I also find movies depicting bullying of people with disabilities inappropriate. Some people write offensive materials, either unknowingly or deliberately. Since everyone has the right to free speech, we have to tolerate it. If there are inappropriate materials in the library that we don't like or don't want our children to see, we can simply avoid them.

I believe that materials with racist content or unsightly images should be removed from library shelves. However, this raises the issue of racism in classic books. For instance, "To Kill a Mockingbird" uses a derogatory term for African - Americans, which was common when the book was published but is unacceptable today. Generally, most of the books I've read are not overly offensive. There are magazines like "Playboy" and "Maxim" that are offensive to women, but there are age - related purchase laws. During the Nazi era in Germany, many books were banned for religious or ideological reasons. Also, some of Mark Twain's works were briefly banned for using the same derogatory term, but it was part of the common language at that time. As a Catholic, there is a list of forbidden books, though I'm unaware of their content. Regarding music, I think music advocating violence against police or promoting racism, like that of the Aryan Brotherhood, should be banned. I don't think movies should be banned for violence, but pornographic movies should be prohibited, and libraries already have such a policy. I agree with Katherine Paterson that if we start banning based on personal offense, there will be no books left on the shelves. My view of what is offensive is relatively relaxed compared to others.

Have you ever encountered a book you thought was great, yet knew it might offend someone you know? In my view, materials that could be offensive in libraries should not be removed from the shelves. People should have the freedom to choose their own books, and no one has the right to dictate what others should read. My suggestion is that such materials be placed in a designated "adult material" section, including books, music, movies, etc.  I once couldn't borrow a movie called @CAPS2 @PERSON1 because of my age. It was just an action - adventure movie, and I found it very unfair that my youth prevented me from checking it out. This experience led me to believe that materials that might offend should not be removed.  Another reason is that people have diverse interests. No two individuals have the exact same preferences all the time. Removing materials only satisfies one person while depriving many of something they might be interested in. I understand that some people may be uncomfortable with offensive materials due to their past experiences. However, I think everyone can choose the materials they like and leave the rest for others.  In conclusion, I firmly believe that materials that may offend certain people should remain available. What might be offensive to one person could be highly interesting to another. As the saying from Ebony magazine goes, "Another person's junk might be someone else's treasure," which perfectly sums up this situation.

I firmly believe that materials of this kind should not be removed from the shelves. Instead, they should be rated. This is a free country, and taking away such materials would infringe on people's freedom of speech. Countless individuals have fought for this fundamental right in the past.  If we rate the materials that are released, they are less likely to end up in the wrong hands. For example, if @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3 had been removed from the market when it first came out because it contains violence, profanity, and guns, the company would have suffered significant financial losses. While it may be inappropriate for children, it is the responsibility of parents to be more discerning when purchasing such items for their children.  The creators should not be held accountable for how people react to the materials they produce. Buyers need to be more responsible and ensure proper supervision. The old saying "Everything isn't made for everybody" is very true. People have different tastes, and what is acceptable to one person may not be to another.  Certain books are inappropriate for young children as they contain sexual content and discuss topics that children should not be thinking about at that age. When children read such books, they may start to have inappropriate thoughts. It is the parents' responsibility to monitor what their children read, not the author's. The author may be writing for an older audience and exercising their freedom of speech.  Similarly, if parents find music inappropriate for their children, they should monitor their children's listening habits. Music can evoke different moods in people. Magazines also vary in their suitability, and adult magazines with certain imagery should be kept out of reach of children. The fault lies with the buyers who leave such materials accessible to children, not the creators who are simply trying to make a living by producing what people like.

We've all come across a book that we wish had never been written. As Katherine Paterson, an author, once said, "All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us."  I think there should be a proper mechanism for dealing with such materials. For instance, if we can gather at least @NUM1 people to sign a petition, the book could be removed. This principle applies to music, movies, magazines, and even bibles in libraries.  I'm not advocating for a law that restricts access to something just because one person dislikes it. However, if a large number of the public agrees that a particular item should not be available, it might be best to remove it. We all worry about our children and constantly monitor them to ensure they don't access inappropriate things. The same concern applies to books, movies, music, magazines, and for some, even bibles.  It's true that when a child tries to check out an "inappropriate" book at a library, the checkout counter usually denies the request. But this doesn't prevent the child from reading the book in the library. Moreover, considering today's high crime rates, it's quite possible that a child could steal a book, magazine, or film.  To prevent such issues, libraries could have an adult section, not just for "@CAPS1" rated materials but for all content that is considered unsuitable for children. Additionally, we should have the option to petition to remove books that we believe are inappropriate for our children. This is my opinion on library censorship, and I hope it resonates with others.

There's no need to be offended when visiting a library. Libraries are places where people can access what they like. Everyone has their own preferences, and you don't have to look at materials you don't like.  Books, movies, music, and magazines are created for people to consume. People have the right to choose what they want, and libraries are the perfect place to fulfill those choices. Others should not be offended by the preferences of others.  Most libraries are divided into sections for children, young adults, and adults. If you think a particular material doesn't belong in a certain section, you can request it to be moved to another. However, you shouldn't have a material removed just because you find it offensive. This is unfair to those who might enjoy it.  If you're offended by a material in a library section, it's acceptable to have it moved. Remember, someone else might like it. Libraries are for everyone, and we should respect each other's tastes. In conclusion, we should not be offended by what others like in a library.

Libraries are inclusive spaces that cater to people of all ages, from young children to the elderly. When we visit a library, we expect to find a wide range of books to meet our personal interests and research needs. However, some libraries are considering removing this diversity.  Libraries house books on almost every subject to accommodate the individual differences of their patrons. For example, a person from an extremist religious group may visit the library to read about their religion. A strict @CAPS1 individual might be offended if they come across a book on that extreme religion, and the reverse could also be true. Due to our diverse beliefs and customs, we all have different views on literature.  Most libraries are large enough to be divided into sections such as young adult, mature adult, children, non - fiction, fiction, and science fiction. If a child wanders into the mature adult section and reads a book beyond their maturity level, it is the child's responsibility. Mature readers should not be penalized by having all adult - oriented books removed because a child didn't stay in their designated area.  Different cultural beliefs lead to different views on everyday things. A book that one reader strongly disagrees with may be highly recommended by another. One book can have a completely different meaning to different people. While it would be concerning if books about sex were placed next to children's books, this is not the case in most libraries. Libraries could even establish a restricted section to warn readers about the content of the books in that area.  Books in libraries are written for a wide variety of people. Factors such as age, gender, religion, maturity, race, and political beliefs all influence how we respond to a book. Whether a book appeals to us depends on our beliefs, values, and customs. So, why should a library remove books that only a certain percentage of people disagree with? Removing such books could upset those who like them and may even be relevant to their daily lives.  A library is a repository of knowledge, filled with facts, beliefs, theories, and opinions. Removing access to certain books would be a violation of the author's freedom of speech. Just because a subject is controversial or mature doesn't mean people should be denied the right to read about it. If our reading choices are limited by someone else's decisions, where is our freedom?  In conclusion, a library is a place for everyone. It should have a wide range of books for all types of people. The library's layout can be arranged to ensure that young children don't encounter inappropriate books near their reading area. Removing books on controversial subjects is unfair to those who want to read them. A library should be a balanced space where people can access any knowledge they desire.

I firmly believe that every individual has the right to express their own opinions on life. Censoring someone's books, music, or movies due to their perceived inappropriateness is akin to silencing a distinct opinion. If we suppress an author and their story or song, we lose the opportunity to view life from another person's perspective.  In the @ORGANIZATION1, we possess the freedoms of speech and press. These amendments enable individuals to voice their opinions without fear of being immediately dismissed. However, despite these amendments, there are still restrictions on what can be published. For instance, if we were to discover a diary written by @PERSON1, should we access his innermost thoughts? Or should we deem it too dark and depressing for the general public? Just because his ideas are different does not mean we should conceal them. On the contrary, we should share them to educate people about the diverse ways of viewing life.  I am of the opinion that, with the author's permission, anyone's ideas should be accessible for others to read and interpret in their own way. If someone wishes to learn about how to commit murder in a @CAPS1, they should be allowed to do so. The @CAPS1 is becoming obsolete as we enter the technology era, and there is little that can be found in a @CAPS1 that cannot be sourced online.  Although the @CAPS1 is a government - run institution, many people will seek alternative means to access censored media. It is true that allowing 'censored' material in a @CAPS1 could expose children to inappropriate content. However, similar to the internet, we can implement blocking mechanisms to protect children.  All voices, regardless of whether they are racist, sexist, biased, or seemingly insane, should be heard. These can offer insights into the perspectives and causes behind hate and war. If we can learn from different mindsets through books, music, and movies, then such access should be permitted. Nothing should be blocked from the public, as everyone has the right to express their opinions in their own way.

I advocate for keeping all books in the library. If we start removing books, eventually, there will be none left. The only exception might be rated @CAPS2 movies, which could potentially be removed. However, just because a book might be offensive to one person does not mean it should be removed from the library. For example, an older woman might be offended by a magazine featuring a teenage girl taking drugs or being half - naked, while a teenager sitting beside her might enjoy such gossip.  Removing books would lead to a lack of variety in the library, leaving only one genre. A better approach would be to separate the books. Offensive books could be placed at the back, and children's books should be kept away from mystery and horror books.  Consider a student who goes to the library to work on a history report about slavery. If all books on slavery have been removed because someone thought they were offensive to African - Americans, the student will be at a loss.  I understand the reasons for removing some books due to sexual content, as children should not be exposed to such material. Similarly, books with religious content that might be considered inappropriate, like those about worshiping the devil, are sometimes removed.  The situation with movies is also complex. I wouldn't want my daughter to pick up a movie with sex scenes or drug content. But just because I want such movies removed doesn't mean everyone does. Removing all offensive movies would spell the end of the library's movie business.  In conclusion, no one should have the power to decide what should or should not be in the library. There should be a wide variety of materials to prevent people from getting bored with the same books over and over again. KEEP @CAPS1 ON THE SHELF.

Author Katherine Paterson believed that if a book was not suitable for her children, it should be removed from library shelves. If you found a book in your public library offensive, would you want it removed? Personally, I would not. I believe that such a book could offer valuable learning experiences for others. In this essay, I will share my personal experience to explain why I disagree with Katherine Paterson.  In sixth grade, we learned how to find books in a public library using a specific system. As an assignment, we had to locate certain books in our school library. One of the books was the @CAPS1 @CAPS2. I found it easily because I knew its location and appearance. However, there was a classmate who had never seen a @CAPS2 before. After helping her find the book, she asked, '@CAPS5 is this book so important to people? I don't understand it.' I did my best to explain the life of @CAPS6 and why it was important to me. Soon, she became interested in learning more.  In some states, it is illegal to have a @CAPS2 in school due to various beliefs or non - beliefs. If the library did not have the @CAPS2 on its shelves, that girl would never have had the opportunity to learn something that is now important to her. A book may be offensive to some, but it can also change a person's life. Unfortunately, like Katherine Paterson, many others believe that certain books should be removed from libraries. But what if that one book that could change a person's life is not available in the library?

I think a library should house any kind of book with diverse content. After all, a library is a place where people go to access information. If you don't want your children to read, watch, or listen to certain materials, you can restrict their access until they are old enough and mature enough to handle it. However, no book should be removed just because it offends someone, is too gory, or contains curse words.  Not everyone is offended by the same things. If you find a book or movie offensive, you can simply choose not to engage with it. But this does not mean it should be removed from the library. Libraries serve the entire community, not just one individual. There may be others who want to read or watch the very material that some find offensive.  This is my stance on the censorship of books, movies, music, magazines, etc. A library is bound to have a large amount of diverse material. If you come across something offensive, be mature about it, put it back, and find something else to read, watch, or listen to.

The question of whether certain materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines, should be removed from library shelves if they are considered offensive is a complex one. Many people get upset when they encounter inappropriate materials in a library. Inappropriate materials typically include pictures and words that can offend people. Song lyrics can be offensive, especially when they talk about girls disrespectfully, which can upset both girls and other listeners. Pictures can also be offensive in terms of sex, race, and violence.  I believe that if a book, music, movie, or magazine upsets you, you should avoid that section or that particular material. In a library, kids usually stay in the children's section, and adults should be mature enough to ignore what bothers them. I have visited libraries several times in my life, and when I search for what I need, I simply ignore offensive or upsetting materials.  In conclusion, my answer to the question of whether offensive materials should be removed from library shelves is no. People should be mature enough to stay away from offensive materials in the library and not let them affect them.

Who can determine what is appropriate for whom? Who has the right to judge right and wrong for others? As with most things, it depends on one's perspective. Those who are overly protected must learn the truth one day. If children learn early, such as not to insert forks into electrical outlets, they will be less curious as they grow older. Over - protection is not always beneficial, and the censorship of what we read, watch, or listen to is absurd and disrespectful to authors.  In the matter of censorship, I find it utterly pointless. Censorship does not prevent children from learning; instead, it only makes them more curious and more likely to hide things from their parents. They may feel unable to ask questions or be honest with their parents. This causes children to act behind their parents' backs, and when in trouble, they may not consider their parents as the first place to seek help.  I firmly believe that libraries should not censor anything. It is an alteration of an author's work. Imagine how it would feel if you had written a piece, had it published, and then someone in the library decided to censor parts of it or restrict certain people from reading it. I contend that censorship should be illegal, not required.  Sheltering children from the real world prevents them from maturing and discovering reality. The idea of presenting a world free of evil or hiding the bad from children often leads them to rebel or leaves them ill - prepared for the future. It is better to help and teach children about the world rather than telling them everything is perfect and only "bad people" use certain language.  In conclusion, censorship is unjust, unfair, and truly wrong. It is not the profanity or violence that will one day be part of their lives that is the problem. In the real world, we cannot live with the mindset that everything is perfect or controlled. I believe censorship is merely a means of controlling minds through upbringing.

I believe it is unnecessary to remove items from shelves for offensive reasons, and I have three main reasons for this view. Firstly, the item could be a book, movie, or magazine that someone intends to read. Removing it will disappoint the customer. People visit libraries to find materials that interest them for entertainment. Libraries should offer a wide variety of literature for all types of people because everyone has different tastes. Every time an item is removed from the shelf, there will be an unsatisfied customer.  Secondly, there are numerous solutions to try before removing an item. Libraries usually have some form of organization. To avoid offending anyone, items should be categorized and placed in separate sections. This approach can prevent people from encountering offensive content. If this does not work, librarians could post a sign at the front door indicating the types of materials inside so that everyone is aware before entering.  Lastly, customers must accept some decisions made by a business. A business should generally meet customers' needs and wants, but not when a customer tries to run the business as if it were their own. If a library selects certain items based on what it knows its readers like, others should not interfere. If I owned a library, I would be annoyed if a customer removed a book from the shelf as it would disrupt my business operations.  In conclusion, I believe it is unnecessary to remove items from shelves for three reasons. Firstly, it could be an item someone plans to read. Secondly, there are many solutions to try before removal. Thirdly, customers need to accept business decisions. I have fully expressed my opinion. Although some may disagree with me, I stand by my view. If items were removed for offensive reasons, there would likely be very few books left for anyone.

I am writing to this newspaper company to share my views on why certain books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. I will draw on my own experiences and readings to present a convincing argument and reflect my stance on library censorship.  I think no book should be removed from library shelves simply because of people's thoughts on religion, race, or other potentially offensive topics. For example, regarding the topic of same - sex marriage, everyone's opinions should be respected. However, if the language used in a book is harsh and intended to be harmful, then it should be removed.  Another aspect is children taking books off shelves. Parents should accompany their children in the children's section and teach them what they should not do, such as taking down inappropriate items. In general, if a book uses negative words to harm others' feelings, it should be removed.  This letter is to convey my opinion on what should or should not be in a library. I have used examples and common sense to illustrate my point of view. I hope my arguments have convinced you about whether to remove a book from the shelf.  Sincerely, [ORGANIZATION1]

Are there books that are universally evil and should never be read? Is the distinction between good and bad no longer a matter of the readers' personal opinions? The answer is no. Censorship is a harmful practice that masquerades as a benefit. The right to read certain books should not be determined by a conservative minority because everyone has their own viewpoints. Every book has something we can learn from, and it is wrong to deprive people of that opportunity. Freedom of speech also plays a crucial role here, allowing authors' voices to be heard without interference from those who would control what we read.  Libraries have multiple sections for a reason. They need to cater to the diverse tastes of the public, regardless of what others may find offensive. If people were to go through the library and remove every book they disliked, there would be little left. If another person with different tastes did the same, the library would be empty. It is much better to leave all the books available so that everyone can find something to enjoy. In fact, there are likely people who share the author's opinions on almost any topic, so authors should be allowed to express them.  In terms of knowledge, what is offensive to one person may be exactly what another person wants or needs to read, whether for entertainment or educational purposes. We can learn a great deal about psychology and human nature from almost any piece of writing. A restricted section might be appropriate if there is a concern about corrupting innocent minds, but complete censorship is never necessary.  Finally, there is an amendment in the [CAPS1] of [CAPS2] that prohibits censorship. It is unconstitutional to restrict any form of expressive speech, including books, movies, music, and magazines. Banning an author's books is one of the most restrictive actions. The freedom of expression is what differentiates our country from a totalitarian regime. If we start restricting this freedom, what kind of country will we become?  In conclusion, censorship is a harmful practice that should be avoided. People have diverse opinions, all forms of media can be educational, and our freedom should not be restricted. Censorship itself is what should be removed from the "shelves" of our society.

Dear [CAPS1], It's hard to draw a line on what kids should or should not see in the world. Should we shelter kids to make them behave better, or should we make them street - smart and aware of what's going on?  I think we can decide what we want our kids to do and say, but we don't have full control over them. I believe kids are being over - sheltered these days. With the rise of new technology, kids are growing up with computers, laptops, and gaming systems. They don't know what it's like to play outside. The world has so much to offer, but we often ignore it because of the new technological advances.  It's important for kids to be both book - smart and street - smart. If they focus too much on one thing, they'll end up lacking in the other. I'm confident that good grades will follow when they have a balanced approach.  Kids are over - sheltered because when they see something we don't want them to see, we restrict them. But who's to say they won't encounter the same thing in the real world when we're not around? That's why it's crucial to teach kids about the world and not keep them in the dark.  We're living in a new age where computers and laptops are the most commonly used devices. It's difficult for kids to understand the reality of life because so much is done online. Since everything is virtual, it's hard for them to grasp the realness of life.  As we get older, we rely more on information from the web. Kids may not learn practical skills like fixing cars or starting a lawnmower.  I think books should not be removed from the shelves. As time passes, kids are losing touch with reality more and more. It's very important what kids learn about everyday life because they are our future. If they have no idea what's going on in the world, it's a scary thought. We need to teach them as much as we can and hope they become the best versions of themselves.  Thank you for your [CAPS3]. Deven

Censorship has been a long - standing issue in various forms of art. In many cases, censorship targets materials that are generally considered inappropriate for creation and consumption. However, there are also more serious instances where censors decide that certain content is unsuitable for a particular audience or an entire country. It begs the question: what gives a select few the right to ban imaginative creations, even those that might be somewhat lewd?  Censorship is a tool that many governments use to achieve a variety of goals, claiming to ensure the “safety” of people's minds and bodies. Some well - known examples of this oppressive control tactic come from countries such as @CAPS1, @CAPS2, @LOCATION3, @LOCATION4R, @CAPS3, @LOCATION5, and @LOCATION2. In these places, materials deemed potentially harmful to the @ORGANIZATION2 are strictly monitored and often destroyed.  A notable example occurred in @LOCATION3, where the @CAPS4 would collect large quantities of books from the public and burn them in massive rallies. The people, under the influence of the @CAPS5 leadership, often voluntarily surrendered their books without resistance and, in some cases, even participated in the book - burning.  In @LOCATION5, internet censorship still exists. In @DATE1, the popular search engine @ORGANIZATION3 attempted to enter the country but quickly got into a dispute with the @ORGANIZATION2 over the censorship of certain materials. After a few months of argument, the company briefly removed all bans, much to the dissatisfaction of the @ORGANIZATION2. During that period, it was reported that some of the main search topics were related to social reformers and religions other than the one sanctioned by the @ORGANIZATION2.  @LOCATION2 takes censorship to an extreme. Its @ORGANIZATION2 restricts and polices all technology in the country, and the common people live in a so - called “@CAPS6 @CAPS7 @CAPS8”.  In our home country, @LOCATION1, we are promised rights to protect our freedom as citizens, including freedom of speech and press. Censoring our libraries would restrict these freedoms. If we don't stand up for our rights, who will? We are a @ORGANIZATION2 “for the people, by the people”. Why should we allow the censorship of our intellectual creations in a place meant to provide access to knowledge for the less fortunate? If we tolerate such blatant restrictions on our freedoms, we don't deserve them in the first place. Our country was founded and almost torn apart by those who fought for their freedoms. As descendants of these people, we should not squander what our forefathers earned through hard - fought battles.  The censors often pose the question “Is it really better off this way?” They point out that for every great work of art, there are more deviant and inappropriate ones. Pornography is their most common example, arguing that without restrictions, children accessing library resources and the internet would be exposed. While it's a reasonable concern, it's the responsibility of parents or guardians. Simply dropping a child off at the library and hoping they find something suitable is not enough. Parents should accompany their children on the journey of finding what they want.  As author Katherine Paterson said, “All of us can think of a book that we hope none or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf—that work I abhor—then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.”  Censorship has been around for a long time and is likely to persist in any functioning @ORGANIZATION2. This is an unfortunate inevitability. However, the extent of censorship in our daily lives depends on how much we are willing to fight for our freedom.

Almost everyone in the world reads. Many people read on a daily basis, perhaps without even realizing it. Reading is an integral part of life. If you can't read, you're less likely to be successful. Even having basic reading skills is crucial; while knowing just a few simple words might be sufficient in some cases, people definitely need to be able to read.  I firmly believe that nothing should be removed from the shelves. Why would anyone take books off the shelves? If someone finds a book offensive, they can simply choose not to read it. Just because a book offends one person doesn't mean others won't find it interesting. If we start removing books because they offend someone, we have no idea how many books will remain. People can be offended very easily, and almost every book can potentially offend someone.  The same goes for movies. Movies can be just as offensive as books, and I think they might even be more likely to offend.  In conclusion, books, movies, and similar media should not be removed from the shelves just because they offend someone. Many people are too easily offended. One person might love a book while another hates it. Just because you dislike a book doesn't mean it should be taken off the shelves.

Censorship is a significant global issue today. One camp argues that offensive materials are harmful to society and should not be tolerated. The other side contends that freedom of speech is a universal right encompassing all forms of human expression. The matter is further complicated by the question of what is appropriate for children. Are there materials suitable for adults but not for kids? These questions have troubled humanity for centuries, and there is no straightforward solution.  Currently, many view censorship negatively. However, the concept of censorship itself is not inherently bad. Problems arise when those in power abuse it by censoring materials that should not be restricted. For example, many countries restrict the sale and ownership of “@PERSON2,” a book written by @PERSON1 as a mission - statement for @LOCATION1. Although the ideas in the book are offensive, it should not be censored. People have the right to read and form their own opinions on @PERSON1's teachings; it's not the government's role to make that decision for them. While dictatorship and mass - murder are crimes, reading about them is not.  There are few materials that should be rightfully censored from adult access. If an adult can understand what they're reading and form an informed opinion, no one has the right to stop them from expanding their knowledge or creating similar works. But the situation changes when considering children. Adults' choices to view pornography or read about extreme violence are their own business. However, these concepts are inappropriate for children, and responsible parents wouldn't want their kids exposed to such content. Children need a gradual and gentle introduction to these ideas to fully understand them. Thus, careful censorship is necessary for their healthy development.  In libraries, very few materials should be banned. Since libraries are places of learning, limiting the information they offer is unjust. However, this doesn't mean there should be no restrictions. Many libraries have a children's section with age - appropriate materials. It's the parents' responsibility to ensure their children stay in this section. When parents believe their child is ready, they can take them to the adult section. This system allows parents to protect their children without depriving adults of access to uncensored materials. Some may argue that unsupervised children could access inappropriate content, but this is a parental issue, not the library's. It's better for a few children to see something inappropriate than for all adults to read censored material.  In conclusion, censorship has its place in society but must be used with great care. When the aim is to protect people, especially children, from harmful content, it can be used sparingly. However, when those in power use it to suppress ideas they oppose, it becomes a form of oppression. Above all, people should be free to educate themselves, form their own opinions, and express themselves. If someone dislikes a piece of material, they can ignore it but should never try to remove it from others' access.

Books can have a profound impact on readers, and sometimes this impact isn't appropriate. Books deemed inappropriate for children or teenagers should be reconsidered for removal from shelves accessible to them. I believe children shouldn't be exposed to inappropriate material until they are old enough and mature enough to understand it.  Books aren't the only concern; movies, music, magazines, and other media can also give children and teenagers wrong ideas. Inappropriate media and information should not be accessible to those who aren't ready or mature enough to handle it.  Children who read inappropriate books or watch inappropriate media can change their behavior. I've seen many movies that are extremely inappropriate for young children. Since children don't have the same level of understanding as adults, they may misinterpret what they see and form wrong ideas. Inappropriate books and media can have a negative impact on a child's childhood.  Children and teenagers need to be mature enough to be exposed to all books, movies, and magazines. If all age groups had access to higher - rated content, it wouldn't be responsible on the part of libraries or those providing the media. Society would be more difficult to control with such unrestricted access. Parents also wouldn't appreciate their children being exposed to content they deem inappropriate.  Many children do foolish things they've seen in movies or read in books, thinking it's cool or something to try. We already have issues with pre - teens and teenagers because they're exposed to inappropriate content at a young age, which affects their actions. I've witnessed or heard of many actions that are likely related to a book or movie and might not have occurred without that exposure.  In conclusion, children simply aren't ready or mature enough to be exposed to all books, movies, and magazines. Exposing them to such content would cause numerous problems for many people, and it's essential to ensure appropriate age - based access to media.

Censorship has become a prominent issue regarding books, music, and movies. These forms of media are being censored to protect young kids, but what about adults? Removing books, music, and movies from library shelves due to censorship is unfair to adults.  Books are now being rewritten to remove offensive language. “To @CAPS1 A @CAPS2” is a prime example. Altering the offensive language in this book would ruin its essence, as it mainly depicts the racism faced by African - Americans. If libraries have censored books, they should have a separate shelf for them so that adults can still read them.  Music is also affected by censorship. Offensive language is being removed from songs, and some stores won't sell uncensored CDs. Some adults prefer the original, uncensored versions. Libraries should carry both explicit and clean versions of CDs to provide options for both kids and adults.  Movies are subject to censorship as well. They are rated @CAPS3 (suitable for all ages), @NUM1 (suitable for children @NUM2 and older), and @CAPS4 (suitable for people @NUM3 and older). These ratings are useful guidelines, but parents should make the final decision on whether their child can watch a particular movie. Libraries should have a wide range of movies on their shelves. A twelve - year - old should be able to watch a @NUM1 or @CAPS4 movie with parental consent.  In conclusion, censorship has its place, but it shouldn't be taken to extremes. Adults should be able to access censored books in libraries, and children should be allowed to watch age - restricted movies with parental approval. This way, both adults' rights and children's protection can be balanced.

Censorship of adult shows is a misguided practice. While it is understandable to implement censorship on children's shows, applying it to good movies and songs is unjustifiable. Freedom of speech should not be compromised in this way. In conclusion, censorship on adult shows undermines the principle of free expression and should be re - evaluated.

To the Newspaper: There should be censorship in libraries, but access to certain books should be age - restricted. Some people visit libraries precisely because of censorship. Nowadays, censorship can encourage children and students to pick up books. If parents believe that censored books are harmless to their children, it is acceptable. Libraries could create a section for readers @NUM1 and older, accessible only with @CAPS2, to address the age issue. However, removing censorship entirely would likely lead to financial losses for libraries and could cause them to go out of business. Therefore, libraries should maintain censorship. The question remains: do we really want to remove censorship from libraries?

Censorship in public libraries is a grave error. Let's reflect on high school and the immersive experiences of classic literature, such as roaming under the opera house with the phantom, fighting for @PERSON2's freedom with @PERSON1, or getting into scrapes in @LOCATION1 with @CAPS1. These literary works draw us into their worlds and offer a wealth of sensations. It's unjust to miss out on such literary treasures because the author is a @CAPS2, uses occasional profanity, or is a woman. History has shown the perils of censorship. During the @CAPS3, countless @CAPS4 people, homosexuals, and other minorities were killed due to religious differences, and the @ORGANIZATION1 burned millions of books by @CAPS4 authors. This act of censorship was morally wrong. Censoring books, movies, magazines, or songs for a curse word, a bit of skin, or a controversial idea is often unnecessary. Sometimes, these elements are crucial for emphasis. Giving up beautiful compositions due to controversy or hiding children from materials that can help them form their own opinions is unacceptable. I firmly oppose censorship and will continue to fight against it until it no longer silences great works. Censorship in public libraries is an unjust practice that must be eradicated.

Public libraries are a treasure trove of excellent books, offering a wide variety of types. You can find books on any topic, whether it's to obtain facts or learn new skills. Just because a book presents an opinion doesn't mean it should be removed from the shelves, as everyone perceives things differently. Reading can be highly beneficial, allowing you to learn a great deal. Personally, I'm not fond of reading and don't learn much from it. I'm more of a hands - on person, and words often go in one ear and out the other. It's difficult for me to focus when reading, listening, or writing simultaneously. Despite my personal struggle, the value of diverse books in libraries should not be underestimated, and they should remain accessible to all.

Libraries should not remove certain types of books from their shelves. Just because some individuals find a book offensive does not mean it should be taken off. If you don't like a book, simply don't choose it; others may enjoy it as it is for entertainment. When searching for a book, if one seems inappropriate, just move on. There are numerous books in the library, so find an alternative rather than fixating on a single one. If there is a so - called "bad" book, go to a different section. There will always be more good books available. If other people like a book, the library should not remove it. A book that may be offensive to some could be appealing to others, and some people visit libraries specifically for such books. It might just be that a person is in the wrong section. A seemingly unappealing book could actually be interesting if given a chance. The purpose of books in the library is for entertainment, which is why there are multiple sections and selections. For example, if an adult believes a kids' book gives the wrong idea, they don't have to choose it for their child, but another parent might think it's suitable. Librarians should not remove books based on one person's opinion. Instead, people should remember that others may like the book and that books are there for readers' entertainment. In conclusion, libraries should keep a diverse collection of books on their shelves for all patrons to access.

I would say no. Since all that belongs to history, for instance, if there was a KKK - related matter or anything similar. Suppose there was a waiting period but information was required for it. That information would include notes, dates, and other details. This shows that historical context and related information are significant and should be considered.

I believe in censorship, but I think it's not as serious an issue as it's often made out to be. It's the parents' responsibility to block materials they consider inappropriate for their children. If the content is truly bad, parents have the right to ensure their kids don't access it. In my view, when it comes to restricting materials like books, music, movies, and magazines, some content isn't suitable for younger people unless they have parental approval. I think that if people find something offensive, they may want to get rid of it. If the content is seriously wrong, it should be censored. However, if it's a minor issue like a single word in a book, people should be more understanding and try to look past it or find an alternative approach. If you don't like something, don't read or listen to it, and keep your kids away from it. I've never read a book that was offensive or disturbing. I've come across books I didn't like, but I've never encountered something so bad that I'd want to ban it for everyone. If something is to be censored, it should be for a valid reason, not because of personal dislike or a disagreement with an idea. It should be due to content that's offensive to an entire race or too graphic for young people. In my opinion, this is the proper way to view censorship. When I have kids, I'll decide whether to block certain materials, and that's how it should be.

If I were given the opportunity to decide whether offensive books at local libraries should be removed from the shelves, I don't think either removing them or leaving them as they are is entirely correct. I would definitely recommend holding a vote to determine what to do with these books. A vote is reasonable because people have diverse beliefs, and some may be offended by certain content. I would select at least ten individuals with different religions, backgrounds, etc., and have them vote on the fate of the offensive books. People have different beliefs, so it's difficult to satisfy everyone. That's why a vote with a diverse group of people would be effective for most. As my mom said, 'you will never make everyone happy.' There are so many things in society that can offend people, and what deeply offends one person may not affect another at all. This is the main reason why voting is challenging, as there's a wide range of people in the world. One should also consider how many times the book has been checked out previously, as it's possible that none of the voters share the same opinion as those who have borrowed the book. If the book is voted to stay in the library, it should be properly labeled. Since it may be offensive to some, labeling it can prevent someone, like a child, who is unaware, from accidentally coming across it. Voting is a common and effective practice in our society. It's not only used in elections but can also be applied in this situation. Voting is always important, and people should recognize its value. I believe voting could solve many problems in the world.

Nowadays, a few negative comments rarely influence what people read. That's the trend in the current era. No one wants to read a boring article unless it's intended to be so. I'll share my opinions on whether certain materials like books, music, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they're considered offensive. I base my opinions on my observations, experiences, and reading some so - called offensive articles. In my view, no one's work should be removed from the shelves because I'm sure they put a lot of effort into it to get it published. There's no valid reason to take it off. If my work was removed, I'd be shocked and upset. It can hurt people emotionally. However, there are times when we don't want certain content to be seen because it's too embarrassing. For example, if an athlete who was suspended for violations is interviewed in an article and is cursing and out of control, I'd put that article away to avoid public exposure. Everyone knows that some movies and music with explicit content or lyrics can't be publicly displayed. You have to request them, and someone will retrieve them from the back. Only G - rated movies should be on the shelves, while movies rated [rating] and above, as well as similar music, should be behind the counter. I'm sure this is clear to the audience. Now that I've shared my views on censorship in libraries, what are your thoughts on this topic after reading this persuasive essay? You've read my thoughts based on experience, observations, and common sense. If you had to write an essay on library censorship, how would you approach it?

Materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines are for people's enjoyment. Adults and children can gain a lot of information from library reading materials. Books offer an alternative way to learn new things, rather than just in a classroom. If the reading materials are already in the library, they shouldn't be removed. People who visit the library must be responsible. Adults and young adults should know what is appropriate to read and what isn't. No one has the right to remove a book from the shelf just because they find it offensive. There are millions of books in the world that some people find offensive. There's no such thing as a perfect book that doesn't bother anyone. Every book that's published today has the right to be read. There are people out there looking for specific books, magazines, movies, and music. These materials can help solve problems, make the right decisions, and guide people in the right direction. [Religious book] is a source of understanding and knowledge. However, there are many people who think we shouldn't read it or even pick it up. But as [Religious book] says, we have free will. We have the freedom to choose the books we want to read. Books provide an additional way for people to learn new things, and library materials are a great source of information for both adults and kids. In conclusion, these materials should be accessible for people's enjoyment and learning.

Should offensive material be censored? No, censoring books, music, movies, magazines, and other forms of media infringes upon the freedom of American citizens. Consider this: would the words 'hell' or 'damned' be removed from the Bible because they are considered offensive? I think not, as these words contribute to the power of the book. Books that are considered offensive offer insights into history and culture. Removing them would limit education, so they should not be censored.  A well - known and controversial case of censorship is the popular book '@ORGANIZATION1 @ORGANIZATION1'. The book tells the story of a young white boy running away with an older black man, and the word 'nigger' is used frequently. Many people were offended by this word, so a new version was republished, replacing 'nigger' with 'slave'. Some were satisfied with the change, but others felt that it removed a crucial part of the story. I agree with the latter view. The story is set in a time when black people were slaves and commonly referred to as 'niggers'. While the word has a heavy connotation, that is precisely why the author used it, to give readers a sense of the era. For future generations who may not know about slavery or black oppression, the book provides an unfiltered view of a black man's life. The word symbolizes slavery, and without it, the book loses its impact.  Censorship is a complex issue, and everyone has a different threshold. The case of '@ORGANIZATION1' is just one example. On television, nudity and inappropriate language are censored. However, it should be the parents' responsibility to decide what their children read, watch, or buy. If a parent finds a book offensive, they should ensure their child does not read it, but the books should not be removed from the shelves as they can entertain and educate others. In conclusion, books should not be censored. If a person deems a book inappropriate, they can simply choose not to read it.

Imagine you're in the library, looking for a book to read, when your child runs up to you holding a magazine of questionable content. What would you do? Libraries should not have inappropriate items on their shelves. Censoring libraries is a way to protect you and your family, ensuring that everyone can enjoy their time there.  One reason libraries should be censored is for the sake of children. Children are naturally curious and are drawn to colorful and unique things. For example, my little sister once preferred going to the zoo over the museum. She said, 'I want to see the animals, not a boring statue. I can see those anytime around town.' This shows that children are attracted to new and different things. If they see inappropriate material in the library for the first time, they'll be curious about it because it's novel.  Another reason is that sometimes library items are mis - shelved. Suppose you check out a movie that sounds great, only to find out it's not what you expected when you get home. What if you rented it for a party with guests? It would be embarrassing. Something similar happened to my cousin; she rented a '@LOCATION1' by mistake and was embarrassed for weeks. This embarrassment could have been avoided if libraries were censored.  Lastly, seeing certain material in a library can be offensive. I know I'd be offended, and I wouldn't want others to experience that either. When I was a kid, I went to the mall with my grandmother to buy jeans. I was offended when the salesperson said I 'looked fat' in the jeans I picked. People should consider others' feelings before causing offense.  Some people think inappropriate material is okay in libraries, but I believe they should find other places for it. Think about your family and the potential consequences of not having library censorship. Are you willing to be responsible for not taking action? We should work towards stricter laws on library censorship.

Why should books that some people enjoy be removed from library shelves? It's absurd. There are many alternatives to completely removing certain books.  It's understandable that young children should not be exposed to inappropriate materials such as books, magazines, poems, movies, or songs. It's unnecessary for them to read explicit content, but we can prevent it.  One way libraries across the country can prevent this is by creating separate libraries for explicit materials or placing them on the opposite side of the library from children's materials. Although libraries usually have different corners for adult and children's materials, there should be stricter rules about children entering the adult section.  Another idea is to require parental permission on a child's library card. The permission should specify which areas of the library the child can access. For example, if a child's parents only allow them to get materials from the children's section, the child won't be able to borrow from other areas without their parents present to give permission.  When I was a child, I was upset when I couldn't do what my parents were doing. But now, I understand that they wanted me to stay a child for as long as possible. They knew that exposing me to inappropriate materials would make me grow up too fast.  In conclusion, we should keep inappropriate books and magazines away from young kids. I don't advocate banning these materials from libraries; instead, I want parents to take responsibility and prevent their children from being exposed to such content. It's not the library's fault if children are exposed to explicit material; it's the parents' for allowing it to happen.

Should offensive materials be removed from shelves? Should the movies you loved as a child suddenly disappear?  Magazines have always been known for being offensive. They often distort the words of celebrities and people, presenting a completely different version of the truth. There are numerous movies that show violence, replay painful parts of people's lives, or say offensive things. Music, too, can be offensive. Songs are sometimes written about people's past actions that others may find offensive. I once saw a music video making fun of @PERSON1 for being in jail, but I don't think it should be removed from the internet because it's entertaining.  This world needs things to keep us entertained. Imagine a world without news reporters or paparazzi. We'd be completely unaware of what's happening around us. While I understand that celebrities may be offended by being constantly talked about, especially regarding their mistakes, that's just how the world works. Gossip and discussion are part of everyone's lives.  In my opinion, getting rid of offensive movies, music, magazines, and books is not a good idea. What would we have to entertain us if they were gone? In conclusion, we should accept that offensive materials are a part of our entertainment and not seek to eliminate them.

In @LOCATION1, the constitution guarantees freedom of speech, allowing individuals to express their thoughts, opinions, and individuality. This freedom should also extend to books, music, movies, magazines, and other forms of entertainment. However, with freedom of speech, there will always be people who take offense to others' ideas and opinions.  If someone finds a particular type of material offensive in a public library, they should simply avoid it. They shouldn't make a fuss over something that others enjoy. They need to understand and accept the concept of freedom of speech. What one person dislikes may be another person's favorite.  So, why should others' forms of enjoyment be censored and taken away just because one person is offended? It's unjust. Everyone has their own way of expressing themselves, which is a healthy way to release positive or negative energy. Whether it's writing books, posting articles, or creating music, it's a form of venting, and some people may appreciate that style. It's up to the offended person to decide whether to engage with such content.  Censorship should not be allowed in libraries. Implementing censorship would deprive people of the things they enjoy and violate the artists' and authors' freedom of speech and expression. There are books that have been banned from schools across the country, but just because some think it's right doesn't mean it is. While the intention may be to protect people from offensive content, it also shields them from the real world. We should let people experience the diverse forms of art in the world. In conclusion, libraries should uphold the principle of freedom of speech and refrain from censorship.

I never thought I'd witness the day when there'd be talk of book censorship. However, this doesn't mean I approve of it. Just because I don't approve doesn't mean I oppose it either. I believe it's fair and necessary to consider both sides of the argument.  If one thing is censored, it sets a precedent to censor everything. Public media like televisions, radios, magazines, and books have become part of our imperfect world. There are indeed crimes and indecencies occurring, but can we truly say that these public items have completely influenced and brainwashed children until early adulthood? It's possible, but also uncertain.  It's well - known that children are highly impressionable at a young age and can be shaped into who they'll become, at least until they're old enough to form their own opinions. For example, when I was young, my cousin, who was a few years older, liked a particular thing. After spending a lot of time with her, I became obsessed with it too. Later, my mother told me it wasn't really my interest but hers. I had simply modeled after her. Every child has had similar experiences. So, is it not reasonable to think they might imitate what they see in uncensored media?  On the other hand, it would be unfair to remove books that some consider improper. If we did so, nearly every book would be removed. Nowadays, the radio is full of references to sex, drugs, alcohol, and smoking. The internet is flooded with porn and crude ads. Books, too, have become more explicit.  The world has become rather chaotic. In the end, I stand by my view: if one thing is censored, all should be. It's only fair. Radios, televisions, movies, and other forms of media are already censored. Books are not as innocent as they seem. Therefore, libraries should censor their books or at least make an effort to do so. Libraries are places for learning and enjoyment, not for leaving mental scars from inappropriate reading material.

I find library censorship laws unnecessary. People should have the freedom to borrow whatever they like. Those who create these laws should be glad that young people are interested in reading.  Books, music, movies, magazines, etc., all fall under censorship. Everyone perceives things differently, and some are more mature than others. If someone wants to engage with a particular product, they should be allowed to. The person who selects the item should know their own capabilities and whether they can handle the content.
