I'm an avid reader and enjoy all types of books. I'm aware that there are books I've read that my parents might not approve of, but that hasn't stopped me. I think that after a certain age, people should have the freedom to read whatever they want. If I feel I'm not mature enough to read a particular book, I simply won't pick it up. When it comes to music, movies, and magazines, the situation is different. Music is similar to a book, but it engages a different sense as it's listened to rather than read. In my view, movies should be judged more carefully because they're like a form of show - and - tell. If children or teens take them too seriously, it can lead to problems. I believe that we shouldn't judge all materials based on assumptions. Everyone has different opinions and preferences. So, materials shouldn't be removed from library shelves if there are people who like or support what they offer.

When one thinks of a library, the first thoughts are often of quietness, peace, and calm. However, once someone starts reading a book, magazine, movie, etc. in a library and comes across something offensive, this perception can change. I firmly believe that offensive materials like books, magazines, and movies should be censored and removed from libraries. Although everyone has the right to their own opinion, a library is supposed to be a place of peace. Having offensive literature makes the library seem unkempt. If people want to read offensive materials, they should look elsewhere. When I was young, I participated in library events like reading - contests. I loved exploring the library. I remember that there were always many magazines on the shelves, some showing half - dressed people. While I understand people want to stay informed, they can find such magazines elsewhere. Having these offensive magazines in libraries where children can see them is inappropriate and can upset parents. Another reason for censorship is that offensive materials can influence teens to do bad things. For example, books about drugs and smoking can make teens think these actions are okay. Removing such books from libraries would likely reduce the negative influence on teens. In my opinion, censoring library materials would make people happier and the world a better place. If someone wants to read offensive content, a library is not the place to look.

My stance on censorship is that it's a complex issue. I believe that if a book, movie, etc. discriminates against one or more groups of people, the public should have a say in whether it stays on library shelves. If the materials use offensive language or actions to harm or discriminate against a race, they should be removed. However, if they are part of the world or national history, they should remain for future generations to learn from. Most materials in libraries don't aim to discriminate. Censorship can go either way, depending on the situation and the material. Just because someone thinks something is offensive doesn't make it a fact. If a book is popular in the library, I'd be hesitant to remove it as people have different views on what is offensive. If I were a parent today, I'd let my child read a so - called offensive book if it was part of our country's past. My intention would be for my child to learn about history, not to act on the content. In conclusion, my view is that censorship depends on the situation and material, and these are just my personal opinions.

I do not believe that offensive materials such as books, movies, and magazines should be removed from library shelves. There are several reasons for this. Firstly, if anyone could remove books they find offensive, libraries would become useless. Students would have a harder time learning about various topics in the world. For example, a mother didn't want her sixth - grade daughter to learn about sex education because she thought her daughter was too young. But by doing so, the daughter may miss out on learning about diseases related to underage or unprotected sex, which could lead to serious consequences that could have been prevented through library books or school classes. Secondly, removing books from the shelves is disrespectful to the authors and everyone involved in writing them. Just because we don't agree with the content doesn't mean we can discard the hard work. It defeats the purpose of freedom of speech as it restricts authors from writing and publishing what they want and expressing their opinions. This problem can be easily solved. For example, offensive materials can be placed in a separate section of the library and made available only to adults of a certain age. They can also be rated like movies. In conclusion, I strongly oppose giving citizens the right to remove offensive materials from library shelves as it can have a negative impact on the community, is disrespectful to authors, and there are simple solutions to address the issue.

I firmly believe that offensive and inappropriate books, movies, music, and magazines should be removed from the shelves. While people have the right to freedom of speech, it should not be expressed in an offensive way. If individuals wish to have their works, such as movies or music, presented or heard, they should ensure they are appropriate. Just because others engage in inappropriate content does not make it acceptable. Some people may lack the judgment to avoid imitating the actions depicted in movies or songs. Many individuals are attracted to songs that promote negative behavior, perhaps to gain attention. I recall that when I was younger, I was influenced by the media and engaged in foolish actions, thinking they were right. People often desire to express themselves, but it should be done appropriately. Some artists and actors may not intend to convey negative messages to children, yet they feel compelled to create offensive content to gain public attention. I learned this the hard way and now understand that the only way to be heard is by saying and doing appropriate things. In conclusion, we should uphold appropriate standards in media content to avoid negative influences.

Censorship has been a long - standing issue, and many people advocate for censorship in various media, including television, books, and magazines. However, there is a problem when it comes to older teens. They are not young children and should not have everything censored. For example, the requirement to be accompanied by an adult to watch a rated movie is an over - reach for older teens. For young children, censorship is necessary as they are too young to be exposed to bad language and inappropriate content. Parents should also be vigilant about what their young children read and hear. Some parents are negligent in this regard, and their children may pick up bad language and habits, which can lead to trouble at school. Younger kids are like sponges, and those around them act as role models. On the other hand, older teens, such as those aged @NUM1 and @NUM2, are more mature. They are likely to encounter bad language in their daily lives, so censoring books in the library may be unnecessary. Books are meant to provide real - life experiences and knowledge. Everyone has different opinions, and in my view, high - school materials like books and magazines should not be overly censored. As people grow older, they become more aware of what is right and wrong. Therefore, we should respect the maturity of older teens and not impose excessive censorship.

Imagine walking into your favorite library and finding that your favorite book or movie is missing. The librarian tells you it was removed from all public libraries because it was considered offensive. This would surely be frustrating, especially if you had read the book and found nothing wrong with it. Of course, there are some materials that children should not access due to offensive content, but complete removal is not the answer. There are alternative solutions that can satisfy everyone. One option is to restrict access to offensive material. Only the librarian would have access, and they would be responsible for determining whether a person, child or adult, can view this content. Another solution is to have a separate building for offensive materials. Only those over @NUM1 would be allowed entry, and they would need to present an ID and a library card. This would prevent underage individuals from obtaining inappropriate items. A third solution is to require signed permission from a parent or guardian for underage users. When a child applies for a library card, the parent must be present and specify what the child can and cannot borrow. I believe that removing books, movies, and music from shelves violates the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech. If someone can control what others read, see, or listen to, it could lead to the erosion of our rights. However, I also recognize that certain age groups should not have access to certain materials. By implementing these alternative solutions, we can strike a balance between protecting individuals from inappropriate content and upholding the principle of free speech.

In my opinion, what one person finds offensive may be valuable to another. All types of books, music, and magazines should remain on library shelves. Different books offer diverse perspectives, and some people have a deep connection with certain books that others may not understand. Removing certain books can hurt people's feelings. Taking away music would be even worse, as many people use it to escape from their problems. Losing this form of escape can leave them feeling helpless. Movies are also popular as they help people understand different viewpoints. Banning movies would deprive people of entertainment. While some movies may be offensive, it is not up to others to decide. Magazines are a source of news, and although much of the news can be offensive, it reflects the real world. Removing magazines would prevent people from staying informed about the latest news and gossip. Taking away the things that people use to connect, escape, be entertained, and stay informed is likely to cause negative reactions. Everyone is different, and what one person finds offensive may be important to another. If someone thought what you liked was inappropriate, you would surely feel unfair. Therefore, we should respect everyone's preferences and not remove materials based on subjective judgments of offensiveness.

Titles like 'The @CAPS1 in the @CAPS2', 'The @CAPS3 @CAPS4', and 'The @CAPS5 of @PERSON2' are well - known literary masterpieces that have been enjoyed by many since their publication. However, these books have also been banned from certain libraries across the country and the world. In conclusion, we should encourage independent thinking and proper guidance rather than censorship in schools.

The purpose of libraries is to allow people to read what they desire. If I owned a library, I would keep all materials on the shelves because people have diverse preferences. We all enjoy reading books, watching movies, listening to music, and reading magazines. Censorship involves the removal or blocking of certain media or readable content, and the decision often lies with the distributor rather than the creator (author, director, or publisher). Creators make content based on their own interests, while distributors have the right to decide whether to publicly display it. Libraries have a wide range of materials on their shelves, but the display of graphic content is restricted by educational rules. It's not the creator's responsibility to ensure where the content is displayed, but the audience's choice to view it. As for the right to restrict a child's reading, my mother wouldn't let me read certain books when I was younger as she thought they were from the devil. This only made me more eager to read them. In conclusion, maintaining an uncensored library environment is essential for the free exchange of ideas and the development of a well - informed society.

Nowadays, many libraries contain violent and offensive books. The question is whether libraries should remove these books, movies, and music from the shelves. Children under a certain age should not be allowed to access offensive books without parental permission. If they wish to rent such a book, they must obtain their parents' consent.  In conclusion, rather than removing offensive books, movies, and music, libraries should organize them into separate sections with appropriate age restrictions and parental consent requirements. Rewrite of the first item Reading is highly popular, serving as an activity both at home and in the classroom. In conclusion, libraries should not remove books, movies, and magazines that some people find offensive. In schools and libraries, many people come across books that do not suit their taste. Everyone has their own opinions, and what one person finds offensive may be of interest to another. The question is whether we should remove books that the majority of people consider offensive or keep them on the shelves. Here is my stance on this issue.  Books are intended for learning and enjoyment, not to offend anyone. Each book has its own purpose and was written for a reason. There are numerous books that many people dislike, but this does not mean that no one else appreciates them. We should keep these books in schools and libraries because they may be beneficial to someone. If these books were removed, how would that person access the information they need if no other resources were available?  One solution is to categorize books by genre. This way, people will know what they are looking for and are less likely to stumble upon offensive books accidentally. Categorization also helps to keep the library organized. When visiting the library, patrons can go directly to the section they need and avoid sections that may contain offensive material.  Libraries and schools aim to keep books on the shelves. This is the primary function of libraries, as they provide access to information that may not be available elsewhere. If libraries removed every book that someone complained about, there would be little left in the library.  In summary, everyone is entitled to their opinion and may find a book offensive. However, books are written for a reason, and if the library or publisher thought the content would cause a significant problem, they would not have made it available. Therefore, we should keep the books on the shelves.

Visiting the library can be challenging because there is a vast array of genres to choose from. In addition to books, there are also music and magazines. Among the books, there are various subjects and categories, including children's books, biographies, and autobiographies. There is also a wide variety of music to suit different tastes. Therefore, I do not think that certain books or music should be removed from the library shelves based on a few individual opinions.  Just because one person finds a book offensive does not mean it should be removed from the shelves. For example, when going to the mall, people visit the shops they like and avoid those they dislike or find offensive due to the items they sell. This does not mean that these shops should be banned from the mall, as some people may find them interesting and want to purchase their products. The same principle applies to books and materials in the library.  One way for libraries to address this issue without removing books from the shelves is to conduct a survey among local visitors. Personally, I do not always read the most popular subjects. I enjoy reading about murder cases, drug busts, biographies, and autobiographies. Some people may find my interests unusual, but this shows that not everyone has the same reading and music preferences. Therefore, libraries should maintain a diverse selection of materials to satisfy all readers.  In conclusion, libraries should not remove books or music based on a few individual opinions. People should have the freedom to choose what they want to read and listen to, and libraries should provide a wide range of options to meet different needs.

In my opinion, libraries should not remove any of the books currently in their collections. If parents or individuals do not want to read certain types of books, they can simply choose not to. The question of whether certain materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines, should be removed from library shelves if they are offensive to some people is a complex one. In my view, the library should not censor materials. In the United States, a country that upholds freedom of speech, there should be no place for censorship. I firmly hold the opinion that certain materials like books, music, movies, and magazines shouldn't be removed from the shelves just because someone finds them offensive. Do you think that removing a book from the shelf will shield you or your kids from offensive material? If so, you're mistaken. I don't believe that certain materials should be removed from library shelves. Patrons have the freedom to select what they want, and librarians do not coerce them into choosing any particular item. I firmly believe that there should be a debate about removing certain forms of media such as movies, music, and books. Nowadays, people are engaging in behaviors they never would have before. There are numerous issues related to offensive materials used for entertainment. Censorship can be a solution to this problem. This situation can also be debated. People who are offended by the material, whether due to religious or racial reasons, don't necessarily have to be exposed to it. In my personal view, I have no issues with the content found in libraries today. Overall, libraries should remain as they are. They are places where people can freely explore knowledge, and no one should take away that opportunity.

I don't think people should remove books from library shelves. Town libraries offer a wide variety of books, and everyone should be able to enjoy reading different types of literature. To prevent children from reading inappropriate books, libraries can issue permission cards with parental consent. If that doesn't work, an age limit can be set. Parents can be asked to show their children's birth certificates. A restricted section can be established in the library, and parents should sign a note allowing their children to borrow books from this section.  Children aged thirteen and under should not be given magazines, while those aged fourteen and above can have access. Music shouldn't be a concern for parents, and if parents buy movies, there shouldn't be an issue either. Other details can be sorted out on an individual basis.  This is my view on how library books should be managed. I've explained how a library should operate and what I think is appropriate. My advice is to think carefully before taking any action regarding library books.

I believe that all materials should be allowed in libraries because every individual has the right to choose what they read, listen to, and watch. In conclusion, while libraries should uphold the principle of free access to materials, we need to be more vigilant about the content of music, movies, and magazines. I firmly believe that books, movies, music, magazines, and other such materials should not be removed simply because some people do not like them. The question at hand is whether certain materials should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. I will delve into this topic, covering the introduction, main body, and conclusion. The question of whether there should be censorship in libraries is a matter on which many people hold personal views. In my view, all books and movies should be accompanied by warning signs. This ensures that people know what to expect before reading or watching. Censoring our cultural heritage is a grave mistake. Language is the cornerstone of human legacy, and every word spoken or written is a part of our collective creation. I firmly oppose library censorship. Every individual should have the right to express their beliefs and ideas. Some library materials contain information that may be offensive to others. The question arises: should these materials be removed if they are found offensive? Some people believe that removal should depend on the severity of the offense. Materials should be removed if they involve sexual, racist, or life - threatening content. Some materials may contain sexual offensive comments. If the content is excessive and the author or artist has overstepped boundaries, there is a valid reason for removal. Such content can evoke negative emotions in readers, making them feel violated and offended. There are also materials with racist comments. Racism is a significant global conflict that causes fights, arguments, and emotional distress. If a material contains excessive racism, it should be removed. Additionally, some materials may present life - threatening offenses. For example, if a book about a nation contains content that implies the nation is in danger, some readers may be offended and demand its removal. Materials with excessive threats can make people feel their lives are at risk. In conclusion, offensive materials should be removed from library shelves. If they are sexually explicit, life - threatening, or contain racist comments, removal is necessary to prevent individuals from experiencing such harmful content.

Removing 'offensive' books from library shelves is equivalent to infringing on the right of speech. There is no valid reason for it. In this country, people have the right of speech and the right to be heard. An author's opinions may be offensive to some, but that does not mean they should be silenced. Writers draw inspiration from society, and taking away these books will not change people's thoughts and feelings. Moreover, citizens have the right to make their own choices. If someone doesn't like a book, they can simply choose not to borrow it. Writers may state things that, to some extent, may offend a small number of people. However, others view it as an exercise of freedom of speech and writing. An author who writes a story involving sex is not targeting second - graders. But if someone has an issue with an author's worldview, they will encounter similar things in the real world. Some books may be fictional, but they still draw ideas from society. When writers create books with 'inappropriate' actions, they reflect real - world behavior. Banning books with sex scenes or provocative language does not stop people from having sex or using curse words. Kids learn about these things from their parents and peers. Reading about them in a book does not change the fact that they are exposed to such content through other means. Removing swear - word books from library shelves will not change society, as there is no perfect society. Placing a book with offensive language on the shelf does not harm anyone. If a reader dislikes an author's expression, they can choose not to read the book. No one is forced to read offensive books. Banning a book at the request of an unhappy parent is a waste of resources and intelligence. The library is not responsible for readers' feelings. If a reader doesn't like a book, they can simply close it. In conclusion, banning books from public libraries is not an effective solution. It does not change society, and people should have the freedom to choose what they read.

It is understandable that some people advocate for library censorship to remove rude, unwanted, or offensive media. However, as Katherine Paterson pointed out, if one person has the right to remove a book from the shelf, then everyone does. Considering this, is library censorship really a wise idea? If everyone could decide which books to remove or which music to ban, there would be nothing left in libraries. It is impossible to please everyone. There are, of course, benefits to censorship. No parent wants their child exposed to certain materials at a young age. But libraries should not be censored. Responsible parents who want their children to avoid a particular book or movie should handle the situation themselves instead of having the book removed from the shelves. Removing a book also means condemning the author. As an author, one has the freedom of speech, which extends to media. An author has the right to write a book that some may find offensive, and no one has the right to take away this right. In the classic novel Fahrenheit 451 by Ray Bradbury, the protagonist lives in a future world where books are banned and burned. The story contains a disturbing undertone, suggesting that such a 'future' may be closer than we think. The protagonist, a bibliophile, works as a fireman whose job is to burn books. Despite his love for literature, he is forced to participate in this practice. Throughout the novel, he tries to end the madness but is ostracized from society. The book highlights the harsh reality of censorship, which is prevalent everywhere. While we don't need to worry about Bradbury's futuristic nightmare becoming a reality soon, we should be aware of the dangers of censorship. No one person has the right to remove a book they find offensive from the shelves, let alone ban it completely. Banning books is a violation of freedom of speech, ideas, and thought. In conclusion, libraries should remain uncensored, and parents should take personal responsibility for guiding their children's reading choices.

There are numerous books that parents may not want their children to read. However, using censorship in libraries is not a good idea. Although some books may not be suitable for children, they can help children make better real - life choices. We also cannot overlook the principle of freedom of the press. With freedom of the press, anyone can write about anything, including the good, the bad, violence, crimes, love, and romance. Everyone has their own writing style and imagination. Without imagination, there would be no fictional books for children to read. Censorship would leave library shelves bare, as every book has something that could potentially be censored, whether it's swearing, guns, killing, romance, or love. If libraries were to censor books, there would be nothing left to read, and children's intelligence would decline significantly. Children read for various reasons, such as expanding their minds and entering a fictional world. Reading also enhances their vocabulary. When children read, they learn new words and are exposed to different perspectives, which helps them in everyday situations. If libraries censor books, children would be left with limited and un - stimulating reading materials. They would read the same books repeatedly and fail to learn new things. This is not what we want for our community. In conclusion, library censorship is not a great idea as it would deprive children of valuable learning opportunities and limit their intellectual growth.

There is a scary book that one would not want their children to pick up from the shelf. In my view, if kids read it, they might get scared and have nightmares, which parents would likely want to avoid. If parents have the right to move such a book, children may follow suit as they tend to imitate their parents' actions. So, it's advisable to move the book when the children are not around. I firmly believe that certain materials should be carefully managed to safeguard children from potential harm.

Have you ever come across offensive material in a library? Would you want your children exposed to offensive content? I believe no parent desires that. Consider how children access such things. This is wrong; everyone should strive for the best for children and teenagers. The prevalence of violence, bad attitudes, and crimes can be attributed to the easy access to such content. Schools can play a role by removing offensive materials from library shelves. It's regrettable that such materials are present in schools, but that's the reality of today's generation. A library should be a place for learning, reading, and using computers for educational purposes. It should not allow children to play games, listen to music with offensive language, or access inappropriate magazines. Reducing offensive materials in the school environment is a step towards solving this problem. Censorship is urgently needed everywhere as it would greatly benefit children.

The well - known adage 'knowledge is power' aptly describes the current situation regarding library censorship. Censoring libraries, which are intended to provide free access to diverse media materials, deprives people of the opportunity to empower themselves through knowledge. There are multiple compelling reasons against censoring library media, including its unconstitutionality, the lack of a proper definition of 'offensive', and the fundamental conflict with the essence of a library. First and foremost, censoring library materials is unconstitutional. The freedom of speech and the freedom of the press are cornerstones of the nation's founding constitution. Authors, illustrators, journalists, and other creators of library materials exercise their right to free speech through their works, and they are constitutionally protected in what they express. The freedom of the press allows them to share their ideas globally. Censoring library materials would limit the means by which artists can communicate with the citizens of @LOCATION1, clearly violating citizens' rights. Therefore, library censorship cannot be justified on constitutional grounds. The constitutional principle of equality also comes into play. There is no clear legal definition of 'offend'. People can be offended by a wide range of things, from serious personal attacks to minor distastes for certain ideas. Since all individuals are equal, we must respect all forms and degrees of 'offense'. This makes every library - provided work, whether a book, movie, or magazine, vulnerable to the subjective definition of 'offensive' and the personal feelings of each individual. Allowing individuals' offense to mark a work as 'offensive' and lead to its removal from libraries would enable some citizens to undermine the rights of others, which is unacceptable in libraries. Finally, there is a fundamental clash between the nature of censorship and the purpose of a library. Censorship aims to create a politically correct and non - offensive environment by restricting access to materials. Libraries, on the other hand, are meant to offer public access to works that challenge and expand people's knowledge, beliefs, and ideas. Implementing censorship would conflict with the core purpose of a library. For example, a library could not provide new information if someone disliked it, or challenge individual beliefs if someone was offended. In summary, censorship would destroy the system that libraries operate under, and thus, it should not be introduced.

I firmly believe that kids should have the freedom to read what they want. Learning should never be restricted, and there are no truly bad books that kids would encounter at school. When a child starts to dislike their schoolwork, it can lead to a chain reaction of hating school and the books in it. So, we should respect kids' choices in reading to foster their love for learning.

In my opinion, certain materials in books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from shelves as everyone has the right to express themselves. We all have our preferred books, while some others don't appeal to us. Have you ever entered a library hoping to find that long - forgotten all - time favorite book or a book recommended by a friend? Killings, murders, and books related to homosexuality can be offensive to some people, but that doesn't mean they should be removed. Censoring any form of media, such as books, magazines, movies, or music, from a library is unjust. A library is a vast repository of information, a common place where people can seek knowledge. When something is deemed offensive, it should not be hidden away as if it never existed. Instead, it should be the individual seeking the information who decides whether to use it.  For example, when a child encounters something offensive, the immediate reaction is often to remove it from the library or television. However, a better approach is to explain to the child what they are looking at. Eventually, they will understand why it might be offensive. But the question remains: who determines what is offensive? Just because one or two people find something offensive doesn't justify its removal.  Decisions about offensive media should be made through group discussions. If a book or magazine on the shelf might be offensive, the people around that type of information should decide whether to remove it, rather than simply hiding it.  In conclusion, censorship of media in libraries should not be a hasty decision. It is important to respect the right of individuals to access information and make their own choices. By engaging in discussions and allowing people to decide for themselves, we can ensure that libraries remain a place of free knowledge and exploration.

Are offensive materials offensive to everyone? Do all people consider the same materials offensive? Who has the right to determine what is or isn't offensive? Offensive material can be whatever someone deems it to be. Whether we remove offensive material or not, children will encounter it. Offensive material, like cursing or expressions of rage, is a form of self - expression and a way to relieve stress. It can also convey anger, hate, and depression.  Children will inevitably see and hear offensive things. Currently, parents try to shield their children from such content, which only makes children more curious. Offensive things are part of daily life, and the more we try to hide them, the more children will seek them out.  In movies, books, and music, offensive material is a form of expression. It helps relieve stress and rage and presents a true picture of what is happening. For example, in a book, if a character says, '... and she says with grief and anger, 'You are wrong! You don't know what you have done!'...', it's difficult to fully understand the character's true anger. However, if the character says, '... and she says with grief and anger, 'You are wrong! You will perish! You don't know what you have done! Death will come!'...', we can get an idea of how the author will develop the story, how the character truly feels, and we can see the foreshadowing. The author might be hinting at the death of a good man who could have stopped evil or the death of an evil man and the subsequent revenge.  Some people might find such examples offensive. To me, cursing isn't offensive. Offensive material shows how a character, writer, or singer feels without having to explicitly state it. It can also convey grief, amplifying the story and allowing the reader, viewer, or listener to expect more.  Only a specific group of people, like family, friends, or a close - knit group, might agree on what is offensive. Offensive material adds elements like foreshadowing, interest, anger, grief, and sometimes passion to a work. Since children will see offensive material if they want to, there's no point in getting rid of it. It interests them and encourages them to read more, watch or make movies, and listen to or create music.  In conclusion, offensive material, despite being offensive to some, has its place in various forms of media. It enriches the content and allows for a more in - depth understanding of characters and stories. We should not try to eliminate it just because it might be offensive to a few.

Do you think a book should be removed from the shelf just because it offends someone or you don't like it? Katherine pointed out that if everyone had the right to remove a book from the shelf, there would be no books left. I agree that some of the material displayed on the shelves at our local library is inappropriate or even vulgar. In today's world, too many people get away with too much. I firmly believe that we should not remove books, music, movies, magazines, and other media from libraries for several reasons. The only time I would support removing such items is if they would seriously harm people or have a negative impact. If I walked into a public library and saw a book about a girl cutting herself or someone killing another person, I would turn away, even though many kids read such books today. In conclusion, removing books, magazines, movies, music, and other media from libraries would have a negative impact on many people. It would take away sources of entertainment and learning. I firmly believe that books that no one reads should not occupy the shelves of bookstores. When it comes to movies shown in theaters, no child under @NUM1 should be allowed to watch half of the content. Children should not be exposed to things typically meant for adults. This exposure is one of the reasons why young children may engage in inappropriate behaviors. The creators of certain movies need to consider how children might react to their works. In conclusion, we need to be more cautious about the content available to children in books, music, movies, and magazines.

I think books from Mexico are important. Reading books is a great activity, especially during family time. Many people enjoy reading and often go to bookstores. As an @CAPS1 citizen, I do not believe that any materials should be removed from libraries or stores. There are three main reasons supporting my view.  First, @LOCATION1 is known as the land of the free and the home of the brave. When someone removes a book or movie from a library because they find it offensive, they are infringing on my right to freedom. Second, people have the choice to read or watch a particular item. Just because a book or movie is available doesn't mean one has to engage with it. There may be many people who love a particular book, so it's unfair to remove it for the sake of a few.  Finally, the argument that a book or movie should be removed because it's inappropriate for children is unfounded. People have diverse views on various things, and it's impossible to please everyone. I don't think libraries should remove materials just because some people find them offensive.  Firstly, removing offensive materials won't make everyone happy. Just because some individuals are offended by certain books doesn't mean others are. People have the choice to read or not read a book. A 'suggestive' book cover might make some people take offense, but that's not a valid reason to remove the book.  Secondly, offensive materials are enjoyable for some people. If a book or magazine is in the library, it's because someone reads, listens to, or watches it. If it were never checked out, the library would likely get rid of it. Removing so - called 'offensive' materials won't solve the problem of people getting offended easily.  Thirdly, everyone is entitled to their own opinion. Just because some people think there are offensive materials in the library doesn't mean others share the same view. Removing such materials is like taking away freedom, similar to making kids wear uniforms at school.  In conclusion, the world is imperfect, and people will always be offended by something. Removing offensive materials from libraries won't make the world a better place, and we should respect everyone's right to access the materials they choose.

Some books may be offensive, but not all of them. Unfortunately, some libraries have started to censor their book collections by removing books they consider offensive. Another reason is that books on different religions are often removed. I once witnessed a librarian throw away a book about the @CAPS1 religion. This is a terrible act as the @CAPS1 religion is very interesting, and many people will now never learn about it.  Also, removing a book may end up offending some people. I heard about an @CAPS3 family complaining because a library removed a book about their religion. Everyone should have access to the books they want.  I propose that libraries separate books by subject and genre and put up warning signs. This way, people can get the books they want, and libraries won't have to worry about offending people. In conclusion, libraries should refrain from censorship and find better ways to manage their collections.

Throughout history, people have attempted to censor or ban materials they find offensive, which may stem from their upbringing or personal beliefs. However, I firmly believe that individuals should only have the right to decide what is appropriate for themselves. Everyone has one life, during which we form our own opinions and beliefs about right and wrong. Since we are unaware of the values of many people in our lives, claiming to know what should be banned for everyone is presumptuous. For example, if I bring a book to school that I find relevant and not exploitative, I should be able to read it as long as I don't force others to do the same. Suppose another student, raised in a household where the content of my book is considered offensive, sees me reading it. I don't think they should be able to ban the book based solely on their upbringing. While there can be a consensus, there is also the risk of mass ignorance. To claim to know what should or should not be shown to others is, in my view, ignorant. I believe the only justifiable form of censorship is parental control over their children. Parents have the responsibility to guide their children in distinguishing right from wrong. By censoring certain content for their children, they are fulfilling their duty as caregivers. In conclusion, while censorship may have its place in parental guidance, it should not be imposed on others without good reason.

At Jeffersonville High School, students do not have the right to remove a book from the library shelf.
