The real world isn't always a friendly place, and books can convey this reality with less harm than experiencing it firsthand.  I firmly believe that all books should remain on the shelves. Just because a book is offensive to someone doesn't mean it should be removed. For every book, there will always be someone who finds something offensive in it. If the criterion is offensiveness, then all books would have to be removed. If an author has taken the time to write a book and ensure its accuracy, we shouldn't prevent others from reading it. They have the right to write, and we have the right to read, and no one should take these rights away.  Take, for example, books about the Holocaust. Many people are deeply offended by them, but they don't try to get rid of these books. So why should other books be treated differently just because they aren't about a major event? It's truly absurd that some people go to such lengths to remove a book simply because they're offended by it. They should just accept it and move on. If they don't like a book, they don't have to read it. We shouldn't take away the opportunity for those who want to read it.  I remember a time when someone wanted to read a book in our library, but they were told, "Oh, you can't read that because it was found to be offensive." It really upset me that someone else could decide how another person should feel about a book. It's as if they think they're magical, knowing how someone else feels about a book or any subject. In our library, there are some books kept behind the librarian's desk. If someone really wants to read them, they can. I'm okay with this arrangement because at least these books are still available for those who want to read them. This is what should happen with books that are considered too offensive. We should at least make an effort to preserve our rights as citizens.  Let's also consider the financial aspect. The books in the library are often paid for by taxpayers. So, you and many others have contributed to the purchase of these books. It's insane to waste that money by removing a book just because it's offensive to someone. Does it really make you feel better to get worked up over a book and then have it removed? All you've done is get angry and waste money. People need to look at the bigger picture and consider others. When someone removes a book because they're offended, it offends me. It's unnecessary and ruins something that could have been a source of knowledge for others.  In conclusion, I'm very disappointed that people would go to such lengths to ban books from libraries. If you were an author and people did this to your work, how would you feel? You'd probably feel terrible. People need to calm down and think rationally. They should ask themselves, "Will this really affect me if I let this book stay on the shelf?" It also makes me angry that the library spent money on a book, and now it's gone. We should respect the rights of both authors and readers and not let a few offended individuals dictate what others can and cannot read.

The question of whether citizens have the right to remove books, magazines, and other materials from library shelves due to personal disagreement with the content is a complex one with no clear - cut answer. Some individuals believe they have the right to eliminate books, music, and movies containing what they consider 'offensive' material. On the other hand, there are those who think library censorship is wrong and that people should have unrestricted access to any material they desire.  In today's society, there are no strict boundaries. The human imagination can create both beautiful literary and musical works and content that may not be suitable for all age groups. Library censorship is seen as a way to shield young and curious minds from such 'unsuitable' material. However, what might be inappropriate for children could be perfectly acceptable for mature adults. Censorship is highly subjective. For instance, a person who firmly believes in a certain religious creation story might find a book or movie supporting the theory of evolution offensive. A parent who doesn't want their child exposed to a particular topic would prefer not to see related materials in the children's section. But it's unfair to remove all content related to a particular subject just because one person has an issue with it. If someone doesn't want to be exposed to certain 'offensive' subjects, they can choose to avoid them, but they don't have the right to prevent others from accessing that knowledge.  Writing is a form of self - expression, a means to convey thoughts and feelings and share them with others. It's also a way to educate people about the past. If written works are not shared, how can individuals form their own opinions when they're not exposed to diverse viewpoints? It's unjust to prevent someone from learning about a subject just because a few people oppose the content. If we start removing books and movies based on individual sensitivities, eventually, there will be nothing left on the library shelves because everyone is offended by something. Freedom of speech is a fundamental right in our society. By living here, we have the right to read and learn about whatever we choose. Censorship restricts the learning opportunities of those who seek knowledge.  Parents are often strong advocates of library censorship. Their concern about their children being exposed to explicit or graphic material is understandable. But just because a parent doesn't want their child to see a particular movie or read a certain book doesn't mean they have the right to stop others from accessing it. Children need to be exposed to different ideas at some point to develop open - mindedness and acceptance of others. Libraries are a valuable source for young people to learn about different religions, beliefs, and customs. It shouldn't be up to parents to decide what goes on the library shelves. If they don't want their children to access certain materials, they can restrict their children's library visits.  In conclusion, library censorship is a matter of personal opinion. Citizens have the right to access the materials they want. While it's reasonable for parents to protect their children, they shouldn't prevent others from learning. The right to express oneself through literature is meaningless if that literature can't be shared. As Katherine Paterson said, if we continue with excessive censorship, there will be no books left on the shelves for anyone.

Why are there so many offensive books, magazines, movies, and music in the world? In our society, people have moved on from the era of shows like @CAPS1 - duty time, @PERSON1, @CAPS2 @CAPS3, which were non - offensive. Today's shows, books, and movies are often inappropriate for younger viewers.  The good old cartoons that I used to watch, such as @CAPS4, @PERSON3, @ORGANIZATION1, and @CAPS5, which taught me values like @CAPS6, @CAPS7, and @CAPS8, have disappeared. The so - called good cartoons for children today mainly focus on @CAPS9, @CAPS10, @CAPS11, and other deadly sins. They show these without providing any useful life lessons, which is a real problem.  We can't completely eliminate offensive materials. We can't make books disappear from shelves, force directors to stop directing, rappers to stop rapping, or end the production of pornography. However, we can restrict access to them. Offensive content will always be available, whether through the black market or adult stores. Thankfully, there are ways to protect our children. We can set restrictions on televisions, and place offensive books and magazines in restricted areas of the library, accessible only to those over @NUM2 years old.  The music today can be extremely offensive. I grew up listening to traditional country music, but unfortunately, the genre has changed for the worse. The shift in music started with the hippies in the @LOCATION2 @CAPS13 era. While they were under the influence of @CAPS14, @CAPS15, and @CAPS16, they introduced new forms of music that have been around for over @NUM3 years and are not going away. All we can do is hope that our children don't turn on the radio tuned to such offensive music and think it's good.  Pornographic magazines have been around for a long time. No matter what we do, they won't disappear. All we can do is try to keep them out of our lives and our children's sight. But we know that children will eventually be aware of their existence.  In conclusion, we should move offensive materials to restricted areas in the library and other media. We can't completely stop the spread of offensive content, but we can take steps to limit our children's exposure. With determination, we can at least make an effort to protect our children from the negative influence of such materials.

The question of whether libraries should censor materials is a pressing one. In our society, there's a dilemma regarding the presence of offensive books, music, movies, and magazines in libraries. Some people believe they have the right to remove these items, while others think everyone should have access to all materials.  As a citizen, I believe that offensive materials have no place in a public library. There are children in libraries who might stumble upon inappropriate movies or books. For example, a child looking for something to read might come across a movie that is highly inappropriate. This kind of content should not be available in a public space where children can easily access it.  Books these days often contain a lot of offensive language. Kids might pick up this foul language, which is why some books need to be censored. Similarly, a lot of music has offensive lyrics. Rock stars and rappers often write lyrics without considering how others might feel. They use the worst language in their songs, mainly for the sake of making money. We should stand up and demand that they censor their lyrics or at least be more considerate. Writing a letter to express our concerns is a good way to start.  Magazines in libraries can also be a problem. Some magazines talk about sex, drugs, and other inappropriate topics. While some people might be interested in this content, it's not suitable for a 12 - year - old boy to pick up and read. I once saw an 11 - year - old boy reading about drugs, sex, and violence in a library book. This is a serious issue because children might be influenced by what they read.  Censorship is the solution. We need to check and edit the materials in libraries. Books, movies, magazines, and other items should be carefully reviewed, and offensive parts should be blacked out or removed. Not all of these materials should be displayed on the library shelves.  In conclusion, I firmly believe that offensive materials in libraries need to be censored. It's unfair to expose children to such content in a public library. People should start caring more about what is available in libraries and take action to ensure that the environment is suitable for all, especially children. This is my opinion on why censorship is necessary in libraries.

In today's media landscape, numerous elements can be deemed offensive, such as movies, books, songs, and magazines. In my view, everything presented in the media serves a purpose. When an individual finds something offensive, they should distance themselves from it rather than depriving others of access. For instance, song - artists incorporate certain content in their songs to convey a message to the audience. Similarly, movies are crafted in a particular way to make a point. If people find a movie offensive, they simply need to avoid watching it. Some people may find certain library books offensive because they disagree with the content. However, removing a book from the library shelf means denying others the chance to read it. I firmly believe that media that some of the public finds offensive should not be removed. Not everyone is offended by the same things in the media. Every item on the market and in the media is there to convey a message. In conclusion, we should respect the diversity of media content and the different perspectives of the public.

I don't think certain materials like books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from the shelves just because they're offensive. These items should remain accessible, with appropriate age - restrictions. Adults over 18 should have the freedom to choose what they read, watch, or listen to. For those under 18, there should be age requirements and parental consent. When minors get a library membership, they should verify their date of birth and the materials their parents allow them to access. Libraries and bookstores should rate materials, similar to movie ratings. This would reduce parental anger over their children engaging with inappropriate content. If bookstores sell restricted items to minors without consent, they can face charges, just like selling liquor or cigarettes to a minor. I've seen firsthand the negative impact of inappropriate content on children. My little brother, with my mother's permission, played video games with violence, sex, drugs, and foul language. As a result, he became disobedient and misbehaved at school. Even if parents give permission, there should still be age limits. Some parents make poor decisions, and it will affect their children later. In conclusion, keep these materials on the shelves for mature audiences. Limiting access to minors can reduce crimes, violence, and drug - related issues.

Some books, magazines, music, and movies should not be freely available in libraries as children can be exposed to inappropriate content that parents may not approve of. Libraries often contain offensive materials, such as prejudiced books or music with swear words and political views. Libraries need to address this issue properly. Instead of removing the materials, they should monitor certain sections more closely. For example, they can require children to stay with their parents. To address the issue of offending people, libraries can put up signs in prominent locations. These signs can clearly state that the content in a particular section may be offensive and that parental control is needed. Libraries should be more empathetic towards the public's feelings. They should consider how they would feel if such content was shown to their own children. I once had a personal experience in a library. I was offended by a book title against my religion. If there had been a warning sign, I wouldn't have had to see it. My brother also rented a movie that our parents didn't approve of, as the library's controls were inadequate. Other children could engage in more inappropriate behavior, like looking at inappropriate magazines or reading unapproved books. In conclusion, libraries need to take control and present themselves to the public in a more appropriate manner. Putting up signs and ensuring parental control can reduce or eliminate these issues.

Offensive materials should be removed from the shelves for several reasons. The content in magazines should be appropriate for public viewing. One reason is that it may offend important figures, such as the president of an organization or the governor of a state. If someone is offended by the content in reading materials, they should speak up to defend themselves. Otherwise, no one will take steps to make changes. I'm puzzled as to why such offensive content is allowed in magazines, music, and movies. Although movies are often fictional, they can still cause offense. In books, the author may have a reason for including offensive content, which may be relevant to real - life situations. For example, I read a newspaper article about the current president being questioned about his birth certificate. People doubted he was born in the United States. I personally believe he was born in the U.S., and since his certificate proved his citizenship, the issue should be dropped. I can't help but wonder what the president thought when asked that question. It's likely that someone would have verified his birth details before he became president. In conclusion, offensive materials should be carefully considered and removed when they cause unnecessary offense.

What if someone finds your favorite book offensive? While inappropriate materials should be kept away from young minds, we can't shield people from everything. Everyone has different views on what is offensive. One person may think a book should be removed from the shelves, while another sees no problem with it. Children need protection from harmful materials. Magazines featuring celebrities breaking the law can have a negative influence on young people, who may try to imitate such behavior. However, children are exposed to worse things at home, on TV, and at school than in some books. We can't "baby - proof" life. Parents should teach their children to say no to bad influences. Libraries serve a diverse public, and someone will always find something offensive. Due to different views, beliefs, and religions, books on certain topics may be offensive to some but a part of another's lifestyle. As Katherine Paterson said, if we remove every offensive book, there will be no books left in libraries. Even if a book is not suitable for a particular group, it should be available if someone wants to read it. Libraries should not be prejudiced against certain books. Children can be protected from inappropriate books if they have learned moral values to make mature choices. In conclusion, libraries should maintain a wide variety of books to meet the diverse needs of the public.

I firmly believe that any book or movie in the library has a valid reason for being there. The world is filled with both things that can harm and demoralize a person and those that can make one feel on top of the world. There are indeed things that are inappropriate for children, and these are typically not exposed to students until they reach a mature and responsible age. As children grow up, they will inevitably be taught and shown things that parents may find uncomfortable, such as books about people with disorders, romance novels, movies with cursing, sex scenes, and violence. Some parents even don't want their children to see a simple kiss on the cheek, which I find rather strange because these are all part of life. However, if a child is engaging in inappropriate behavior, that's a different matter. For example, I also believe that children should not be taught about sex or shown the physical differences between genders. Their minds should not be focused on such things. Books, movies, and TV shows should not be removed from the library because they depict real life and what one will encounter as they get older. In conclusion, we should accept that these materials are a part of the library's collection as they contribute to a more comprehensive understanding of the world.

Debates are an integral part of our contemporary society. Everyone holds an opinion on how the world should be, and there is no absolute right or wrong. Books that describe the behavior of other cultures, which may seem offensive to the people being described, are crucial as we need to learn as much as possible about different cultures. Our businesses operate in foreign countries, many people in our country are bilingual, and individuals have the right to read materials that might be offensive to a particular race. Businesses thrive in other countries, and a significant portion of our country's income comes from factories and companies abroad. For instance, [LOCATION2] is a major business hub for [ORGANIZATION2]. If we, as [CAPS1], cannot learn about the [CAPS2], how can we understand their business methods and way of life? While these books may be offensive to the [CAPS2], they serve as learning tools for us to understand their culture. Bilingualism is a widespread trend, and high schools require students to learn a foreign language, even if it's just the basics, to prepare them for the global workforce. Learning about other languages and cultures often comes from books. Although the Mexican population may not like the way they are portrayed in our stories, it is necessary for us to learn about them. In the [ORGANIZATION1], we enjoy various freedoms, including freedom of speech, which extends to books. It's likely that other countries also have books that are offensive to us, and this is a common phenomenon globally. Since businesses thrive in foreign countries, we should be able to read books about them, even if they seem offensive. Learning is an essential aspect of education, and there should be no limit to what we can learn. If a book contains vulgar language or sexual scenes, it should be moved from the children's section rather than being completely banned. The same principle applies to other groups of people. They should not take offense at what we read, as there are likely worse things said about them elsewhere. Learning is a necessary tool in our society, and nothing should be restricted. In conclusion, we should embrace these books as they contribute to our understanding of the world and our ability to conduct business globally.

Books are of utmost importance to our society. They hold a special place in our hearts and contain a vast amount of the world's knowledge. Everyone has their own view on what should or should not be included in books. I strongly believe that young children should not be allowed to purchase books with explicit content. However, many of us, including myself, have checked out or bought books only to later realize the content. I do not think that any book should be removed from the shelves simply because it contains certain content. There are numerous books in school and public libraries that could be considered offensive. For example, books about the [CAPS1] and even the [CAPS2] [CAPS3], like '[CAPS4] [CAPS5]'s [CAPS6]', can be misinterpreted. These books do contain language that is inappropriate for children, yet they remain on the shelves. Why? Because these books, along with many others, are extremely valuable to us. As Katherine Paterson aptly said, '... And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This means that if everyone removed books they found offensive, there would be no books left. Books are essential for learning. We have been recording our knowledge in books for hundreds, if not thousands, of years. When the libraries in [LOCATION2] were destroyed, we feared that our knowledge was lost forever. Fortunately, there was a backup system in [LOCATION1]. I have read the [ORGANIZATION1] and believe in it whole - heartedly. However, I know that some people do not believe in the [CAPS8] and may take some statements in the [ORGANIZATION1] personally. I think the [ORGANIZATION1] is the most important book in the world. Without it, we would not know about the wonderful things our [CAPS8] has done for us. Nevertheless, some people may find its statements about homosexuals and divorces offensive. But would we allow gays or divorced individuals to remove the [ORGANIZATION1] from the shelves? Of course not! If we don't allow the removal of this important book, why should we allow the removal of other books? In conclusion, books are vital to our world as they preserve knowledge and touch our hearts. We cannot imagine a world without them.

In today's world, children are exposed to more inappropriate content than ever before. They hear inappropriate things from older siblings, watch uncensored TV programs, listen to explicit music, and read books with improper content. The question at hand is whether libraries should dispose of inappropriate books, movies, music, and magazines. Children can read what they like with parental permission, but in modern society, some parents are too busy with work to pay attention. One solution is to set age limits on books. My mother has often restricted me from reading books that deal with issues I'm not ready for. Since not all parents are as vigilant, an age limit would help keep children from being exposed to inappropriate content. Librarians or a national book association could determine the appropriate age for each book. This would prevent children from reading about vulgar issues. Additionally, [CAPS1] books should be more accessible. These books teach good morals and how to live a fulfilling life. Many [CAPS1] authors are not represented in public school libraries. By adding these books, students would be more likely to discover and learn from them. Libraries also face issues with music and movies. It's convenient to borrow CDs and movies from the library, but some contain offensive language and inappropriate scenes. The public should demand the removal of music and videos with non - child - friendly content. Movie ratings exist for a reason, and any movie rated above [NUM1] should not be in libraries. If a movie has content unsuitable for children under thirteen, it should be removed. Magazines can be educational, but some have content inappropriate for children. Like books, magazines should also have ratings. For example, the [CAPS3] magazine has articles that are too vulgar for students. Such magazines should be placed in an adult section. Some magazines also contain pictures that were once considered illegal. These magazines should not be allowed in libraries. America's standards regarding what is acceptable to read, watch, and listen to have changed significantly. Children are learning inappropriate things at a young age. Society needs to impose strict restrictions on what is suitable for children. I personally believe that strict rules should be set for what children can watch, read, and listen to. My parents' strictness in this regard has benefited my learning. Libraries should remove books that were once considered inappropriate. Since parents are less involved in monitoring their children's media consumption, society should enforce strict rules on library content. In conclusion, by implementing these measures, we can protect children from inappropriate content and ensure a more suitable learning environment.

This essay will discuss whether offensive materials in libraries or music should be censored and removed from the shelves. In my opinion, most materials in libraries and music should be censored, but not removed just because one person finds them offensive. Uncensored materials, such as books that some people find offensive, may be relatable to others who have had similar experiences during their upbringing. However, we should be more cautious to prevent younger kids from getting the wrong ideas when they listen to the radio or read books. Censorship should be carried out to a certain extent, but not overdone. In the long run, appropriate censorship can contribute to a cleaner and safer society by exposing people only to positive content. There's a possibility that we can make a significant difference by doing so. I wouldn't attempt to censor everything because it's impossible to stop everyone from accessing such materials. While it's worth a try, I wouldn't completely remove offensive materials just because a particular person is offended. I understand moving a book if someone finds it offensive, but only to a place where it won't cause offense. I'm not saying it's wrong to censor, but I think it could make many people angry. After all, the government has done many things that we don't like and can't do much about. In conclusion, we should approach censorship with a balanced perspective, considering both the need to protect the public and the rights of individuals to access diverse materials.

In contemporary society, books, movies, magazines, music, and other forms of media constitute a significant portion of our entertainment system. Today, local libraries offer a wide range of entertainment materials, both informational and purely for amusement, which is a departure from the past when most libraries only housed books. It is evident that entertainment has evolved over time and will continue to change in the future.  Libraries today contain diverse materials. Some may provide information about the solar system or the human body, while others may be fictional stories filled with action, horror, or romance. There are also materials featuring true, life - changing, and inspiring stories. However, certain materials may be offensive to some individuals and inappropriate for younger audiences.  Nonetheless, materials in libraries that contain offensive, inappropriate, or rude content should not be banned. Most libraries are large and well - organized into different sections. For instance, there are areas for fiction books, non - fiction books, children's books, and sections for magazines, movies, and music, all categorized by type and genre. Materials suitable only for adults should be placed in a separate section. When someone checks out a book from this section, the library should verify the person's age. This approach can also be applied to movies, magazines, and music in that section.  What is offensive to one person may not be offensive to another. Removing offensive materials from the library will not satisfy everyone and may disappoint those who do not find such materials offensive. Placing these materials in a separate section is the most beneficial solution. Just because one person deems certain materials offensive, it does not mean that everyone shares the same view, nor should all such materials be removed. Dividing these materials into their own section and regulating access is the best way to ensure that everyone's needs are met.

I firmly believe that certain materials should not be removed from library shelves due to censorship. Different sections should be provided in libraries to accommodate the diverse preferences of patrons. Everyone has their own opinions on what they like to read or watch, and individuals should be able to make choices at their own risk. Censorship should not impact libraries.  Libraries should have distinct sections for kids, teenagers, and adults. The kids' section should offer age - appropriate books, and children should only be allowed to check out materials from this area. They should not be exposed to content that librarians consider inappropriate, and thus, do not need to worry about censorship.  The teenage section should not have censorship. Many teenagers are already aware of various things, and exposure to certain content in books, such as foul language and inappropriate themes, or in music, does not have a significant influence on them. Since they are familiar with the content of the music they listen to, it is unnecessary to offer only censored music in libraries. Removing uncensored materials is pointless when teenagers are already aware of such content.  The adult section should also be free from censorship. Adults have experienced and seen a great deal, and it is futile to remove materials from the shelves. They are well - informed, and there is no reason to discard books that others may want to read. A library should offer materials that enhance intelligence, not limit it.  Censorship is pointless. People should make choices at their own risk. The content in movies, books, and magazines reflects the real world. It is impossible to block out all negative things. If someone finds something offensive, they can choose not to engage with it. Patrons should enter the library with the understanding that they are responsible for their own choices.  Libraries are places where people with different opinions and preferences gather. Censorship would lead to the loss of many materials due to the opinions of a few, disregarding the preferences of others. Everyone enjoys a wide variety of materials, and libraries should offer a broad selection. Therefore, censorship should not be implemented in libraries. It would reduce the available materials and likely result in fewer check - outs.

In my opinion, certain materials, including books, music, movies, and magazines, should not be removed from library shelves simply because they are considered offensive. Firstly, the definition of "offensive" is subjective. Is it content that discriminates against a particular group, creates negative attention, or is simply something one does not like? Anyone can enter a library and find something they dislike, but that does not necessarily mean it is offensive.  For example, both the National Geographic magazine and the [@CAPS1] magazine often feature pictures of naked people. Deciding which one to censor would spark a major argument about what is offensive and what is not, leading to a conflict between different viewpoints. Offensiveness is often a matter of perception; we can choose not to look at something we find unpleasant.  The [@ORGANIZATION1] and the [@CAPS2] may have differences, but if their respective holy books are on library shelves, neither can claim that the other's book is offensive just because it does not align with their beliefs. We have the First Amendment, which guarantees freedom of speech and the press. Just because we may not like what someone publishes does not make their work offensive, as it may appeal to a specific group of people. Every item in the library has a purpose, and if it does not serve our purpose, it is not offensive to us.  Libraries are places for a wide range of materials, including books, music, movies, and magazines. We visit libraries to conduct research, learn, and read the latest books in a series. Implementing censorship would hinder our ability to achieve these goals. We may be unable to complete a research project because a book is considered offensive, or we may be unable to listen to a new album because some find the lyrics offensive. Censorship would upset the general public more than not having it, as allowing everyone to check out what they want from the library ensures satisfaction.

I personally think that there's no need to remove materials like books, music, movies, and magazines from library shelves if they're considered offensive. First, how do we even define "offensive"? Is it something that discriminates against a group, creates negative attention, or is just something we don't like? Just because someone walks into a library and doesn't like something, it doesn't mean it's offensive.  Take the National Geographic magazine and the [@CAPS1] magazine. They both sometimes have pictures of naked people. If we start putting censorship on them, it'll start a huge argument about what's offensive and what's not. It's only offensive when we make it so. We have the choice not to pick up something we think might be offensive.  The [@ORGANIZATION1] and the [@CAPS2] might not get along, but if their holy books are in the library, they can't say one's book is offensive just because it doesn't match their beliefs. We have the freedom of speech and press. Just because we don't like what someone publishes doesn't make it offensive, as it might be for a group that likes it. Everything in the library has a purpose, and if it doesn't fit ours, it's not offensive to us.  Libraries are for books, music, movies, and magazines. We go there to check out books for research or to read the latest in a series. Censorship would stop us from doing these things. We might not be able to finish a research project because someone thought a book was offensive, or we can't listen to a new album because some people think the lyrics are too much. Having censorship would make people more unhappy than not having it. If everyone can check out what they want from the library, they'll be content.

I sincerely hope that children won't pick up inappropriate books or magazines in the library. However, we shouldn't censor movies, books, and other materials just because there are children everywhere. If I had the power, I would keep these uncensored materials on the shelves.  I believe that libraries should have uncensored books. If everything were censored, we would have little to read or watch. Censoring everything is unfair to the world. Everyone should be able to watch and read what they want without censorship. If people's favorite movies or music were censored, they might no longer find them enjoyable and stop watching or listening.  I don't think libraries should implement censorship. Some materials, like certain CD songs, may seem a bit offensive at times, but that's part of life. If you find something offensive, you can simply choose not to listen to it. There's no reason to remove it from the shelves just because some people don't like it. Maybe others enjoy that kind of music.  Children today are exposed to more and know more than they should. For example, they may be familiar with cursing. If a child sees cursing in a magazine at the library and their parents get angry, the parents shouldn't overreact. The library shouldn't censor materials because of such isolated incidents. Children will encounter such things sooner or later.  If I had the decision - making power, I would ensure that libraries keep their materials uncensored. These are the reasons why I think libraries shouldn't censor movies, music, and other materials.

The author is writing about removing books that adults don't want. They take out books with bad words or pictures. However, I don't believe they should be removed because some of these books are interesting. I'm not a fan of reading, but I have to read anyway, and I don't think these books should be removed. It's better to keep them so kids can read and learn from the pictures. Some books aren't bad for elementary kids, who like picture - books, while middle - school kids prefer chapter books and interesting ones. Parents want educational books to help kids learn new words and school - related things. Adults want books with meaning and knowledge. But I think they should leave these books for kids as they are at least educational. By doing so, adults will have more educated students to rely on.

I firmly believe that materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should not be removed from shelves just because they are considered offensive. People have different views and beliefs regarding various aspects, including religion, culture, and sexuality. While some may be offended by certain materials, others can gain information and learn new facts. Everyone perceives things differently, and each person has their own way of life and thought process. If one person deems a book offensive and removes it, others may start removing other materials too, which would eventually leave us with no books, music, movies, or magazines. In my opinion, it's ridiculous to remove materials from shelves just because they are found offensive. If someone finds a book, magazine, movie, or music offensive, they can simply choose not to engage with it again. These materials are valuable resources that help us learn. In America, we value freedom of speech. Removing materials from shelves is not the solution. We should respect different opinions and keep these resources available for everyone.

We should definitely keep books, music, movies, and magazines. Magazines and music are beneficial for many. Most people use music to concentrate on work, and magazines can provide topics for classwork. It makes no sense for someone to take away things that are helpful in life. So, those who want to remove books or other items should leave them alone. We need to fight for what we want. It shouldn't be up to others to decide what is good for us. In conclusion, these materials should remain on the shelves as they are valuable resources for all.

I believe that books, magazines, music, and movies should be taken off the shelf when someone wants to use them. If another person wants the same item, they should wait until it is returned. These items are meant to be used, not just displayed. Books and magazines are made to entertain and catch the reader's attention, as well as to help people learn new things. For example, in school, classroom books teach us math, history, and English. Magazines can be browsed even just for pictures. Music should be taken off the shelf to be listened to. It comes in various genres like rap, R&B, gospel, and soul. Music can tell us about people's lives, inspire us, and is an important part of life. Movies are meant to be watched. They can inspire people, tell life stories, and give us something to do when we're bored. In conclusion, we should take these items off the shelf, use them, and then put them back so others can enjoy them too. They are valuable resources that can enhance our lives and knowledge.

Why do people find small things offensive? In my opinion, everyone has their own idea of what is offensive. For instance, a parent might not want a book about '@CAPS2' on the shelf when their child is getting @CAPS2. But parents should consider that kids may need to know what @CAPS2 really means. Some movies, like @CAPS3 @CAPS4, are tough to watch, but they can help us understand what really happened to certain people. As the saying goes, seeing is believing. Music can be offensive to some, but it's a singer's way of expressing their feelings. We can't discriminate against them for their beliefs. Singers like @CAPS5 @CAPS6 may use bad words in their songs, but that's their way of getting their emotions across. In conclusion, we are all different and have our own opinions.
